The unique thing about Lahore Karahi is all the self service which I've never really had experience with. There is unlimited hot chai tea, wine glasses, water jugs in the refrigerator all DIY. I actually kinda liked it, you don't have to wait around for a server for simple requests at this casual dining spot. 

The food did take kind of long to come but I think the kitchen is small and everything is so fresh, it takes a bit and it's definitely worth the wait. I suppose don't come when you're in a rush and want to be in and out quickly. 

We started off with an order of samosa. It's REALLY simple. Not too many spices, no peas. This is a very basic samosa that gets the job done. I needed some extra salt. Their tamarind sauce is a bit too watery, but the flavor is still good. The cilantro/mint one was spot on. For the main meal, my partner ordered the chicken boti tikka. This was fantastic -- 4 huge pieces of tender and moist chicken in a beautiful bright red color and sauteed onions with lime on a skillet. It doesn't come with a sauce for dipping if you get naan, so be mindful of that. 

I ordered the chicken tikka masala which I really did enjoy, but the flavors are little bit muted compared to a great chicken tikka. Still though, with the naan and gravy I thoroughly enjoyed my meal. I have to say the naan at Lahore Karahi is off the charts. I might even go so far as to say this is the one of the best, if not the best naan I've ever had. It was super fresh, sooooo soft and chewy and delicious. They have so many kinds of naan, so next time I going to try one of the different flavors -- sesame naan, cheese naan, aloo paratha, Afghani naan, etc.  

We will definitely be back even if it's just for the naan.

excerpts: we order so many things for 3 people - half a tandoori chicken, shrimp briyani, saag paneer, fish tikka masala, veg tikka masala, cheese naan and garlic naan.
cheese naan.author: Christina L.
cheese naan.review:
lahore karahi has been on my list for a while, but since they dont deliver and is in a sketchier part of town, i've been holding off on trying. since the parents are in town though, and were shopping downtown, we decided to stop in because authentic indian food is hard to come by in shanghai...

the restaurant is very minimal and simple - everything is self serve (though they brought us plates and utensils (maybe we looked a bit lost).  we order so many things for 3 people - half a tandoori chicken, shrimp briyani, saag paneer, fish tikka masala, veg tikka masala, cheese naan and garlic naan. haah SUCH FATTIES. 

food came out reasonably fast and all of a sudden our table was full.  the naans were really thin and crispy, and the cheese one was delicious with the tikka sauce.  saag paneer was a bit underwhelming, not as liquidity as i usually like my saag. briyani had good flavors, but not a lot of shrimp.  my mom really enjoyed the tandoori chicken, and here was a good amount of it!  i thought the tikka was flavorful, but....missing SOMETHING.  dinner after tax & tip was $75 - a bargain for all this food (we had a bit of leftovers for my lunch the next day).  i probably wont be coming back given the location...and lack of memorable-ness.

excerpts:
Had the garlic naan, chicken cheese naan, chicken tikka masala, butter chicken, and lamb vindaloo.
The butter chicken was the best out of the three.
I prefer the chicken tikka masala better at Chutney, although the meat is really dry there.
The lamb vindaloo was nothing memorable but it wasn't bad.
You couldn't taste the chicken in the chicken cheese naan.
The meal was pretty inexpensive.
cheese naan.author: Heejin L.
cheese naan.review:
3.5
I thought this place maybe slightly better than some of the other places I have been to.  You order first, then sit.

Had the garlic naan, chicken cheese naan, chicken tikka masala, butter chicken, and lamb vindaloo.
The butter chicken was the best out of the three.
I prefer the chicken tikka masala better at Chutney, although the meat is really dry there.
The lamb vindaloo was nothing memorable but it wasn't bad.
You couldn't taste the chicken in the chicken cheese naan.
The meal was pretty inexpensive.

excerpts: Chilli Cheese Naan - Garlic naan is usually my go-to choice, but saw the chilli naan mentioned in some yelp reviews.
Had a nice kick to it.
cheese naan.author: Andrey L.
cheese naan.review:
Summary - Good Indian food. Hole-in-the-wall place that's good for lunch. Try the tandoori fish.

I came here for lunch on a weekday around noon. The place was pretty empty (2 - 3 other people there). There was a bit of a wait for the food to arrive (~25 minutes).

Tandoori Fish - Best dish by far. I haven't ordered fish at an Indian restaurant before, so wasn't sure what to expect, but turned out to be a great choice.

Chilli Cheese Naan - Garlic naan is usually my go-to choice, but saw the chilli naan mentioned in some yelp reviews. Had a nice kick to it. Would order again.

Lamb Vindaloo - Pretty good dish. Not extremely memorable, but the lamb was cooked well.
 
The place itself is pretty hole-in-the-wall, with about 10 - 15 tables.

excerpts: Others ordered chicken tikka masala, rice with garlic and cheese naan.
Loved the cheese naan!
Everything was great and will return on our next trip!
cheese naan.author: Daniella W.
cheese naan.review: Butter chicken was great! We had dinner on our trip and loved this place. Pretty relaxed vibe with great food. Others ordered chicken tikka masala, rice with garlic and cheese naan. Loved the cheese naan! Everything was great and will return on our next trip!

excerpts: Cheese naan was also really good.
cheese naan.author: Adam M.
cheese naan.review:
TL;DR - Brilliant food, great prices. Full of flavor, tender meat dishes.

So far I've had the Butter Chicken, Tikka Masala, Lamb Vindaloo, and Vegetable Korma. They were all exceptional. Some of the best indian food I've had in San Francisco. They took Korma to a whole new level for me. Cheese naan was also really good.

You order at the cash register when you walk in, so if your looking for a "nice" restaurant with attentive waiters this really isn't the place for you. I prefer ordering upfront it lets me enjoy my meal in peace and provides me the opportunity to leave when I want.

excerpts: Today I had the chicken tiki masala and cheese naan.
OMG
it was amazing!
Just walking into this joint gets me excited.
The service is ok, but the food makes up for it 110%.
As a local TL resident this is definitely a go-to.
Thanks for the best indian food.
cheese naan.author: Gus M.
cheese naan.review: I've been here a few times, but never got around to writing a review. Today I had the chicken tiki masala and cheese naan. OMG it was amazing! Just walking into this joint gets me excited. The service is ok, but the food makes up for it 110%. As a local TL resident this is definitely a go-to. Thanks for the best indian food.

excerpts: For starters, the Chicken Cheese Naan was so good.
The vegtable samosa was the weakest, not enough flavor and a little bland.
cheese naan.author: Vol T.
cheese naan.review:
The food here is solid. The Chicken Boti Tikka was pretty amazing. So moist and flavorful. Chicken Tikka Masala was also very good. For starters, the Chicken Cheese Naan was so good. The vegtable samosa was the weakest, not enough flavor and a little bland. But overall, the food is very good here.

3 stars is due to really slow service. We were there for late lunch.. we were the only ones in the restaurant. We asked for water.. he gestured towards the fridge for us to get the water carafe ourselves. There were a few tables that remained dirty with dishes and never cleaned the whole time we were there. And he took his time cooking our food. So service is very lacking. 

So... my advice is maybe try it and see what your expereince is. You can do takeout also.

excerpts: Especially the cheese naan....that's the best.
This used to be my regular spot when I lived in downtown SF.
It's probably the best naam and curry I've had here.
cheese naan.author: Megha J.
cheese naan.review: I have tried almost everything on the vegetarian menu. The food is mind blowing. Especially the cheese naan....that's the best. This used to be my regular spot when I lived in downtown SF. It's probably the best naam and curry I've had here.

excerpts: I usually get the Daal Masala, Chicken Tikka Masala (best I ever had!), and the garlic cheese naan (not on the menu, you have to ask for it.).
The chef/owner Guddu is also very nice.
cheese naan.author: Michael C.
cheese naan.review:
There is not much I can say here that hasn't been said. Lahore Karahi is the best indian food I have ever had, meanin yes it is the best indian food in the bay area. It is the high bar that all other indian food are judged by. Yes it is in a sketchy neighborhood, so just bring your mace spray or get a cab it's worth it. The food is also very inexpensive and it is BYOB. I know you're asking yourself a question right now, the answer is yes you will smell of Lahore until sunrise.

I usually get the Daal Masala, Chicken Tikka Masala (best I ever had!), and the garlic cheese naan (not on the menu, you have to ask for it.).  The chef/owner Guddu is also very nice.

excerpts: The hot chai (deeper and more intense than I expected), chicken tikka masala, cheese naan, and paneer tikka were also memorable: comforting, perfectly spiced, and cleanly flavored.
cheese naan.author: Brianne C.
cheese naan.review:
4.25 stars.

I have a serious issue with Lahore Karahi. I ate dinner here on my first night in San Francisco, a foodie city I have dreamed of visiting, and wanted to do nothing but return for dinner each subsequent night. It didn't matter that thousands of other places were waiting to change the way I think about food, I wanted Lahore's casual, lovingly prepared bowls of goodness! Guddu, I am holding you personally responsible.

The tandoori fish is incredible. Truly, this beautifully presented dish of spice-crusted butter fish is something special. The hot chai (deeper and more intense than I expected), chicken tikka masala, cheese naan, and paneer tikka were also memorable: comforting, perfectly spiced, and cleanly flavored. I also enjoyed the lamb saag, but wanted something a bit spicier. Still, I absolutely can't wait to return.

excerpts: Next up was the cheese Naan which was super tasty I must say.
For our entrees we ordered Spicy Chicken Boti, Lamb Boti and Bengan Bhartiia   all savory and mighty proper!
Also we got Lahore Karachi Rice which   was amazingly spiced and flavorful.
Nom nom nom nom nom...
For desert we tried the Gulab Jaman which are deep fried dough balls dipped in a honey like concoction pretty good
but I think I'll try something else next time.
Had a little Chi to wash it down also.
The service was decent and the owner/chef bid us farewell from the kitchen as we left.
This place has comfy mellow feel to it and is TOPZ in my book.
cheese naan.author: Timbo G.
cheese naan.review:
First of all I've been wanting to try this place forever and something always comes up for some reason or another. Went with some friends on a cold and crisp Sunday twilight session and let one person do the ordering since she is somewhat of a regular. We got the Papadam appetizer to start. Everything here is made to order here mind you. Paper thin and served with a buttermilk sauce and also a sweet plum sauce if my taste buds serve me right. 

Next up was the cheese Naan which was super tasty I must say. For our entrees we ordered Spicy Chicken Boti, Lamb Boti and Bengan Bhartiia   all savory and mighty proper! Also we got Lahore Karachi Rice which   was amazingly spiced and flavorful. Nom nom nom nom nom... For desert we tried the Gulab Jaman which are deep fried dough balls dipped in a honey like concoction pretty good but I think I'll try something else next time. Had a little Chi to wash it down also. The service was decent and the owner/chef bid us farewell from the kitchen as we left. This place has comfy mellow feel to it and is TOPZ in my book. I'll be taking some other friends here very soon if I have my say.

Oh yeah white rice ='s boring people fyi... Chowmerz..

excerpts:
- keema naan
- garlic naan
keema naan.author: Nicole H.
keema naan.review:
Food was above average but gave me tummy aches at night/the day after.

Yums:
- lamb tikka masala (lamb SO tender!! yummy!!!!)
- keema naan
- garlic naan

Meh:
- butter chicken (chicken dry/sauce not as tasty as tikka masala)

excerpts: I think my personal favorite was the aloo and Keema naan.
keema naan.author: Matthew M.
keema naan.review: Naans were outstanding! Biryani was one of the best in the bay. Chicken Karahi was solid. Looking forward to trying their other options. I think my personal favorite was the aloo and Keema naan.

excerpts: We ordered all kinds... even ones not on the menu (Keema Naan).
Everything was reasonably priced except for the soda cans!!!
(If you can avoid ordering the overpriced drinks... then you won't be angry about having to pay $3 for a can of Sprite/Pepsi when a fresh homemade Naan straight from the oven is only $1.
(But I could be wrong about the price of the drinks since I didn't actually look at the bill personally and just going by what one member of our party was saying...
keema naan.author: Kit S.
keema naan.review:
We love good Indian/Pakistani food...there are far too many eateries out there with substandard dishes (especially the cheap buffets!!!)  We don't like to waste our time, so we rely on reading reviews here to help us when eating out of town.  We liked the reviews we read and decided to take a chance at Lahore Karahi.

We were not disappointed!!!  There were 6 of us, including a 4 year old who thought everything was too spicy except for the Naan... the rest of us enjoyed everything from the Butter Chicken (the best I've ever had...just the right blend of spices and texture-I ordered mild but the 4 year old still thought it was too spicy,  to the grilled plates, tandoori fish, kabobs and saag paneer for our vegetarian daughter).

My husband liked the kabob a lot!!!  He is very picky about his Kabobs since he is from Iran and eating good Kabobs is very important to him. 

I must say, the highlight of the evening was eating the tasty fresh out of the the tanoor, Naans.  We ordered all kinds... even ones not on the menu (Keema Naan).  Everything was reasonably priced except for the soda cans!!!  (If you can avoid ordering the overpriced drinks... then you won't be angry about having to pay $3 for a can of Sprite/Pepsi when a fresh homemade Naan straight from the oven is only $1.  (But I could be wrong about the price of the drinks since I didn't actually look at the bill personally and just going by what one member of our party was saying... which is why I didn't take a star away from my ratings.)  

Anyway, our server, a young boy (probably owner's son) was very polite and pleasant, but distracted probably because many people do go through.  We were lucky to be there when it wasn't quite so busy just yet.

I highly recommend this place... especially for those tired of the same menu and blah taste of the usual Paskistani/Indian food.  This place is small.. a bit of a hole int he wall.. but worth venturing to!  You won't regret it!

excerpts: The chili naan was delicious and we each had super tasty kormas.
The prices were so cheap and the service was friendly.
I will definitely be back to this Tenderloin treasure again.
My stomach is so happy right now.
chili naan.author: Megna M.
chili naan.review: This place was a pleasant surprise.  My husband and I were on our way to Little Delhi for dinner and the orange walls, Christmas lights in the windows, and packed tables beckoned us, so we entered.  It was a delicious taste treat.  The chili naan was delicious and we each had super tasty kormas.  The prices were so cheap and the service was friendly.  I will definitely be back to this Tenderloin treasure again.  My stomach is so happy right now.

excerpts: The chili naan dipped in the sauce from the fridge...
chili naan.author: Craig H.
chili naan.review: Loved it. The chili naan dipped in the sauce from the fridge...the garlic naan soaking up all the goo from my lamb bhunna. I am still a bit of a newbie to Pakistani food, so they may be getting by on my ignorance. But, as far as I am concerned, other places will have to live up to the expectations that this place has given me.

excerpts: I was thinking it would be more like this other sweet naan
I was in search of, but this reminded me more of a fruitcake naan.
Same colors and odd taste.
sweet naan.author: Cindy W.
sweet naan.review:
I pass this place on the 38 bus every day. And the only reason I had the courage to go (since it was in the tenderloin) was because I had a coupon from the Entertainment book (xmas gift). So I gathered 3 other friends and went. 

Wow - it was really good! We had plain and afghani naan, lamb biryani, karahi chicken, prawn curry. Each dish was brought out separately, and not necessarily in order. Meaning, the naan arrived with nothing else at first. I asked the owner/chef and he responded that one must wait because everything is made fresh. Not exactly the answer I was looking for but ok. And I wasn't disappointed when he and his assistant (it was a 2-man operation) came with the curries. The sauces were flavorful, hot, and fresh. 

If you read my other review, you'll know I'm not a lamb fan, but my 2 other friends devored the biryani. Seems like a good sign. My only disappointment was the Afghani naan. I was thinking it would be more like this other sweet naan I was in search of, but this reminded me more of a fruitcake naan. Same colors and odd taste. But hey, what do I know.

I'd definitely go back, without fear nor coupons (the bill was $40 for FOUR people with a few non alcoholic drinks + tip). Be adventurous and go! Just remember to be patient or else you'll be reprimanded too.

excerpts: My favs, chicken tiki masala, naan bread, rice and aloo saag, tandoori fish.
If the restaurant is to dirty for you cause you're use to going to apples bees, chills and bj's, then get to go.
aloo saag.author: Sarah T.
aloo saag.review: The people complaining about the self serve are funny, you're not in the burbs anymore this is SF! Welcome to an awesome hole in the wall restaurant, where you can byob, wine or liquor. I crave Lahore and my friends that are from Indian and Pakistan co-sign on this place. The owner/mom comes in the morning and preps the food. I try and come here once a week. My favs, chicken tiki masala, naan bread, rice and aloo saag, tandoori fish. If the restaurant is to dirty for you cause you're use to going to apples bees, chills and bj's, then get to go.

excerpts: I can't say that I know what anything tasted like (except that the aloo saag was heavy on fenugreek and light on aloos) aside from incredibly, stomach-gurgling-ly, pores-on-scalp-opening spicy.
aloo saag.author: Jennifer N.
aloo saag.review:
A year ago, my husband and I were eating dinner with his parents in Calcutta. His mother ordered a coriander and corn soup which was so spicy that I declared "the pores on my scalp are opening up." I literally felt like my head was sweating. I don't remember it as a good feeling - just as a strange feeling of being both warm and cold simultaneously.  I had that same experience at Lahore a few nights ago.  I can't say that I know what anything tasted like (except that the aloo saag was heavy on fenugreek and light on aloos) aside from incredibly, stomach-gurgling-ly, pores-on-scalp-opening spicy.  If you like red chilis in just about everything, even in your daal, this might be the place for you.

On the plus side: This wasn't quite as divey as I expected based on reviews - in fact, there were plenty of folks enjoying a Friday night date when we were there two nights ago. I don't mean to suggest that this is a romantic place (it isn't) but a few reviews described it as smoky and grimy, and it was neither. Just slow and spicy.

excerpts: We also got an order of chicken boti tikka and some aloo saag.
They were great.
Was surprised the tikka didn't come with lemons, it seems to in most places.
But the meat was flavorful and cooked properly.
The aloo saag was tasty and spicy, but
not overly so.
aloo saag.author: Sweet A.
aloo saag.review:
We stumbled onto this place while cruising the Tenderloin and loved the food. It's one of those little unassuming hole-in-the-wall places. The crowd was happy, the food was tasty and the prices were great.

The tablecloth was under glass but still dirty. The guy taking our order couldn't be forced to smile and I can usually break through to anyone. But it was a fun experience and we'd return. 

You order at the counter, grab some glasses, and help yourself to a carafe of water from the fridge. People around us were bringing in their own wine from a nearby store.

There were three of us. We got 3 orders of naan. Each piece was huge! Nice flavor, perfect combo of crisp outside and tender inside. We got 2 orders of rice. It was a little dry, like it had been cooked quite a bit earlier, but still flavorful. We also got an order of chicken boti tikka and some aloo saag. They were great. Was surprised the tikka didn't come with lemons, it seems to in most places. But the meat was flavorful and cooked properly. The aloo saag was tasty and spicy, but not overly so. The potatoes had good texture. 

Our total for all of this food, with plenty of leftovers, was $28. Amazing! If we lived nearby, we'd be regulars.

excerpts: Luckily the samosas were pretty good, as was the aloo saag, and the chicken tikka was great.
aloo saag.author: Susanna W.
aloo saag.review: Pretty good food, but we ordered takeout, and they got half our order wrong. Unfortunately I didn't check too closely when we picked it up, just peeked in the bag and checked their receipt to make sure it was mine. Got back to the hotel and found we'd been given veg samosa instead of veg pakora, and kulfi instead of gulab jamun. Luckily the samosas were pretty good, as was the aloo saag, and the chicken tikka was great. But the kulfi was melted by the time we figured out it wasn't gulab jamun (it was heavily wrapped in tin foil) and it was just ok. Decent food, careless service.

excerpts: We also ordered two vegetable curries - Benghan Bharta and Aloo Saag.
aloo saag.author: Tinna H.
aloo saag.review:
Updated without a true update because it deserves five stars. I can easily say this is one of my favorite Indian places. Delicious and cheap, just the way I like it. 

I can never remember the full name of this restaurant. I always say something along the lines of "Lahore Blah Blah Blah" or "that Lahore place." Service is slow and strange. Over the fantastic birthday weekend, we had the most bizarre dining experience ever. It was a little stressful, but oh-so-delicious! Twilight zone dinner. Every action taken was first discussed in our committee of three. 

Should we sit down? 

Do we order here, or will he come over here? 

Do we get our own plates? 

Should we grab some water? Silverware, maybe? 

Is this our food? 

Does this come with rice?

Where's our other naan? 

Should we pay our bill from the table or bring it to the register? 

What's going on!?!

Why isn't he bringing our change? Should we have paid with credit card instead? 

The Garlic Naan was like a mini garlic pizza - delicious! The Chicken Tikka Masala was surprisingly not just sauce and a few bits of chicken like at other places. We also ordered two vegetable curries - Benghan Bharta and Aloo Saag. Tasty!

With all the discussions that took place, the dinner lasted quite a long time. So come here if you have the time. Plus, there is just one person cooking the delicious food. Well worth the wait if you've got the time! I'm trying the Tandoori Chicken next time - it's supposedly their signature dish.

excerpts: Bengan Bartha, Butter Chicken, Garlic Naan, Aloo Saag.
aloo saag.author: Heather R.
aloo saag.review:
Lahore Karahi is that "little spot" you bring your new girlfriend or boyfriend to in the city to show off how you, too, know a quaint family- owned joint in the heart of the Tenderloin that only a true San Franciscan would know about. One time, I showed up with a group of friends for dinner. We decided we were to have a feast of epic proportions and after checking out the menu, we ordered whatever sounded good.  The waiter totally indulged us, making great recommendations on the menu and helping set up a SERIOUS spread of INEXPENSIVE food.  

Even though the wait for food can be a little long (I wouldn't recommend Lahore if you're in a rush, but definitely must after seeing a show at the Great American Music Hall) because of the two-man crew that runs the restaurant, you don't mind because you're either a) completely engrossed in the Bollywood movies playing on the tiny monitor in the corner of the restaurant or you're b) enjoying the view of a crack deal outside.    

Thumbs up for: Bengan Bartha, Butter Chicken, Garlic Naan, Aloo Saag.  Enough options for the meat lover AND the humble herbivore.

Pick up beer or wine from one of the liquor stores just outside.  And don't listen to the waiter when he gives you a hard time for refilling your own water.  Enjoy.

excerpts: The Aloo Saag was also had great flavor and a rich, creamy texture.
aloo saag.author: Aaron S.
aloo saag.review:
The food here is absolutely great curry-house fare but the service is nearly non-existent.

We went here just before the dinner rush on New Year's Eve and as soon as we walked in I was a bit dismayed that most the tables were really messy. However, I knew from the beginning that this was a curry joint in the Tenderloin not an upscale restaurant

The Lamb Vindaloo (often a benchmark in my evaluation of curry houses) was extremely flavorful and the lamb perfectly cooked. However, I ordered it "extra spicy" and it wasn't hot at all. The Aloo Saag was also had great flavor and a rich, creamy texture. The vegatable pakoras were perfectly fried and not at all greasy and the garlic naan was also excellent.

The price is right so I will definitely return if I'm in the area. The only detractor is that the service is awful. Expect to ask for things like silverware, your bill, etc. and don't expect them to honor any special requests. The upside is that this saves you from having to leave a big tip!

excerpts: I got the Mango Lassi, Vegetable Samosa, Vegetable Korma and I enjoyed all.
The Mango Lassi is very good.
The Vegetable Korma is a mild curry but you can ask to make it spicy.
They ask what percent spicy you want it, if you want it spicy.
The drinks you grab yourself if you want water, tea, canned soda, but the Mango Lassi is on the menu.
There are a lot of vegetarian choices as well as meat choices and seafood.
vegetable korma.author: Apolline B.
vegetable korma.review: Very delicious food and a warm environment. I'm a vegetarian but my family is not. We all enjoyed our food. I got the Mango Lassi, Vegetable Samosa, Vegetable Korma and I enjoyed all. The Mango Lassi is very good. The Vegetable Korma is a mild curry but you can ask to make it spicy. They ask what percent spicy you want it, if you want it spicy. The drinks you grab yourself if you want water, tea, canned soda, but the Mango Lassi is on the menu. There are a lot of vegetarian choices as well as meat choices and seafood.

excerpts: The Vegetable Korma and Chicken Makhani were hits.
In general, the food had a bit of kick to it, but it was never too spicy.
vegetable korma.author: Mark C.
vegetable korma.review:
This place is DOPE! From start to finish, absolute greatness was delivered to our table. The Lamb Samosa appetizer was great. The Vegetable Korma and Chicken Makhani were hits. In general, the food had a bit of kick to it, but it was never too spicy. The Mango and Cashew Indian Ice Cream sealed the deal on our great meal. 

I can't believe I'm saying this, given the somewhat shady neighborhood, but I actually want to come back!

excerpts: So far I've had the Butter Chicken, Tikka Masala, Lamb Vindaloo, and Vegetable Korma.
They were all exceptional.
Some of the best indian food I've had in San Francisco.
They took Korma to a whole new level for me.
vegetable korma.author: Adam M.
vegetable korma.review:
TL;DR - Brilliant food, great prices. Full of flavor, tender meat dishes.

So far I've had the Butter Chicken, Tikka Masala, Lamb Vindaloo, and Vegetable Korma. They were all exceptional. Some of the best indian food I've had in San Francisco. They took Korma to a whole new level for me. Cheese naan was also really good.

You order at the cash register when you walk in, so if your looking for a "nice" restaurant with attentive waiters this really isn't the place for you. I prefer ordering upfront it lets me enjoy my meal in peace and provides me the opportunity to leave when I want.

excerpts: We ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala, Vegetable Korma, and Garlic Naan.
The Vegetable Korma was gross.
It lacked variety of vegetables and tasted chemically.
Some of the vegetables tasted pickled...maybe.
Either way, fresh it was not.
The garlic naan was nothing to write home about.
I did not get the impression
it was fresh.
vegetable korma.author: Kiki I.
vegetable korma.review:
I give them 3 stars because the Giants game was on and the free tea was solid.

We ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala, Vegetable Korma, and Garlic Naan.  We later realized we needed rice.

The chicken was dry.  Although they cook to order, the chicken and other items are prepared ahead of time and sitting out.  So, that explains it.  Otherwise, the flavor of the Tikka Masala was fairly well rounded and a bit sweet.  We asked for spicy and it was not.

The Vegetable Korma was gross.  It lacked variety of vegetables and tasted chemically.  Some of the vegetables tasted pickled...maybe.  Either way, fresh it was not.  It was disappointing to say the least.

The garlic naan was nothing to write home about.  I did not get the impression it was fresh.  The garlic was a boost, but not enough to save it.

Based upon the reviews, I was disappointed.  I do not think I would go back.

excerpts: I like the vegetable Korma the best there.
Tell them to make it spicy it tastes great.
Enjoy !
vegetable korma.author: Vikash G.
vegetable korma.review: Great Food. I've been coming here for the past 4 years and love it. It's a hole in the wall place.  It's a small place and is visited by regulars so be prepared to wait for table if you are coming after 7 PM. Service is also a little slow BUT food is delicious , inexpensive and it's a BYOB. Yes , so get some beers or white wine and drink while waiting for the food. I like the vegetable Korma the best there. Tell them to make it spicy it tastes great. Enjoy !

excerpts: For main course, we ordered Vegetable Korma, Bhindi Masala, Roti and Garlic Naan.
The Garlic Naan was good, the Roti was fine, the Bhindi Masala was barely palatable, and the Vegetable Korma was simply un-eatable.
The Garlic Naan was good, the Roti was fine, the Bhindi Masala was barely palatable, and the Vegetable Korma was simply un-eatable.
vegetable korma.author: Saurabh G.
vegetable korma.review:
Close to the worst Indian/Pakistani Food I have ever had in the US over the last 2 years. 

For starters, we ordered Vegetable Pakoras, most of them were over-fried. For main course, we ordered Vegetable Korma, Bhindi Masala, Roti and Garlic Naan. The Garlic Naan was good, the Roti was fine, the Bhindi Masala was barely palatable, and the Vegetable Korma was simply un-eatable. On top of food being absolutely tasteless, there was an overwhelming amount of oil in the entres. 

Apart from the food, the ambience was pretty bad too, and the place could seriously use better cleaning of utensils (yes!!!), and tables.

I would not revisit this place.

excerpts: Ordered Aloo Ghobi and Garlic Naan for a quick take out dinner.
The Aloo Ghobi was lacking all flavor and was dry-
did they forget to put the spices in?
I've never had Indian Food that I didn't finish, until now!
Maybe I chose the wrong dish?
Or maybe they were having a off night?
Major bummed out!
Wish I would have saved my $14.
aloo ghobi.author: Pamela R.
aloo ghobi.review: I really hate to be that person... but here I am.  Ordered Aloo Ghobi and Garlic Naan for a quick take out dinner.  The Aloo Ghobi was lacking all flavor and was dry- did they forget to put the spices in?  I've never had Indian Food that I didn't finish, until now!  Maybe I chose the wrong dish? Or maybe they were having a off night?  Major bummed out! Wish I would have saved my $14.

excerpts: This is one of the best aloo ghobi and chicken Karahi place with chilli naan I've experienced in San Francisco area.
The crown and ambience might not be the best but this rating is purely based on the taste and authenticity of the dishes ordered.
Keep up the great tasting Pakistani and Indian cuisine!!
aloo ghobi.author: Moon S.
aloo ghobi.review: This is one of the best aloo ghobi and chicken Karahi place with chilli naan I've experienced in San Francisco area. The crown and ambience might not be the best but this rating is purely based on the taste and authenticity of the dishes ordered. Keep up the great tasting Pakistani and Indian cuisine!!

excerpts: Ordered recently for the first time (Lamb Korma; Butter Chicken; Aloo Ghobi; Garlic Naan; Veggie Samosas; Rice).
Loved everything, especially the Butter Chicken and Lamb Korma.
Upon first glance, the meat dishes seemed somewhat "greasy" (this was mostly noticed upon hardening after refrigerating).
However, be it fat or oil or whatever
(and I have no issue with enjoying fat), the ingredients mixed back together wonderfully, and this was one of the tastiest places at which I've had these dishes.
aloo ghobi.author: Tommy M.
aloo ghobi.review:
Ordered recently for the first time (Lamb Korma; Butter Chicken; Aloo Ghobi; Garlic Naan; Veggie Samosas; Rice). 

Loved everything, especially the Butter Chicken and Lamb Korma. Upon first glance, the meat dishes seemed somewhat "greasy" (this was mostly noticed upon hardening after refrigerating). However, be it fat or oil or whatever (and I have no issue with enjoying fat), the ingredients mixed back together wonderfully, and this was one of the tastiest places at which I've had these dishes. Flavors were bold, spicy, consistent and very well balanced. 

Can't wait to order again. Very impressed with the flavor.

excerpts: We got the aloo ghobi (potato) and eggplant curry, but both came out in such a small portion order and everything was a little too overcooked (especially the dry samosas).
The place wasn't full house status, but there were other groups and tables filled besides our party of two.
They do give you take-home boxes in
aloo ghobi.author: Jodi H.
aloo ghobi.review:
Ate dinner before a show at the Great American Music Hall just a block away, and felt that it didn't live up to the Indian food standards in South Bay--primarily Sunnyvale (whaddup).

We walked in and service wasn't on point, but they did seem understaffed. There were three guys in the open kitchen working their butts off, and only one cashier. SHOUTOUT to the workers because they seemed so tired and overworked. I give them 5 stars, but the food itself wasn't anything to get excited about.

We were starving after driving up from South Bay, and got our favorite starter: samosas, two curries, and regular naan and garlic naan--our usual order. We got the aloo ghobi (potato) and eggplant curry, but both came out in such a small portion order and everything was a little too overcooked (especially the dry samosas). The place wasn't full house status, but there were other groups and tables filled besides our party of two. They do give you take-home boxes in case you can't finish your food, and it's a no frills kind of spot, just how I like my Indian food joints.

Plus: they have a clean restroom and lots of tap water in their fridge, Indian style! It's convenient and there are lots of street parking spots nearby. However, for our Friday night, it wasn't the most affordable (total came out to approx $40 for two), largest portions, or tastiest (rather, it was really dry) food.

excerpts: You can't go wrong with any of the matar mushroom, bengan bharta, choley, aloo ghobi, or daal masala.
aloo ghobi.author: James D.
aloo ghobi.review:
Free chai, generous quantities, and insanely low prices. I've brought groups of four hungry young people here and left with all of our heads spinning trying in the new reality where we're all stuffed silly and the bill comes to $45. I've brought friends from France, China, Portugal, Greece, Cameroon, Korea and all over the USA in and everyone left satisfied. Something about the open kitchen and utilitarian decor adds to the experience; it's alive with noise and spice.

The veggie options are also executed so skillfully that no veggie eater will ever feel deprived. You can't go wrong with any of the matar mushroom, bengan bharta, choley, aloo ghobi, or daal masala. The answer to every line in the menu is always Yes.

Pro tip: They allow and it seems even somewhat encourage the BYOB option, so feel free to wander in with a bottle of wine or a sixer from any of the nearby convenience stores.

excerpts:
* ALOO GHOBI ($7.99) - 4 STARS:
Pretty standard but what makes this dish extra special is that you can order it without the potatoes which to me is such a filler ingredient
aloo ghobi.author: Jess C.
aloo ghobi.review:
I love Indian food and I've been wanting to come to Lahore Karahi for ages now - it's a small ghetto Indian restaurant in the tenderloin. Not super convenient and a little scary to walk to at night. 

When you walk in, pick up a plastic covered menu and sit anywhere. I smashed a large insect crawling on the table with my menu - how multi-functional. You order at the cash register, and I *loved* that you could modify the ingredients (I got ghobi aloo without the potatoes). They have Square and can split checks, woohoo for credit cards. 

All in all, solid Indian food and will be coming back again soon for the tandoori fish! For $40 total before tip, this was enough food for 2 girls with a little leftover for lunch for one the next day.

* TANDOORI FISH ($11.99) - 5 STARS: 
Grilled tilapia (claimed to be strictly grilled, not battered) crispy and salty on the outside, but tender on the inside, served on a sizzling plate. While this could be considered on the expensive side, it included ~5 small filets - not a bad deal!

* CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA ($8.99) - 3 STARS:
I've never been a huge fan of tikka masala because the sauce is too creamy and the chicken is usually too dry. This did not break any stereotypes for me, and the portion of chicken was meager.

* ALOO GHOBI ($7.99) - 4 STARS:
Pretty standard but what makes this dish extra special is that you can order it without the potatoes which to me is such a filler ingredient I don't need to have.

* BINDI MASALA ($7.99) - 4 STARS:
Again, pretty standard okra dish but I loved that it was chock full of okra rather than fill ingredients like peas, onions and potatoes.

excerpts:
Below is my thought process:

I subtracted a star for the amount of oil in my Aloo Ghobi.
aloo ghobi.author: Emily D.
aloo ghobi.review:
Indian food to Jenna F. and me is no joke. We don't f. around. Especially not Jenna F. That b. is no f.er. 

Our weekly dinner date rolls around, and its my week to pick. This week in the land of legal eduaction sucked some major b's. Thus, I made the decision. It was time. Time for Jenna F. and I to quit f.ing around and try some S.F. indian. 

Yelp, you did not let me down. But because law school has left me f.'d in the head, I f.'d around hard deciding what stars to give it. Below is my thought process:

I subtracted a star for the amount of oil in my Aloo Ghobi. F. thats a lot of oil....

Then I added a star because of how home cooked and REAL it was. F. that s. was home cooked!

Then I subtracted a star because when the waiter came back, and we were ready to order more DELICIOUS garlic naan, he handed us a check. And we didn't get any more delcious garlic naan. =( F.! that naan is great!

Then I added a star for the delicious garlic naan. F.! THAT NAAN IS GREAT!

Then I added another imaginary star because our food was F.ING FANTASTIC!!!

excerpts: The roti was the consistency of naan, the rice was plain white rice with a few slivers of carrot and minimal spice, and the Aloo ghobi had no sauce whatsoever.
And there was no one in the restaurant at 7:30 pm.
There ya go.
aloo ghobi.author: Lishdish R.
aloo ghobi.review:
Lahore Karahi has fallen off the tallest pedestal.  I have fought the urge to go back to LK since Guddu sold the restaurant some time ago.  Tonight I gave in and really wish I hadn't.  Aside from ordering for delivery using delivery.com and then getting a call that they didnt have  anyone working that could deliver (umm, I literally live across the street) I found the food no short of disgusting.  No joke.  How can food be bland and spicy at the same time?  Well, it can be.  The butter chicken was in a sauce that looked radio-active and was watery.  The roti was the consistency of naan, the rice was plain white rice with a few slivers of carrot and minimal spice, and the Aloo ghobi had no sauce whatsoever.  And there was no one in the restaurant at 7:30 pm.  There ya go.  What a huge (yet predictable) disappointment.  

The major silver lining to this dark cloud is that thanks to yelp reviewers I now see that Guddu is back in SF and has a new restaurant!  While it's apparently in the middle of nowhere (outer sunset) I will be able to enjoy Guddu's artistry again very soon.  I can almost smell the love of his cooking already!

Steer clear of LK.

excerpts: Aloo ghobi is delicious, rich on coriander and other spices.
Lamb korma is similarly great.
Even rice is more earthy, more hearty and again, different from most other places.
aloo ghobi.author: Evg R.
aloo ghobi.review:
The previous reviewers seem to complain about lots of things regarding this place... except few of them have to do with the food itself. Yes, like most Tenderloin places, Lahore Karahi is not about friendly or even timely service. Neither it is about cleanliness, great location, or impeccable take out packaging. 

No. This place is strictly about food. After you are half-starved waiting for at least 40 minutes for your meal to arrive, it strikes you with its aroma and then - its unique taste. This place is no regular Indian restaurant. It is Pakistani-Indian, which really means Pakistani, and unlike most similar joints in the area, it seems to take pride in it. Chicken tikka masala is indeed very different here from most places in town - it is more flavourful, richer in taste and just right in consistency of the curry. Aloo ghobi is delicious, rich on coriander and other spices. Lamb korma is similarly great. Even rice is more earthy, more hearty and again, different from most other places. Finally, nan and kulcha are krispy, fragrant and delicious. 

I used to get frustrated about the extremely slow service, cockroaches on walls and the wrong order of food being brought to my table. But all this is irrelevant compared to the actual quality of food. Think of this place as someone's home and come here as a guest, not a demanding patron. Then you will keep coming back for more.

excerpts: His Aloo Ghobi is out of this world.
His nan is fresh and right out of the oven.
He always gives me a free dessert.
Heaven.
aloo ghobi.author: Joanna S.
aloo ghobi.review: I love Gudoo.  He thought that I was only 22 years old.  His Aloo Ghobi is out of this world.  His nan is fresh and right out of the oven.  He always gives me a free dessert.  Heaven.

excerpts: If the Bollywood flicks on t.v. don't steal your heart, the palak paneer, aloo ghobi, garlic naan, and samosas will!
Truly a place where my Tandoori-culinary-love can roam!
Lahore Karahi is, hands down, the BEST Indian/Pakistani food I've had in San Francisco!
(And Gudu is a real charmer too!)
aloo ghobi.author: G D.
aloo ghobi.review: If the Bollywood flicks on t.v. don't steal your heart, the palak paneer, aloo ghobi, garlic naan, and samosas will! Truly a place where my Tandoori-culinary-love can roam! Lahore Karahi is, hands down, the BEST Indian/Pakistani food I've had in San Francisco! (And Gudu is a real charmer too!) ;)

excerpts: My buddy had the Basmati rice (we were told by the busser that the rice was organic, kudos...) and Aloo Ghobi (extremely delicious, perfectly prepared)
The Chai was nothing special, but the busser, owner, price point, and food all get 5 stars from this chef....
aloo ghobi.author: Samuel J.
aloo ghobi.review: Unbelievably great !   I knew about Lahore, which is in my neighborhood, but i had never eaten there, due to having so many good options in the TL for food. After reading the reviews for this place on Yelp, i decided to check it out and man, what a smart decision that was.. The Naan was out of this world. I also had the Butter Chicken which was so flavorful and had a nice portion of protein in it. My buddy had the Basmati rice (we were told by the busser that the rice was organic, kudos...) and Aloo Ghobi (extremely delicious, perfectly prepared) The Chai was nothing special, but the busser, owner, price point, and food all get 5 stars from this chef....

excerpts: You can't go wrong with any of the matar mushroom, bengan bharta, choley, aloo ghobi, or daal masala.
choley.author: James D.
choley.review:
Free chai, generous quantities, and insanely low prices. I've brought groups of four hungry young people here and left with all of our heads spinning trying in the new reality where we're all stuffed silly and the bill comes to $45. I've brought friends from France, China, Portugal, Greece, Cameroon, Korea and all over the USA in and everyone left satisfied. Something about the open kitchen and utilitarian decor adds to the experience; it's alive with noise and spice.

The veggie options are also executed so skillfully that no veggie eater will ever feel deprived. You can't go wrong with any of the matar mushroom, bengan bharta, choley, aloo ghobi, or daal masala. The answer to every line in the menu is always Yes.

Pro tip: They allow and it seems even somewhat encourage the BYOB option, so feel free to wander in with a bottle of wine or a sixer from any of the nearby convenience stores.

excerpts:
I'll keep that in mind for next time..

LAHORI CHIKKAR CHOLEY - 5.50
Garbanzo beans cooked in a special blend of tomatoes and onions 
- A little too starchy/salty (if I'm being picky).
choley.author: Ziyan C.
choley.review:
I always say you know it's an authentic Indian hole-in-the-wall when there's a VCR TV on the wall playing Bollywood music videos =).

Just know that it's self serve water, utensils, etc. And you have to go up to the counter to order. And it's this ONE guy cooking for and serving everyone!! So even at 10pm on a weeknight our food took a while. 

Oh and it's BYOB! I'll keep that in mind for next time..

LAHORI CHIKKAR CHOLEY - 5.50
Garbanzo beans cooked in a special blend of tomatoes and onions 
- A little too starchy/salty (if I'm being picky).

SHAHl PANEER - 7.50
Lightly fried cheese cooked with nuts in tomato sauce 
- Loved this!
- Slightly sweet yet tangy, with a tiny bit of a spicy kick at the end.
- Paneer was soft and chewy.

LAHORE KARAHI RICE - 2.00
Basmati rice seasoned with special blend of spices
- Not much here, mainly got it as a mixer for our curries. Rice is fairly dry, and I didn't taste much of the flavoring. You get a fairly giant plate though.

ONION KULCHA - 2.50
Naan stuffed with onions and fresh cilantro 
- Wonderful! Loved the onions in the middle.
- A tiny tiny tiny bit burnt on the bottom but I'm being picky.
- Otherwise perfect texture, fluffy but with a good slight crisp.

excerpts: That was: The choley, which tasted like a plate of mush.
I packed and left it on top of a garbage
can for a homeless person to take
and I'm pretty sure I got a dirty look from the guy who peeked inside.
The assorted meat platter had good kababs but the chicken and lamb had no flavor to them.
choley.author: Shreya C.
choley.review:
First, a caveat, I didn't get to order the dishes I normally would which usually results in me not liking the meal as much. Sadly, this place was no exception to the rule. The one dish, I will say, that blew me away was the Karahi chicken. Awesome dish and not one that's mentioned much in reviews because most people, myself included, would probably order the chicken tikka and tandoori fish like everyone else. Definitely try this dish. 

The rest of the stuff I ordered I wouldn't try again. That was: The choley, which tasted like a plate of mush. I packed and left it on top of a garbage can for a homeless person to take and I'm pretty sure I got a dirty look from the guy who peeked inside. The assorted meat platter had good kababs but the chicken and lamb had no flavor to them. The sesame naan and roti was ok but didn't live up to their potential. 

In all I'd go back to try the chicken tikka and tandoori fish but sadly find myself lowering my expectations about a place I've heard so much about.

excerpts: Choley!
Daal!
Nice texture and seasonings.
choley.author: Maggie R.
choley.review:
Great little spot for Lahori cuisine with great prices and friendly staff!  There are a number of restaurants serving Indian/Pakistani food in the area and this one is the best I've found.

Pros:
The owner is so nice and friendly!
Choley!  Daal!  Nice texture and seasonings.
Inexpensive
Great for eat-in or take-out
Brown basmati rice

Cons:
Samosas were not freshly fried

excerpts: I ordered Chicken Tikka Marsala, my Indian restaurant litmus test, and a chick pea dish, Lahori Chikkar Choley, along with rice and plain naan.
What a bargain ringing in at $20 including tip - very nice!
The Chicken Tikka Marsala wasn't the bright radioactive lava orange that I know and love - maybe that's actually a good thing!
The familiar spices and flavor came through on my first bite - but it was much denser, creamier, sweeter and less spicy than Shalimar.
It was a more subtle experience.
The juicy chicken was cooked perfectly and it all paired nicely with the lightly oiled brownish rice.
I enjoyed it, especially because it seemed less oily than Shalimar's.
The choley was another story.
It was super salty, cloying, dense and pretty much unpalatable.
I like chick peas in Indian dishes - but this one rubbed me the wrong way.
The naan also fell short of Shalimar.
Instead of offering a crisp exterior yielding to a delicately puffy and tender center, I gnawed on a crisp but dense hunk of flat bread.
And what was up with that yeasty sour flavor???
In fairness it served its purpose to cut the dish's sweet richness.
choley.author: Brady K.
choley.review:
Please accept my humble apology for the following novel in the guise of a review...

As a musician, I often fall into the trap of hearing only my favorite interpretation of a classic - such as Mozart's Requiem. Each crescendo or crack of the soprano's voice becomes the *only* way to hear the piece. My taste buds seem to have this dysfunction too because I kept comparing Lahore Karahi to Shalimar with each bite.

I was stoked to visit LK based on great feedback from yelpers with top notch cred. The delicious and filling food, super low price and my curiosity to find a new king of the hill over Shalimar beckoned my appetite.

I ordered Chicken Tikka Marsala, my Indian restaurant litmus test, and a chick pea dish, Lahori Chikkar Choley, along with rice and plain naan. What a bargain ringing in at $20 including tip - very nice! The Chicken Tikka Marsala wasn't the bright radioactive lava orange that I know and love - maybe that's actually a good thing! The familiar spices and flavor came through on my first bite - but it was much denser, creamier, sweeter and less spicy than Shalimar. It was a more subtle experience. The juicy chicken was cooked perfectly and it all paired nicely with the lightly oiled brownish rice. I enjoyed it, especially because it seemed less oily than Shalimar's. However I preferred the fiery kick and bolder flavors of Shalimar's orangey lava.  

The choley was another story. It was super salty, cloying, dense and pretty much unpalatable. I like chick peas in Indian dishes - but this one rubbed me the wrong way. The naan also fell short of Shalimar. Instead of offering a crisp exterior yielding to a delicately puffy and tender center, I gnawed on a crisp but dense hunk of flat bread. And what was up with that yeasty sour flavor??? In fairness it served its purpose to cut the dish's sweet richness. I shed a little tear cause I loves my naan.

I'll admit I avoid dining in the tenderloin. Walking from Van Ness to LK provides stereotypical tenderloin thrills and chills that I prefer avoiding. Unless we took a cab, I wouldn't be surprised if my girlfriend withheld sex because I made her walk in this crappy neighborhood.

I actually like the idea of hole in the wall restaurants, just so long as the cooking area is clean - or it's kept well hid. Nope, the kitchen's dirty and visible at LK. The show "Ramsay's Kitchen Nightmares" should film on location at LK. LK scores 80 on the SF Dept of Health inspection for exposed storage of food, unclean non-cooking surfaces and poor handwashing facilities. http://sfscores.com/#Yz0zNy43ODksLTEyMi40MSZ6PTE1Jmk9KDM3Ljc4NTU3MiwgLTEyMi40MTUwNjEpJmY9TGFob3JlJTIwS2FyYWhpJnMxPTAmczI9MTAwJm89cm5k

I did admire the Jackson Pollack-style art splattered behind the filthy stoves in shades of day old curry - oh wait! that is day old curry.  Dirty pans were everywhere and containers of ingredients were on the floor in front of the ovens. This sh** makes you go "Hmmmm." Aren't we all believers that a clean kitchen produces tastier, healthier food?

The owner of LK, "Guddhu" was really friendly. I liked the feel of the place and how Bollywood movies were playing in the background. You can tell this restaurant is part of the fabric of our fair city. For example, a customer came back and said something in an Pakistani dialect - perhaps she forgot to tip - and Guddhu smiled and waved a "no problem" and she thanked him.

It's not like Shalimar has a much better health score (86 and I've seen cockroaches there), but I'm still locked into hearing my Indian dishes conducted by Maestro Shalimar.

excerpts: We ordered the Sabzi (frozen mixed vegetable mush), paneer w/nuts (cloyingly sweet tomato sauce), and choley (not choley at all, but an assortment of mixed dals.)
We had asked for medium spicy and got bland---no spiciness whatsoever.
Our plain rice came 25 minutes later.
choley.author: Astrid X.
choley.review:
No, no, no and NO!

I LOVE Indian food---whatever the region. If it's hot, well-spiced and tasty, I'm the happy girl; no needy for fancy decor, fawning service, or even speed. And you won't ever hear me complain about having to bring in my own beer either.

Spurred by the rave multi-star reviews, this low-maintenance girl grabbed the BF and headed for Lahore Kahani. 2 1/2 hours later (no dessert), we were utterly gobsmacked by the relentless mediocrity and the slow, and I mean paralytically S   L  O   W  service. 

I was forewarned, and, consequently, prepared to wait patiently. However, what I wasn't prepared for was an interminable wait for a crappy ass meal. 

It wasn't even remotely crowded, but  our waitron, though nice enough, just wandered around in dazed, absent-minded circles, serving no one fast. 

We ordered the Sabzi (frozen mixed vegetable mush), paneer w/nuts (cloyingly sweet tomato sauce), and choley (not choley at all, but an assortment of mixed dals.) We had asked for medium spicy and got bland---no spiciness whatsoever. Our plain rice came 25 minutes later. The one truly exceptional item was the super tasty sesame naan.

Perhaps it was a fluke, but with the abundance of truly superb Indian restaurants in the bay area, there's really no motivation to give it a second chance.

excerpts: Saag, choley is great.
choley.author: Priya R.
choley.review:
This is my favorite indian/pakistani restaurant in the city.  The owner is the chef and the waiters work every day - they are the best people. Some people go in and expect american service - you aren't going to get that.  These people are salt of the earth and are very hard-working, but it may not translate to some five star tuxedo staff. (UPDATE: There is a NEW young waiter that SUCKS, but if you ignore him and even better yet, laugh at how bad he is, it won't be as bad.  UPDATE UPDATE: NEW WAITER AGAIN AND HE RULES!!!)

Now lets get to the food: everything is really spicy and each dish has its own set of spices.  You can go to the naan'n'curry's and shalimars and every dish tastes like each other.  NOT here.  Naan is buttery and fluffy, I've had the vegetable biriyani and it is SO yummy - full of interesting veggies.  Goat curry isn't on the menu but he always has it on hand.  Tandoor fish - best in the city.  Sheekh kebab - the lamb is mixed with these wonderful herbs and it comes sizzling to your table.  Saag, choley is great.  Dal Makhani is EXTRA spicy.  

The best part, if that is possible: the price.  We always leave HUGE tips because no one wants any money back.  

Perfect place for large parties (except you may not be able to get a table, this place gets PACKED), so try to go at an off time.

excerpts: I had the LAHORI CHIKKAR CHOLEY and the ALOO BENGAN.
It was so flavorful,
some sweet and some savoy.
The mango lassi here was unique, but very delicious- a little on the sweet side, but hey-
It's mango lassi -
It's suppose to be sweet!
The best part about this place is the Chef/Owner "Guddu," you will like him instantly upon meeting him!!
He's the one who will take your order, cook your food and check you out when you are done!
You will not believe this food...
Be prepared if going in the evening, it is in Tenderloin.
choley.author: Jonathan D.
choley.review: Folks, I eat a lot of Indian food and this is hands down the BEST Indian food that I have EVER had. I had the LAHORI CHIKKAR CHOLEY and the ALOO BENGAN. It was so flavorful, some sweet and some savoy. The mango lassi here was unique, but very delicious- a little on the sweet side, but hey- It's mango lassi - It's suppose to be sweet! The best part about this place is the Chef/Owner "Guddu," you will like him instantly upon meeting him!! He's the one who will take your order, cook your food and check you out when you are done! You will not believe this food... Be prepared if going in the evening, it is in Tenderloin.

excerpts: Favorite dishes are: Chicken Korma, Lamb Vindaloo, Lahori Chikkan Choley (garbanzo beans in yellow-tomato curry), and my favorite: the Bengan Bharta - it's a sweet roasted eggplant mixed with other richer spices which is a major mind-blower every time.
choley.author: Matt T.
choley.review:
This place is the essence of the outer-Tenderloin. It's got the kind of authentic, cheap, exotic food for food's sake that restaurants charging twice as much can't even begin to conjure. The decor is bland and you'll have to put in a real wait for the food, but Lahore always delivers on rich, textured tastes which make you wonder if some of the crack from the streets has made it into the food. The vegetarian options here are also the absolute best I've had in SF. 

I second some of these other reviews - my favorite experience of this place is to order for take-away and show up a the end of the 20-25 minute time frame the chef gives you. Take home and enjoy. This place won't make 5 stars for me until it improves the decor enough that I can be comfortable sitting in there with a first date through the made-to-order wait. 

Favorite dishes are: Chicken Korma, Lamb Vindaloo, Lahori Chikkan Choley (garbanzo beans in yellow-tomato curry), and my favorite: the Bengan Bharta - it's a sweet roasted eggplant mixed with other richer spices which is a major mind-blower every time. All these go great with the cinnamon-infused basmati rice which can be eaten as a stand-alone (very tasty, light rice). 

I know this place is a winner because my friends will often visit me in the tenderloin just to get some Lahore Karahi and indulge in my living room. As if I'm not exciting enough on my own!

excerpts: - Lahori Chikkar Choley ( Curry garbanzo beans which my friends and I found to be a bit too salty.
The only down side to our meal. )

- Tandoori Fish ( Juicy Chilean Sea Bass! )
- Garlic and Reg Naan.
( Garlic is the best.
choley.author: A.D. L.
choley.review:
Best Pakistani/Indian food I've ever had. My friends and I have been having "Lahore withdrawals" since they were closed for a whole month.

So we went this last Friday nite. I noticed the carpets have been replaced with hardwood floors. All the tables have been scrubbed down. Place is lookin A LOT better.

My friends and I ordered...
- Seekh Kababs ( perfectly seasoned, juicy morsels of ground lamb )
- Tandoori Chicken Breast ( Well seasoned and juicy piece of meat )
- Chicken Tikka Masala ( This is the best I've had. Sauce is freshly made; you can even hear the food processor chopping up the spices and pistachios right before he makes the sauce. )
- Lahori Chikkar Choley ( Curry garbanzo beans which my friends and I found to be a bit too salty. The only down side to our meal. )
- Tandoori Fish ( Juicy Chilean Sea Bass! )
- Garlic and Reg Naan. ( Garlic is the best. It's loaded with garlic. )

Better than any of the other Pakistani/Indian places I've had in the city. Anyone know a better place than this. Let me know. =)

excerpts: The choley looked and tasted like baby food.
The chickpeas looked like they had been purposefully smashed up.
Not cool.
choley.author: Nina S.
choley.review:
Being that it was my boyfriend's first time eating Indian food with his Indian girlfriend (me, not some other girlfriend), I was excited to eat here because of all the fabulous reviews. 

But dude, for realz....

The choley looked and tasted like baby food. The chickpeas looked like they had been purposefully smashed up. Not cool. The chicken in the tikka masala was just OK, not melt-in-your-mouth curry goodness like at, say, Mehfil, arguably one of the best Indian restaurants in San Francisco.

The saag was pretty dec. (that's decent for all you older peeps.)

The gentlemen running the joint are an absolute joy, which is why I feel pretty salty about giving this review. But it is what it is.

excerpts: The chicken tikka masala was unlike any I've ever had and their choley and palak paneer were leaps and bounds better than so many others.
choley.author: RugJones
choley.review:
Just got through with a lunch from Lahore Karahi and it definitely deserves all the love. It's the best of our Little Calcutta fo' sho'!


 The chicken tikka masala was unlike any I've ever had and their choley and palak paneer were leaps and bounds better than so many others.


 Give it a shot. You'll be happy.

excerpts: the chicken tikka, choley, and saag paneer were all excellent.
choley.author: Wendy S.
choley.review:
the best indian in SF!  i've been to indian oven, chutney, shalimar, and pakwan and i think lahore karahi is the best!  this place is tiny, but def worth a trip to the 'loin for some tasty indian cuisine.  this place doesn't have great ambiance, just really great food.  :)  

the lahore chicken is my fav dish so far, lots of fresh corriander (aka cilantro) and diced green chili peppers.  YUM!  the chicken tikka, choley, and saag paneer were all excellent.

excerpts: We had the Daal Masaia, Palak Methi, Lahori Chakkar Choley, Saag Paneer, Aloo Tikki (appetizer)
and, of course, Naan - and, all of it was excellent!
Definitely a very casual setting.
No liquor license here, but you can bring a bottle of wine or a beer if you'd like.
Great eats, trust me!
choley.author: R M.
choley.review: All I can say is, get there earlier than normal dinner hours.  Otherwise, you're going to have to wait outside in a line to get a table.  The vegetarian dishes here are so flavorful and so reasonably priced.  We had the Daal Masaia, Palak Methi, Lahori Chakkar Choley, Saag Paneer, Aloo Tikki (appetizer) and, of course, Naan - and, all of it was excellent!  Definitely a very casual setting.   No liquor license here, but you can bring a bottle of wine or a beer if you'd like.  Great eats, trust me!

excerpts: veggie samosas, lahori chikkan choley  (c.f. channa masala), naan, and soda.
choley.author: John M.
choley.review:
i slipped in silently, before the wave of sucka hipsters. booked down a few blocks the wrong way just to make sure i beat any impending friday night rush.

ordering went just right...
  me: "and could i get soup with that too please?"
  you: "this not american restaurant."
  me: "ok but lots of pakistani restaurants serve soup. soup isn't american.
  you: "let me explain."
  (time passes, pointing, ordering, eating ensue)

later: wholy, holy, full. veggie samosas, lahori chikkan choley  (c.f. channa masala), naan, and soda.

perfectly peaceful, especially spicy, totally heavyweight meal. solid kitchen with prep and cook done visibly on site. A+, great transaction.

excerpts: My favorites are the choley, tandoori fish, bhindi masala, naan (chewy and tangy), malai kofta.
Misses are few but include the Afghani naan and the lamb boti which, while very flavorful, was also a tough cut of meat.
I hardly ever go anywhere else when I'm in SF anymore!
choley.author: L A.
choley.review: Absolutely my favorite Indian/Pakistani restaurant in the bay area.  Every dish is wonderful and fresh tasting, never swimming in a pool of oil.  Best to go when you've got some time since it can take a while. But it's worth it!  My favorites are the choley, tandoori fish, bhindi masala, naan (chewy and tangy), malai kofta.  Misses are few but include the Afghani naan and the lamb boti which, while very flavorful, was also a tough cut of meat.  I hardly ever go anywhere else when I'm in SF anymore!

excerpts: my fave choley and naan in the city.
the chicken korma, daal, and lamb biryani are good.
i didn't care for the tandoori fish everyone loves, it was too dry and fishy for my taste.
it's best to pre-order your lunch, especially if you don't have 2 hours to spare.
choley.author: jane d.
choley.review: my fave choley and naan in the city.  the chicken korma, daal, and lamb biryani are good.  i didn't care for the tandoori fish everyone loves, it was too dry and fishy for my taste.  it's best to pre-order your lunch, especially if you don't have 2 hours to spare.

excerpts: You can't go wrong with any of the matar mushroom, bengan bharta, choley, aloo ghobi, or daal masala.
daal masala.author: James D.
daal masala.review:
Free chai, generous quantities, and insanely low prices. I've brought groups of four hungry young people here and left with all of our heads spinning trying in the new reality where we're all stuffed silly and the bill comes to $45. I've brought friends from France, China, Portugal, Greece, Cameroon, Korea and all over the USA in and everyone left satisfied. Something about the open kitchen and utilitarian decor adds to the experience; it's alive with noise and spice.

The veggie options are also executed so skillfully that no veggie eater will ever feel deprived. You can't go wrong with any of the matar mushroom, bengan bharta, choley, aloo ghobi, or daal masala. The answer to every line in the menu is always Yes.

Pro tip: They allow and it seems even somewhat encourage the BYOB option, so feel free to wander in with a bottle of wine or a sixer from any of the nearby convenience stores.

excerpts: Daal masala $5.5 - yellow lentils cooked in mild sauce.
daal masala.author: Ann L.
daal masala.review:
2nd time to Lahore Karahi w/ my 2010 SF Entertainment coupon.  It's on 612 O'Farrell St (@ Leavensworth).  Easy walk from the Asian Art Museum or Powell St Bart.

We got:

Garlic naan $2.5 - fine.  Comes w/ cilantro & I noticed sesame seeds on top.  Like a thin pizza.

Daal masala $5.5 - yellow lentils cooked in mild sauce.  It was tasty.

Matar paneer $7.5 - green peas cooked w/ cheese in mild tomato sauce.  I didn't notice any cheese, saw some potatoes in there - weird they didn't mentioned potatoes.  Tasted ok.

Tandoori Fish $11.95 - fish marinated w/ zesty herbs  spices.  I think they added lime for us which I don't mind.  It was nice & tender white fish maybe swordfish?  It was pretty good, comes out sizzling w/ onions & cabbage.

mango lassi $2.5 - nice

rice $2 - fine, enough for 2.

Subtotal w/ coupon & Tax (not tip) was $28.95

Hrs: Tu-Su 11a-11p
Credit cards over $15
Halal Meat

excerpts: We ordered butter chicken, daal masala and garlic naan; and it was all outstanding!
daal masala.author: Rick J.
daal masala.review: I'm not exactly sure how anyone couldn't rate this place 5 stars. We ordered butter chicken, daal masala and garlic naan; and it was all outstanding!

excerpts: I usually get the Daal Masala, Chicken Tikka Masala (best I ever had!), and the garlic cheese naan (not on the menu, you have to ask for it.).
The chef/owner Guddu is also very nice.
daal masala.author: Michael C.
daal masala.review:
There is not much I can say here that hasn't been said. Lahore Karahi is the best indian food I have ever had, meanin yes it is the best indian food in the bay area. It is the high bar that all other indian food are judged by. Yes it is in a sketchy neighborhood, so just bring your mace spray or get a cab it's worth it. The food is also very inexpensive and it is BYOB. I know you're asking yourself a question right now, the answer is yes you will smell of Lahore until sunrise.

I usually get the Daal Masala, Chicken Tikka Masala (best I ever had!), and the garlic cheese naan (not on the menu, you have to ask for it.).  The chef/owner Guddu is also very nice.

excerpts: The Daal Masala as well.
Wonderful naan (only $1), cinnamon scented rice.
Thats my usual order.
Occasionally stray but always come back to those 5 things.
Not sure theres even waiter service any longer, seems people order when they walk in and then find a table.
We usually call for pickup and eat at home.
(PS - anyone who would rate a restaurant 1 star without ever eating there should be banned from this site.)
daal masala.author: Josh B.
daal masala.review:
6/9/12 - Uh oh. The main guy is on sabbatical? Food nowhere near as good, made differently, served differently. Yikes, is this the end of Lahore??
-----------------
Best Indian food I've ever had. Total dump but who cares. You may wait awhile but it's so worth it. The Saag Paneer has a depth of flavor I've never experienced anywhere else. The Daal Masala as well. Wonderful naan (only $1), cinnamon scented rice. Thats my usual order. Occasionally stray but always come back to those 5 things. Not sure theres even waiter service any longer, seems people order when they walk in and then find a table. We usually call for pickup and eat at home. (PS - anyone who would rate a restaurant 1 star without ever eating there should be banned from this site.)

excerpts: We ordered the vegetable sabzi, saag paneer, daal masala, a side of rice, and one piece of naan.
Nothing really stood out
and I didn't like the naan
, it was too crispy.
I'll have to try it again before I really decide to dislike it.
daal masala.author: Lucia V.
daal masala.review: I was really excited to go here because of the good reviews I had read and because I could walk here from my apartment instead of having to go to the Richmond, West Portal, or the Mission for some tasty Indian food. The service was attentive (that's why I gave two stars) but I thought the food wasn't very great. We ordered the vegetable pakora which I did like because unlike other places where they consist of just dough you could see and taste all the veggies. We ordered the vegetable sabzi, saag paneer, daal masala, a side of rice, and one piece of naan. Nothing really stood out and I didn't like the naan, it was too crispy. I'll have to try it again before I really decide to dislike it.

excerpts: You can't go wrong with any of the matar mushroom, bengan bharta, choley, aloo ghobi, or daal masala.
matar mushroom.author: James D.
matar mushroom.review:
Free chai, generous quantities, and insanely low prices. I've brought groups of four hungry young people here and left with all of our heads spinning trying in the new reality where we're all stuffed silly and the bill comes to $45. I've brought friends from France, China, Portugal, Greece, Cameroon, Korea and all over the USA in and everyone left satisfied. Something about the open kitchen and utilitarian decor adds to the experience; it's alive with noise and spice.

The veggie options are also executed so skillfully that no veggie eater will ever feel deprived. You can't go wrong with any of the matar mushroom, bengan bharta, choley, aloo ghobi, or daal masala. The answer to every line in the menu is always Yes.

Pro tip: They allow and it seems even somewhat encourage the BYOB option, so feel free to wander in with a bottle of wine or a sixer from any of the nearby convenience stores.

excerpts: The staff treats us very well and I don't even have to order my meal anymore (they just know it): vegetable pakora, matar paneer, naan and rice.
Can't ever go wrong with that!
matar paneer.author: Angel M.
matar paneer.review: It's always great here. The staff treats us very well and I don't even have to order my meal anymore (they just know it): vegetable pakora, matar paneer, naan and rice. Can't ever go wrong with that!

excerpts: Recently had the matar paneer, and it too had an interesting flavor combination.
matar paneer.author: Joanna M.
matar paneer.review:
Lahore's new mantra is somewhat like Pink Floyd's, but instead of, "we don't need no education", it's more like "we don't need no service."

There used to be a waiter. There used to more than one person doing all the cooking. It used to not take over an hour to get your food. 

I just don't care. The food is even better than it was before. The sole chef is back in the kitchen non-stop. Sometimes he doesn't have time to take your money, but you better wait and pay. You'd get a karmic asskicking if you didn't give monetary thanks for this amazing food.

The lamb biryani at Lahore is unrivaled. The lamb is tender, and the biryani cooked to perfection. Recently had the matar paneer, and it too had an interesting flavor combination. The naan are standard, except for the one with the dried fruit, which is a treat and almost a dessert on its own. 

Don't come here for lunch if you don't have a hour or two to spare, and I certainly wouldn't recommend going before a show in the area unless you have ample time. But do come when you slow your roll. You won't find food this perfect, this inspired, and this affordable everyday.

excerpts: The Matar Paneer was also unbelievably good, with the perfect level of creaminess and spice, certainly the kind of dish that will make you use the naan to wipe off every remaining drop.
matar paneer.author: Angel S.
matar paneer.review:
Accept it, Lahore Karahi is smacked right at the middle of the Tenderloin and probably won't be winning "best restaurant design" or "most romantic ambiance" awards in our lifetime.  Heck, if SF had a restaurant grading system similar to So. Cal, I won't put my money on an "A" level grade.

The sooner we get over that, the sooner we can learn to appreciate what Lahore is really about...just awesome Indian food cooked and presented just the way it ought to be...dishes made to order by a man passionate about his craft...dishes characterized by lively spices and flavors.  In a nutshell, this place is great.

Lahore has the best garlic naan I've had.  It had that nice buttery flavor, and it stayed warm and crispy throughout the meal.  The garlic was there but was not obnoxious.  Quite fantastic, really.  The Matar Paneer was also unbelievably good, with the perfect level of creaminess and spice, certainly the kind of dish that will make you use the naan to wipe off every remaining drop.

I was actually at five stars until the chicken vindaloo came.  I'll be brief because the shortcomings are not that big of a deal, but suffice it to say that the chicken vindaloo left more to be desired.  Perhaps Chef Haider inadvertently squeezed one too many lemons, but it crossed the line between tangy and sour, plus it only had three small pieces of chicken.  The side order of bamati rice was also nothing special.

Also, the tap water was a little cloudy, so I suggest opting for canned soda or lassi.  The water had a subtle coconut flavor, and we couldn't figure out if it was meant to be that way or if the flavor was a remnant of a previous drink order.  

Okay, the water thing was very disappointing.  Other than that, the hits were big and the misses were minor.  It's clear that Lahore is a quality establishment, worthy of all the hype of being considered as one of the best Indian restaurants in SF.  There was even a lady from the New York Times snapping pictures of the food from every conceivable angle.  Apparently, she's featuring this place in an upcoming food review.  I will be surely be back and will consider an upgrade.  This time, I will not let the Tandoori Fish get away.

excerpts: Matar paneer
$7.5 - green peas cooked w/ cheese in mild tomato sauce.
I didn't notice any cheese, saw some potatoes in there - weird they didn't mentioned potatoes.
matar paneer.author: Ann L.
matar paneer.review:
2nd time to Lahore Karahi w/ my 2010 SF Entertainment coupon.  It's on 612 O'Farrell St (@ Leavensworth).  Easy walk from the Asian Art Museum or Powell St Bart.

We got:

Garlic naan $2.5 - fine.  Comes w/ cilantro & I noticed sesame seeds on top.  Like a thin pizza.

Daal masala $5.5 - yellow lentils cooked in mild sauce.  It was tasty.

Matar paneer $7.5 - green peas cooked w/ cheese in mild tomato sauce.  I didn't notice any cheese, saw some potatoes in there - weird they didn't mentioned potatoes.  Tasted ok.

Tandoori Fish $11.95 - fish marinated w/ zesty herbs  spices.  I think they added lime for us which I don't mind.  It was nice & tender white fish maybe swordfish?  It was pretty good, comes out sizzling w/ onions & cabbage.

mango lassi $2.5 - nice

rice $2 - fine, enough for 2.

Subtotal w/ coupon & Tax (not tip) was $28.95

Hrs: Tu-Su 11a-11p
Credit cards over $15
Halal Meat

excerpts: The two curries, chicken tikka masala and matar paneer (peas and cheese) were a bit on the creamy, buttery side, but well balanced salt and spice-wise.
matar paneer.author: cecilia y.
matar paneer.review:
When I first heard the name of this restaurant I snickered to myself because I am five.

Had two types of bread - garlic naan and onion kulcha - which were VERY GOOD, definitely freshly made - warm and chewy and generously studded with garlic and onion and cilantro.  The two curries, chicken tikka masala and matar paneer (peas and cheese) were a bit on the creamy, buttery side, but well balanced salt and spice-wise.

Really rich and filling meal, but it hit the Indian comfort food spot. Service was a bit slow, but the waiters were friendly and sweet, so whatever. I don't expect to be waited on hand and foot at a hole in the wall place in the tenderloin.

Bill was under $30 for the two curries and two naans (naan? Can it be plural?).

excerpts: We shared the bengan bhartha, the chicken tikka masala, the onion kulcha, lahori chikkar (wish it was spicier though) and matar paneer.
It was worth the 10 block from happy hour and a good exercise on the way back.
I'll definitely be back here.
