matar paneer.author: Jessica P.
matar paneer.review:
440 something people said it before me. I'll say it again. 
Pure, massive, unadulterated carnage was had here on the night of my good friend's birthday.

5 of us ate for around $60? I think? It's also BYOB, and nobody looks at you funny with a magnum of wine and a six-pack of Bud in the TL. Nobody. If anything, they will want to travel WITH you.

We came early enough to where we had our choice of seating and service was somewhat prompt. This isn't a 5 star restaurant, so we got our own wine glasses, but the water was filled as we sat down. 

The pakoras were tasty, the naan soft, yet crisp, and the curries we had, amazing. We shared the bengan bhartha, the chicken tikka masala, the onion kulcha, lahori chikkar (wish it was spicier though) and matar paneer. It was worth the 10 block from happy hour and a good exercise on the way back. I'll definitely be back here.

excerpts: Hard to find Matar Paneer in the city to begin with,
but it's really good here - uniquely sweeter.
Chicken Vandaloo was like Holi taking place in my mouth - colors and spice jumping all around.
matar paneer.author: Mike C.
matar paneer.review:
"I care about every order - thats the difference". Ya know what - that is the difference. Guddu truly seems to care about all the dishes he serves up. Definitely the best Northern Indian/Punjab food I've had in the city and as good as most I've had in India proper.

The best Aloo Paratha I've ever eaten and their Naan is pretty much perfect. Hard to find Matar Paneer in the city to begin with, but it's really good here - uniquely sweeter. Chicken Vandaloo was like Holi taking place in my mouth - colors and spice jumping all around. Like others have pointed out - the fact that his cooking doesn't have a layer of oil floating at the top (standard most places) makes it even better and the flavor doesn't suffer at all.

I could seriously go on about the Kulfi, or how good the free Chai is, but i think you all get the point. You probably don't need to check this place out - after all one cook, smaller place, you don't feel like waiting for food. lol

excerpts: I ordered the matar paneer.
Just a little bit spicy which I liked.
So good
I couldn't stop eating it.
I wanted to save half for lunch the next day but ended up finishing it instead.
matar paneer.author: Katie K.
matar paneer.review:
This place was absolutely phenomenal! A friend took me and my dad here last night and I already can't wait to go back. They ordered the chicken vindaloo and the tandoori fish. My dad couldn't stop raving about how good the fish was. Maybe a hint of lime right at the end? Being a veggie I ordered the matar paneer. Just a little bit spicy which I liked. So good I couldn't stop eating it. I wanted to save half for lunch the next day but ended up finishing it instead. Plus, the ice cream that came with the bill was just the right way to end the meal.

We did have to wait a little while for the food even though the restaurant was only half full. But you can see them working and there are only two guys so it really wasn't that long. Don't go here if you're in a rush but the food is definitely worth the wait!

And the prices are right too.

excerpts: & I'm still fantasizing about the Aloo Mutter & Chicken Tikka Masala.
The Aloo Mutter is so delicious I found myself licking anything that came near it--fork, fingers,
naan...
oh, I so wanted to pick up the plate & lick it clean!
Lots of onions cooked down into a thick, gingery sauce with starchy potatoes & sweet little peas.
[sigh.]
As for the Chicken Tikka Masala, loved the tangy dense sauce filled with cinnamon tomatoey goodness & tender chunks of chicken.
Ordered everything medium which was more mild-medium but all good.
The naan is a bit oily & chewy
but it makes a great vehicle for carrying sauce to your maw.
Don't pass by the kheer even if you're about to re-enact a scene from "The Meaning of Life.
aloo mutter.author: Cam T.
aloo mutter.review:
[sigh.]  

It's been a week & I'm still fantasizing about the Aloo Mutter & Chicken Tikka Masala.  Oooh, & the thickest, creamiest, most cardamom-y kheer I've ever had.  

This cramped corner in the tenderloin has ostensibly the best homestyle Indian/Pakistani food I've ever had.  The sauces are thick & cooked down, none of that anemic, runny tasteless soup masquerading as sauce here!  The Aloo Mutter is so delicious I found myself licking anything that came near it--fork, fingers, naan...oh, I so wanted to pick up the plate & lick it clean!  Lots of onions cooked down into a thick, gingery sauce with starchy potatoes & sweet little peas.  [sigh.]  As for the Chicken Tikka Masala, loved the tangy dense sauce filled with cinnamon tomatoey goodness & tender chunks of chicken.  Ordered everything medium which was more mild-medium but all good.  The naan is a bit oily & chewy but it makes a great vehicle for carrying sauce to your maw.  Don't pass by the kheer even if you're about to re-enact a scene from "The Meaning of Life."  Get it to go & moan & slurp in the privacy of your room.  

[sigh.]

excerpts: * BINDI MASALA ($7.99) - 4 STARS:
Again, pretty standard okra dish
but I loved that it was chock full of okra rather than fill ingredients like peas, onions and potatoes.
bindi masala.author: Jess C.
bindi masala.review:
I love Indian food and I've been wanting to come to Lahore Karahi for ages now - it's a small ghetto Indian restaurant in the tenderloin. Not super convenient and a little scary to walk to at night. 

When you walk in, pick up a plastic covered menu and sit anywhere. I smashed a large insect crawling on the table with my menu - how multi-functional. You order at the cash register, and I *loved* that you could modify the ingredients (I got ghobi aloo without the potatoes). They have Square and can split checks, woohoo for credit cards. 

All in all, solid Indian food and will be coming back again soon for the tandoori fish! For $40 total before tip, this was enough food for 2 girls with a little leftover for lunch for one the next day.

* TANDOORI FISH ($11.99) - 5 STARS: 
Grilled tilapia (claimed to be strictly grilled, not battered) crispy and salty on the outside, but tender on the inside, served on a sizzling plate. While this could be considered on the expensive side, it included ~5 small filets - not a bad deal!

* CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA ($8.99) - 3 STARS:
I've never been a huge fan of tikka masala because the sauce is too creamy and the chicken is usually too dry. This did not break any stereotypes for me, and the portion of chicken was meager.

* ALOO GHOBI ($7.99) - 4 STARS:
Pretty standard but what makes this dish extra special is that you can order it without the potatoes which to me is such a filler ingredient I don't need to have.

* BINDI MASALA ($7.99) - 4 STARS:
Again, pretty standard okra dish but I loved that it was chock full of okra rather than fill ingredients like peas, onions and potatoes.

excerpts: My go-to order is shahi paneer tikka masala, saag paneer , onion naan and garlic naan.
Their onion naan is to die for.
The staff here are super friendly and the order is quite quick.
So we are in and out of the restaurant
In less than an hour.
It's not a fancy restaurant and the prices are very decent.
Definitely try this place when in San Francisco.
shahi paneer tikka masala.author: Sailaja B.
shahi paneer tikka masala.review:
I wonder what I have been doing all this while without reviewing Lahore Karahi. We have been regulars here for over an year. I love their food and Mango Lassi. They have complimentary chai which is pretty good. My go-to order is shahi paneer tikka masala, saag paneer , onion naan and garlic naan. Their onion naan is to die for. The staff here are super friendly and the order is quite quick. So we are in and out of the restaurant 
In less than an hour. It's not a fancy restaurant and the prices are very decent. Definitely try this place when in San Francisco.

excerpts: Shahi Paneer Tikka Masala was 6 pieces of cheese in a watery thin masala sauce.
It was far better than the Chicken Tikka Masala.
That one had few extra dry cubes of chicken with a sauce that separated into a thick layer of oil and a pinkish residue.
shahi paneer tikka masala.author: Yoram F.
shahi paneer tikka masala.review:
We ordered a delivery through Eat24 for dinner.  The Lamb Samosa were good and the Naan was thick and filling which was great as those were the only two items we enjoyed.  

Shahi Paneer Tikka Masala was 6 pieces of cheese in a watery thin masala sauce.  It was far better than the Chicken Tikka Masala.  That one had few extra dry cubes of chicken with a sauce that separated into a thick layer of oil and a pinkish residue.   It was a very small portion but we did not manage to finish it.   

Lamb Biryani was OK and a Chicken Tandoori was missing from the delivery and was refunded by Eat24.

excerpts: Highly recommend the chana saag and the veggie korma.
Rice isn't included, so if you want it, order it separately.
So good!
chana saag.author: Amy H.
chana saag.review: The best little hole-in-the-wall place in the Tenderloin. We've been ordering takeout from here for years and it's DELICIOUS. Highly recommend the chana saag and the veggie korma. Rice isn't included, so if you want it, order it separately. So good!

excerpts: I ordered Chana saag and when the food came after 35 mins it was Daal saag and the server told me while putting food on the table that they ran out of chana.
chana saag.author: Nitesh A.
chana saag.review:
Food is good but you could end up waiting well over  35 mins for just one dish without being told that it could take that long and it's definitely not worth that much of a wait. Also, this is second time I'm here and they don't have roti and I had to get Naan.

I ordered Chana saag and when the food came after 35 mins it was Daal saag and the server told me while putting food on the table that they ran out of chana. 

Cleanliness and ambiance is below average. 

Won't be coming back again.

excerpts: I ordered the chana saag and it was amazingly flavorful.
chana saag.author: Sona P.
chana saag.review:
Not sure what impact review #904 will have, but I have 2 words: GARLIC NAAN.  I ordered the chana saag and it was amazingly flavorful.  It paired well with the naan and plain rice.  

Minor drawback is that your hair/clothes/jacket will come out smelling like spices, but it's well worth it.

excerpts: My group ordered the Chana Saag, Chicken Tikka Masala, and Tandoori Fish with sides of naan and rice.
I thought the food was really, really good.
The food took a long time to come out (-1 star), but the great flavor and super low prices totally made up for it.
I'll be back for sure.
chana saag.author: Pam S.
chana saag.review: Lahore Karahi really embodies a hidden gem hole-in-the-wall restaurant.  My group ordered the Chana Saag, Chicken Tikka Masala, and Tandoori Fish with sides of naan and rice.  I thought the food was really, really good.  The food took a long time to come out (-1 star), but the great flavor and super low prices totally made up for it.  I'll be back for sure.

excerpts: The simple basmati rice was fluffy and pleasant and paired nicely with all dishes
basmati rice.author: Megan K.
basmati rice.review:
Absolutely everything was delicious except for the raita, it had a little too much carrot not enough cucumber but still good. 

Lamb tikka was slow braised and packed with creamy flavor/

The simple basmati rice was fluffy and pleasant and paired nicely with all dishes

The chicken and cheese naan was like a sauce less inside out pizza, not sure how they did it but it was great and actually tasted like a basic garlic pizza

excerpts: The basmati rice was nothing special and we could have made it at home.
basmati rice.author: D L.
basmati rice.review:
I ordered take-out from this place at the recommendation of an India neighbor, for the sake of variety (vs my usual go-to place, nearby Shalimar). 

First couple of bites were okay but overall wasn't more satisfied than my usual go-to place.

For starters, their orders cost more than my usual place, in one case double the cost for the same portion size (saag chicken). The tandoori chicken was fine but by the end of our meal we found both chicken dishes to be on the dry side.

The basmati rice was nothing special and we could have made it at home. 

Overall the meal was initially tasteful and generally fine, but am going to stick to my other neighborhood Indian place in part based on cost (and some loyalty).

excerpts: Basmati rice were the only dish I deem edible.
basmati rice.author: Ayn K.
basmati rice.review: After reading most the positive ratings, I decide to take a chance and try this place.  Man, do I regret it.  I ordered dinner to go.  The naan was like chewing on leather.  The tandoori chicken was very dry, and charred to a crisp in some areas.  Taste on the uncharred areas were ok.  Ordered the okra which have oil oozing out of the container.  The chicken kebab was dry and tasted mediocre.   Lentil curry was bland.  Fish vindoloo and plain  Basmati rice were the only dish I deem edible.

excerpts: Usually opt for the classic "western" choices: chicken tikka masala, basmati rice, &
basmati rice.author: Katie P.
basmati rice.review:
What a great find in the TL. Delicious authentic Indian. I had been searching high and low for an Indian spot in SF for a couple years and this lands the spot of my número uno. Everything is under $10. BYOB w/ no corkage fee. Hope this lasts(!)

Usually opt for the classic "western" choices: chicken tikka masala, basmati rice, & (lots of) garlic naan. All items are consistently good. 

I've become a regular and I've had the pleasure of enjoying the lamb vindaloo, a cauliflower curry, chicken korma, goat curry, palak paneer, etc. Honestly liked everything except for the veggie korma one time tasted a little funky, but I've ordered it since and been thrilled, so maybe it was just me. This is not the cleanest place... But does it matter? It's cheap, pretty quick and if it's cooked for long periods of time over high heat why does it matter? The employees are super nice too - just don't forget to pay on your way out! I know I almost have like 5 times. Good for smaller groups, lots of 4-top tables and there's a big TV for sports fans always playing Warrior's games.

Lahore, I love you. Thanks for plumping me up and keeping me warm on most Friday nights.

excerpts: I ordered the Lamb Vindaloo and Saag Paneer with an order of garlic naan and basmati rice.
These are staples that are pretty hard to mess up, but this new "master" chef did.
Lamb vindaloo had some heavy oil, filled with a invasive chili powder that gave me almost instant heart burn.
I love spicy foods and its pretty rare to trigger that response inside me, but I think its the liberal use of cooking oil that is causing this reaction.
Not only that,
but there's only three pieces of lamb in my dish.
basmati rice.author: Peter C.
basmati rice.review:
I'm updating my review because of the serious degradation in food quality and value. The new owner is longer present at the restaurant. Looks like the new owner promoted the kitchen aid to the master chef. This is a serious mistake and is the reason why I must downgrade my review to one star (I gave this place three stars after the new owner took over, after he bought the place from the previous owner). 

I ordered the Lamb Vindaloo and Saag Paneer with an order of garlic naan and basmati rice. These are staples that are pretty hard to mess up, but this new "master" chef did. Lamb vindaloo had some heavy oil, filled with a invasive chili powder that gave me almost instant heart burn. I love spicy foods and its pretty rare to trigger that response inside me, but I think its the liberal use of cooking oil that is causing this reaction. Not only that, but there's only three pieces of lamb in my dish. Each lamb piece is the size of my pinky finger. 

The Saag Paneer was bland yet spicy at the same time, an odd combination that left the same bad taste in my mouth as trickle-down economics. Saag Paneer is supposed to have this explosive, orgasmically spiced creamy flavor mixed with the mild subtlety of cheese. This Saag Paneer lacked most of those qualities. 

Some may seriously disagree with my review, but that's because they're not acquainted with a) the Old Lahore or b) good Indian/Pakistani food. This new chef is merely throwing things into a pan without understanding how the ingredients complement each other (so he doesn't know how to control each ingredient). Combined with the expensive dish prices (I paid $22.10 for my above order: yes, that's expensive for this "hole-in-the-wall" place), this place lost any respect I had after the new owner took over.

excerpts:
Basmati rice seasoned with special blend of spices
- Not much here, mainly got it as a mixer for our curries.
Rice is fairly dry, and I didn't taste much of the flavoring.
basmati rice.author: Ziyan C.
basmati rice.review:
I always say you know it's an authentic Indian hole-in-the-wall when there's a VCR TV on the wall playing Bollywood music videos =).

Just know that it's self serve water, utensils, etc. And you have to go up to the counter to order. And it's this ONE guy cooking for and serving everyone!! So even at 10pm on a weeknight our food took a while. 

Oh and it's BYOB! I'll keep that in mind for next time..

LAHORI CHIKKAR CHOLEY - 5.50
Garbanzo beans cooked in a special blend of tomatoes and onions 
- A little too starchy/salty (if I'm being picky).

SHAHl PANEER - 7.50
Lightly fried cheese cooked with nuts in tomato sauce 
- Loved this!
- Slightly sweet yet tangy, with a tiny bit of a spicy kick at the end.
- Paneer was soft and chewy.

LAHORE KARAHI RICE - 2.00
Basmati rice seasoned with special blend of spices
- Not much here, mainly got it as a mixer for our curries. Rice is fairly dry, and I didn't taste much of the flavoring. You get a fairly giant plate though.

ONION KULCHA - 2.50
Naan stuffed with onions and fresh cilantro 
- Wonderful! Loved the onions in the middle.
- A tiny tiny tiny bit burnt on the bottom but I'm being picky.
- Otherwise perfect texture, fluffy but with a good slight crisp.

excerpts: We skipped the naan in favor of a plate of Basmati rice to make sure we sop up all the sauces.
basmati rice.author: Ed U.
basmati rice.review:
My kindred Yelper Liz S. so inspired me with her knowledgeable review of Lahore Karahi on "Check Please! Bay Area" that it finally motivated Jamie W. and me to try it finally after all these years. We were expecting a madhouse of chaos, but we must have come after Katrina came through since all we saw were piles of dirty dishes all around. We honestly didn't know whether we should wait for the young waiter to clean it all up or just pitch in with some Palmolive and a pair of Playtex gloves from the Walgreen's down O'Farrell. 

We decided to wait and hoped the waiter would wipe down the table. Alas, Jamie got a stain on his beloved Threadless T-shirt due to leftover curry sauce on the rim of the table, and only my Diet Coke came. Note we both ordered Diet Cokes and only mine came. Not Jamie's, mine. Things were not off to a promising start. However, once the food started coming, all was forgiven. We started with the $3 basket of Vegetable Pakora, tasty and surprisingly light veggie fritters that looked like they came from South Carolina, not South Pakistan (see photo). But the exotic spices came through with each bite. 

I ordered the $6.50 Butter Chicken, which consisted of Tandoori chicken pieces bathing in a buttery cream sauce (see photo). Very tender with carrots and spices complementing the flavor. Jamie went for the $7 Lamb Korma, which was just as tender and succulent though a bit hazardous to spoon since the bowl was filled to the brim with the spicy sauce (see photo). We skipped the naan in favor of a plate of Basmati rice to make sure we sop up all the sauces. Genuinely delicious but maybe bring a sponge just in case the waiter doesn't have time to be thorough next time. 

FOOD - 4.5 stars...homemade Pakistani dishes done up right and packed with flavor 
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...well... 
SERVICE - 4 stars...the attentive young server was everywhere 
TOTAL - 4 stars...definitely worthy of a return visit...thanks Liz!

excerpts: We ordered a Veggie pakora as an appetizer, a butter chicken and a tandoori chicken for entrees, and garlic naan and basmati rice for sides.
The garlic naan was the best naan I've ever had.
It was so crispy and hot.
You can't fake that freshness.
The entrees were good, but not much better than at other indian restauarnts in the area.
The garlic naan alone was worth the trip.
basmati rice.author: Richard T.
basmati rice.review:
My buddy and I came here for lunch on President's Day.  If I was going to base this review on the service, I would have to give it 2 stars. We ordered a Veggie pakora as an appetizer, a butter chicken and a tandoori chicken for entrees, and garlic naan and basmati rice for sides.  They forgot our pakoras which is when I drafted the review and saved it as 2 stars.  

That's when the food came out.  It was great.  The garlic naan was the best naan I've ever had.  It was so crispy and hot.  You can't fake that freshness.  The entrees were good, but not much better than at other indian restauarnts in the area.  The onion naan was not as good as the garlic one.  

It was a reasonable price for two starving guys.  The garlic naan alone was worth the trip.

excerpts: Saag paneer, delicious; chicken tikka masala, hot and delicious; their basmati rice (I'd rather not repeat that.)
basmati rice.author: Fannie S.
basmati rice.review:
Food = delicious.  Reasonable portions. Water and chai tea is free.   Saag paneer, delicious; chicken tikka masala, hot and delicious; their basmati rice (I'd rather not repeat that.)   Their tandoori fish is very delicious, served on a sizzling plate and plentiful!

Service = self-service.  Order at the counter, sit down and wait at the table (and wait you will, it takes 20+ minutes for the food).  Get your own silverware, plates, water, and good luck finding the napkins.  

When you're done eating, go back to the counter and pay.  If you want to take home leftovers--get your own containers from their station.  

Prices = reasonable.  Pay in cash.  

Overall, I'd be back but I'm not going out of my way to do it again.

excerpts: I really could have done without seeing boxes of okra and basmati rice everywhere.
basmati rice.author: Elena T.
basmati rice.review:
First time visitor - will not be coming back. Here's the good, the bad and the downright ugly...

FOOD:
The food was ok, not great. Veggie samosa average.The food was nicely spiced, but the goat curry my boyfriend had was very runny with a distinct lack of goat, but with an abundance of bones...and vertebrae at that. I had the the eggplant curry, which was decent. Onion kulcha was burnt, and the garlic naan did not look or taste like it was made with fresh ingredients. Also, uhm, don't drink the water, it did not look or taste potable. Felt queasy when we got home, but boyfriend did not seem to experience any ill effects from the food.

Recap - food ok. On a 1-5 scale, maybe a 2.

WAIT:
Be prepared to wait. It's a small hole in the wall, which has limited staff. On top of that, it seems like only one person was cooking, with three others doing other stuff that was not customer-related. It mostly looked like they were standing around on the back-line, but I could be wrong. Plenty of time to observe what else was going on, as the wait was so long.

AMBIANCE and CUSTOMER SERVICE:
Ambiance was lacking, but is not usually a deal breaker for me. Although in this case, I could have done without the rolls of toilet paper on top of their drink fridge or the slew of unbussed tables. 

Speaking of which, don't expect anything from the customer service - seat yourself, come up, order at the kitchen/front-end and expect yourself and your needs to be ignored. We were there for an hour with 2 other tables being occupied, and at no point did ANYONE buss any of the empty tables with dirty plates and food still left on them. We did, however, see a customer buss a table by moving the last guests remains to another table and then sit down. Simply unacceptable. 

Also, while we where there, they were restocking their pantry it seems. I really could have done without seeing boxes of okra and basmati rice everywhere. I have worked extensively in food service, and if you don't have a back door, you NEVER get deliveries during business hours - the whole point is to focus on your customers, and not on everything else. 

CLEANLINESS
This is where this place gets some serious dings. Tablecloths with black dirt stains at the edge where they meet the clear plastic table top, broken soap dispenser with watered down soap in the bathroom, bathroom in general not in any great state of cleanliness, "Order Here" sign with big grease stain, kitchen visibly dirty from where you sit and plastic water glasses with cracks in them. Not good. 

All in all, this will not be somewhere we will re-visit.

excerpts: We tried a little of everything: tandori fish, chicken tikka masala, chicken kebabs, onion naan, and basmati rice.
Our host was really nice, he told us "you ordered enough food" and advised us not to order the pakora we wanted.
The naan and the basmati rice equally tasty.
The only thing that we didn't love was the tandori fish.
basmati rice.author: Betty C.
basmati rice.review:
Teeny tiny place that I would have never found without Yelp!

Was in the mood for some authentic mediterranean food and went to my go to source to see what it would recommend and found this place.

The hubs and I walked here from Union Square (it's not really in the Tenderloin and the walk was pretty safe)

Definitely a family feel to this restaurant that seats no more than 25 people. We came here on a Friday night and the place remained fully occupied the whole time we were there.

We tried a little of everything: tandori fish, chicken tikka masala, chicken kebabs, onion naan, and basmati rice. Our host was really nice, he told us "you ordered enough food" and advised us not to order the pakora we wanted. we liked how he actually told us not to order more!

If you are really hungry you might want to get a little snack before you come here because the food definitely takes its time before it gets to your table. 

Chicken Kebabs and the chicken tikka masala was definitely delicious. We finished every bite. The naan and the basmati rice equally tasty. The only thing that we didn't love was the tandori fish. Maybe next time we will try the tikka masala fish.

Loved the value and the home cooked feel of this place. Would definitely come back or order to go from here.

Note: the bathroom is dirty, make sure you use it before you come here!

excerpts: Not to worry, I settled in and ordered the Lamb Vindaloo, Basmati Rice and Garlic Naan.
After a short wait my food arrived.
It all looked great.
I found the Vindaloo to be some of the best I have eaten, the lamb was lean and tender, the potatoes perfectly cooked and sauce not a bit greasy and perfect sinus clearing heat.
The rice nicely seasoned and cooked perfectly.
The Garlic Naan to put it simply, the best I have ever eaten.
Portions were excellent and would leave most people plenty to take home.
Service was good; however since I was the only person in the place it's hard to judge if there had been a crowd.
Décor is nothing special but clean.
basmati rice.author: Dave J.
basmati rice.review:
On a cold windy San Francisco day Lahore Karahi Pakistani Indian Cuisine is a great place to hunker down for some excellent Indian food. Its faults are few, none of which have anything to do with the food. 

I arrived for lunch just after noon. The place was small and deserted, which generally is not a good sign during prime lunch time.  Not to worry, I settled in and ordered the Lamb Vindaloo, Basmati Rice and Garlic Naan. After a short wait my food arrived. It all looked great. I found the Vindaloo to be some of the best I have eaten, the lamb was lean and tender, the potatoes perfectly cooked and sauce not a bit greasy and perfect sinus clearing heat. The rice nicely seasoned and cooked perfectly. The Garlic Naan to put it simply, the best I have ever eaten. Portions were excellent and would leave most people plenty to take home.  Service was good; however since I was the only person in the place it's hard to judge if there had been a crowd. Décor is nothing special but clean. Entrees in $9 range.

It's a bit tough to find fault with Lahore Karahi, nit picking faults: Not the greatest of neighborhoods, its safe just a bit rundown though not overly so. The serve only canned soft drinks and bottled water.  I saw no beer or wine.  

Lahore Karahi Pakistani Indian Cuisine is hard to beat if in the mood for Indian or a cold windy San Francisco day. As a matter fact a great choice any time.  This really is stellar food.

excerpts: Got the chicken saag, lamb vindaloo, sesame naan (don't recommend this one), and basmati rice.
basmati rice.author: Kenny L.
basmati rice.review:
Closed until December 1st due to family emergency! :( 

Lahore (not "Tha Whore) possibly serves some of the best tasting and cheap Indian/Pakistani food around. 

Tip: Get to the counter. Fill out the check yourself with all the yummies that you want, then fill yourself up some delicious free chai! 

Got the chicken saag, lamb vindaloo, sesame naan (don't recommend this one), and basmati rice. 

This will make you go "Mmmmmm" in the TL.

excerpts: (I forgot the name) + basmati rice.
basmati rice.author: Petri Y.
basmati rice.review:
Came here after the "new owner" conversation so I really didnt know the difference between old and new. Came on a sunday afternoon and found parking right away across the st!

It was 2pm, hardly anyone in there but the place was clean and neat and orderly. There were 2 cooks behind the counter who greeted us upon coming in. From the reviews i expected a REAL hole in the wall bu was surprised to find there were actual tables and chairs and even table side service now.

You still order at the counter but they bring you your food and everything is cooked to order.
The garlic naan came out hot n toasty- just how I like it. I could eat this all day with their curries!

We also had the chicken vindaloo- which is pretty standard and it was really good, + a lamb dish- tasty and the vegetarian dish with the tofu inside (I forgot the name) + basmati rice.

Everything was super delicious, and hot and spicy.

The portions could be bigger for $9 a plate but its perfect for two to get a few dishes to share.

While we were eating, we saw a indian couple pull up in a SL that ran in to get their take out. Hey, if its good for them, then its good for us!

A new indian fav for me in the hood!

excerpts:
$2.50
Basmati Rice...
Somehow this rice stood out all on its own among great dishes...
basmati rice.author: Kevin D.
basmati rice.review:
This place is somewhere that is all about the food. If your in search of ambiance, and great service (if at all) then don't expect to find it at Lahore Karahi. The owner/chef is full of smiles and is eager to engage his customers in friendly conversation. Everything made here is all home made from what I can tell, and the food is outstanding, and very reasonably priced:

Vegetable Samosas... 2 Large, flaky, aromatic boys for $3
Tikka Masala... Not your run of the mill same old shit, traditional and un-real! $ 7.50
Lamb Korma... Succulent and tender pieces of lamb in a zesty curry only $7.50
Saag Paneer... So far the best spinach and cheese ive ever had. $7
Garlic Naan... He was kneading fresh balls of dough as he made ours fresh... $2.50
Basmati Rice... Somehow this rice stood out all on its own among great dishes... $2

Bottom line... $30 for a meal that would probably cost at least double this much at any other of the so called "traditional" indian joints here in the city. Expect to find good food at a great price with a very casual and laid back atmosphere at Lahore.

excerpts: Anyways, the 2 lamb dishes were very tasty, the chicken a little dry, the basmati rice yummy, & the naan a generous portion.
If we go back, but I won't order the tandoori chicken again.
Tip included, I paid $63!
Kinda a lot for a whole in the wall, and don't lean on the walls!!
Saw a roach crawling on it!!
Saw Tycoon Thai right next door...looked much cleaner!
basmati rice.author: susan w.
basmati rice.review: The 3 of us got there around 6:20, so no problem parking right in front & not real busy. We ordered garlic naan, lamb curry, lamb chops, & tandoori chicken. The food took a while, but the guy who took our order did say it would take 15 min, more like 30! But that was ok, they allow you to have free chai tea. Anyways, the 2 lamb dishes were very tasty, the chicken a little dry, the basmati rice yummy, & the naan a generous portion. If we go back, but I won't order the tandoori chicken again. Tip included, I paid $63! Kinda a lot for a whole in the wall, and don't lean on the walls!! Saw a roach crawling on it!! Saw Tycoon Thai right next door...looked much cleaner!

excerpts: And how did they manage to make basmati rice sticky?
Guddu, please open another place anywhere.
I'll come find you!
Yelp, can you re-start Lahore Karahi's reviews to coincide with the change in ownership?
It's too deceiving to people when they think they're getting the same old Lahore.
basmati rice.author: Katie A.
basmati rice.review:
What a difference! I'd been waiting to get back to San Francisco for a Lahore fix for months. Finally got there last night. Slow..... finally my butter chicken arrived with side of rice. No plates for nearly 5 minutes. Then another 3 or 4 minutes for the naan to arrive. Meanwhile, there were only 4 bite-sized pieces of chicken in my dish of butter chicken. And how did they manage to make basmati rice sticky?
Guddu, please open another place anywhere. I'll come find you!
Yelp, can you re-start Lahore Karahi's reviews to coincide with the change in ownership? It's too deceiving to people when they think they're getting the same old Lahore.

excerpts:
$5
- Rice (Basmati rice with spices - very flavorful but not overwhelmingly spicy.
- Lamb Biryani (Saffron flavored Basmati Rice with Lamb) - the lamb was very tender and tasty.
BUT had a lot of cilantro (which I hate) in it...
basmati rice.author: Chie J.
basmati rice.review:
I really like this restaurant.  They are very friendly and food is good.
Dishes I liked;
- Paneer Pakora (Fried Cheese) - I don't  like American cheese stick with tons of melted cheese.  This one had solid white cheese lightly battered and fried - very good $4.50
- Chicken Korma (Orange colored Curry) - Very nice mixtures of spices and flavor.  Big boneless chicken chunks. $5
- Rice (Basmati rice with spices - very flavorful but not overwhelmingly spicy. $1.25
- Lamb Biryani (Saffron flavored Basmati Rice with Lamb) - the lamb was very tender and tasty. BUT had a lot of cilantro (which I hate) in it...
$8.95

Oh, one thing... they have no liquor license and I NEED to have beer when I have Indian food, so I called the restaurant prior to going there and asked ,

Me- Can I bring beer to your restaurant?
A guy at Lahore Karahi (LK) - No beer but wine OK
Me-why no beer why wine OK?
LK-wine OK no underage!
Me-??????? Can I please bring beer
LK-No sorry hahaha

I don't understand why wine is ok and beer is not ok....


Me .

excerpts: I've never been to an Indian restaurant that didn't know how to make nice basmati rice!
Given all the hype, this place was a real disappointment.
basmati rice.author: Mark S.
basmati rice.review: The paneer was okay. Everything was just okay. The environment was terrible. The service was below average. And the rice was skimpy and caked together. I've never been to an Indian restaurant that didn't know how to make nice basmati rice!  Given all the hype, this place was a real disappointment.

excerpts: *Basmati rice that was almost too much to eat.
Also fresh and light, not clumpy and thick.
basmati rice.author: Alfonso L.
basmati rice.review:
What can I say that 719 others haven't said?

*Absolutely delectable chicken vindaloo, so fresh tasting and fragrant with oregano and cumin flavors in the thick sauce. For about $7 you easily get plenty to share with a friend, and you get  decent 50/50 mix of chicken chunks with the potatoes.

*Naan that was fresh and pleasantly thick and sopped up every bit of the sauce. For a buck! Come on! Bring on some more!

*Samosas were not heavy and rock-like, which some places can ruin. These were also perfectly seasoned and I think it matters a lot that they're made just moments before and not hanging around on a counter for the entire afternoon.

*Basmati rice that was almost too much to eat. Also fresh and light, not clumpy and thick. It married well with all of the vindaloo.

*Attentive, kind service by my server. I also liked the fact that it wasn't busy at all and I could hold a conversation in the middle of a Tuesday afternoon. Shalimar is never this quiet.

*Next time I have to try the sizzling chicken tandoori, which arrives on a hot platter with a mountain of cabbage.

excerpts:
Inexpensive
Great for eat-in or take-out
Brown basmati rice

Cons:
Samosas were not freshly fried
basmati rice.author: Maggie R.
basmati rice.review:
Great little spot for Lahori cuisine with great prices and friendly staff!  There are a number of restaurants serving Indian/Pakistani food in the area and this one is the best I've found.

Pros:
The owner is so nice and friendly!
Choley!  Daal!  Nice texture and seasonings.
Inexpensive
Great for eat-in or take-out
Brown basmati rice

Cons:
Samosas were not freshly fried

excerpts: The tandooris coming out of the kitchen were sizzling and savory, and the special Basmati rice had a toasted flavor that I really enjoyed.
basmati rice.author: Liz S.
basmati rice.review:
Reason I love living in San Francisco #2,795,034:  Lahore Karahi.

You can go to any number of highly rated, expensive restaurants in any part of the world and be sure of enjoying a great meal, made-to-order, with unique flavors, sophisticated spices, and a variety of ingredients to entertain your palate.

Only in a city such as ours can you do this for under $15 per person and leave full, satisfied, and wanting to go back.

Lahore Karahi is an excellent find.  I never would have known it was there without Yelp, but after reading the many glowing reviews, it had been in my bookmarks for some time.  By sheer luck and timing, I was able to try it tonight with a group of fine folks to accompany me on my maiden voyage.

Naan, Samosas, Saag Paneer, Chicken Tika Masala - all as colorful, fragrant and delicious as any meal that I have had in India.  The tandooris coming out of the kitchen were sizzling and savory, and the special Basmati rice had a toasted flavor that I really enjoyed.  Dessert was a combination of home-made cardamom ice cream "cubes", and Rice Pudding - a great pairing to finish a great meal.

The Mango Lassi is a great example of the authenticity of the food here.  It tasted of yogurt and mango without the over-sweetened taste that I have come to associate with overly creamy Tika Masalas which I can imagine are made to suit a Western palate.

The atmosphere is no-frills casual, yet inviting.  If I lived in the neighborhood, this would be a regular stop for me.  I just ate there and I am already dreaming of my next visit...now that's something.  What time do they open again?

excerpts: I swear, the innards of these suckers was mushy overcooked basmati rice.
basmati rice.author: Mona N.
basmati rice.review:
Wow. 

With the number of glowing reviews, I triple checked to ensure this is the same place I went to the other day...  Indeed it is and I'm quite baffled.

My experience:
Samosa = ugh
isn't the filling supposed to be potato based? I swear, the innards of these suckers was mushy overcooked basmati rice. Like I literally saw the grains... and it curiously resembled Chinese porridge.... with a hint of curry.

Chicken Vindaloo = ick
This is basically what happened:
looked down in my curry ---- saw a pool of grease ----  first thought was ew!! ---- but since it got great reviews on Yelp, assumed the grease was part of what made the curry so great ---- took my spoon and stirred the grease in with the roux. Yes, I am a sav. (a savage... not in the literal sense)

After I took my first few bites, I realized the grease would not have helped the core taste of the curry =/ The reason I love Vindaloo so much is for the depth. It's spicy, with a liiiiitle tangy kick (from the vinegar) which blends SO beautifully with the spices from the curry... but not this one. Maybe I got a bad batch....? =/

Garlic na'an = yikes
I love love LOVE garlic na'an.. but not theirs. It's WAY too greasy and WAAAAAAY too bready. And not in the yummm it's so soft and melts in my mouth type good bready.

I would normally be angry at bad food, but this time I was sad since I love Indian and the nice man with the mustache gave me a free piece of garlic na'an.  I actually feel bad for giving a bad review....


*note: second star is for the nice man with the mustache
**note 2: i couldn't finish..well i didn't want to eat the second piece of na'an so i wrapped it up and tried giving it to the homeless man on the corner who told me to F*CK OFF. sheesh. i was just trying to help!
MAAAAN I love SF!

excerpts: They fry the basmati rice with peppers.
I can't go back to ordinary basmati rice now.
basmati rice.author: Wakako U.
basmati rice.review:
They fry the basmati rice with peppers.   I can't go back to ordinary basmati rice now.  

Yellow Dal is great.  Saag is great.  The saag here is not so creamy and is sprinkled with cilantro!  Love cilantro.   
And, it's so cheap.  Why do I want to pay double for something inferior.  Well, you do smell after you leave here like smoke.  They don't lose to the Korean bbq fumes.  

Warning: One man show.  Don't go if you are inpatient.  Chef doesn't deserve your attitude either because he cooks alone, prepares everything as orders come in, and very proud of what he serves.  

Update: He hired someone else.  Now he has two helpers....though it is still all at chef's pace.

excerpts: some garlic naan and basmati rice.
The garlic naan is goooood.
A warning though, they take their garlic seriously here, so if you're a faux or a semi garlic lover, I suggest going for the regular.
basmati rice.author: Erika I.
basmati rice.review:
My quest to find the best tikka masala among the Tandoorloin's many Indian places brought me to Lahore. Upon entering, we were promptly seated and given our drinks. We got fish tikka masala, chicken biryani, tandoori chicken leg, some garlic naan and basmati rice. 

The fish tikka masala is beyond superb. Chilean sea bass cooked in a buttery tikka masala sauce that has a great depth of flavors. Unlike most places where the TM sauce is very smooth and creamy (sometimes almost too creamy), Lahore's version is chunkier, has more texture to it (I think there were nuts in the sauce...or some other crunchy thing) and has a lot more flavor. Some people prefer their tikka masala smooth and creamy -- I was one of those -- but I'm now a convert for the chunkier and more flavorful sauce that Lahore makes. 

The chicken biryani is also good. We asked for it spicy though, which is a little too spicy for me. I must admit that I have a low tolerance level for anything hot, so I think I downed two cups of water for the small portion of biryani that I tasted. 

The tandoori chicken is yum-o as well. For $3, you get a tandoori chicken thigh/leg on a big plate of grilled veggies. It's moist, delicious and just has the right amount of kick to it.

The garlic naan is goooood. A warning though, they take their garlic seriously here, so if you're a faux or a semi garlic lover, I suggest going for the regular. The garlic and cilantro is just ooozing from the naan and since I love both, I was in naan heaven after having some. 

Oh and of course, forget about parking when you go here. Try walking instead. I know, it's the Tenderloin, but it's a short little walk from Union Square, the muni, bart, so getting here is no problemo at all. 

Just clutch that purse to your chest, have 911 already dialed on your cellphone -- you just need to press the call button -- bring that pepper spray and you're good to go. Just kidding. Seriously, the Tenderloin gets too much bad rap for what it is. You'll be fine.

excerpts: true in the style of the food, but its good quality (not unhealthy like fast food) and authentic indian taste (there was a cinnamon stick in with my chicken saag dish, the basmati rice had one spicy pepper and some unknown spices (tree bark?) along with it..
There was def.
some interesting stuff going on and the chef is also the cashier, etc.
I'd  expect to wait a long time as there's three people running the entire show.
But its tasty and prices are fantastic.
basmati rice.author: Alex S.
basmati rice.review: Indian restaurant. It's authentic indian. It's listed at "divey" and thats def. true in the style of the food, but its good quality (not unhealthy like fast food) and authentic indian taste (there was a cinnamon stick in with my chicken saag dish, the basmati rice had one spicy pepper and some unknown spices (tree bark?) along with it.. There was def. some interesting stuff going on and the chef is also the cashier, etc. I'd  expect to wait a long time as there's three people running the entire show. But its tasty and prices are fantastic.

excerpts: We ordered the Chkn Kabob, Tandoori Chicken,  CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA, wth an order of Garlic Naan and a side of Basmati Rice.
It was plenty for the two of us.
The staff was friendly and the food was fresh....
YUM!
Definitely would visit again the next time I head out to SF. ^^
basmati rice.author: Kitty L.
basmati rice.review: This place was a gem! My boyfriend and I were desperate for Indian food and I believe this spot was the third one down from the list of Indian restaurants recommended by Yelp users. It was the only one with good reviews open on a Sun. The wait was a little long...but the food was absolutely delicious and worth the wait. We ordered the Chkn Kabob, Tandoori Chicken,  CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA, wth an order of Garlic Naan and a side of Basmati Rice. It was plenty for the two of us.The staff was friendly and the food was fresh....YUM! Definitely would visit again the next time I head out to SF. ^^

excerpts: All these go great with the cinnamon-infused basmati rice which can be eaten as a stand-alone (very tasty, light rice).
basmati rice.author: Matt T.
basmati rice.review:
This place is the essence of the outer-Tenderloin. It's got the kind of authentic, cheap, exotic food for food's sake that restaurants charging twice as much can't even begin to conjure. The decor is bland and you'll have to put in a real wait for the food, but Lahore always delivers on rich, textured tastes which make you wonder if some of the crack from the streets has made it into the food. The vegetarian options here are also the absolute best I've had in SF. 

I second some of these other reviews - my favorite experience of this place is to order for take-away and show up a the end of the 20-25 minute time frame the chef gives you. Take home and enjoy. This place won't make 5 stars for me until it improves the decor enough that I can be comfortable sitting in there with a first date through the made-to-order wait. 

Favorite dishes are: Chicken Korma, Lamb Vindaloo, Lahori Chikkan Choley (garbanzo beans in yellow-tomato curry), and my favorite: the Bengan Bharta - it's a sweet roasted eggplant mixed with other richer spices which is a major mind-blower every time. All these go great with the cinnamon-infused basmati rice which can be eaten as a stand-alone (very tasty, light rice). 

I know this place is a winner because my friends will often visit me in the tenderloin just to get some Lahore Karahi and indulge in my living room. As if I'm not exciting enough on my own!

excerpts: We ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala, Vegetable Samosas, Naan (plain & garlic), Mango Lassis, Basmati rice, and Aloo Gobhi (cauliflower & potato).
So, figuring that there was a long wait for the ppl behind us, we were thinking...
this place must be THAT good.
However, everything was satisfying, but unfortunately wasn't mind blowingly good.
Everything seemed to have sauces with more of a sweet base, even their Basmati rice which had cinnamon sprinkled on it.
A bit odd when you're looking for something w/ lots of spice.
Their Mango Lassis though were just to my liking.
Not loaded w/ sugar, it made a perfect addition to the meal.
basmati rice.author: Tiffany M.
basmati rice.review:
Just when I was on a 4-5 star roll....

I dunno what all the hoopla's really about.

My roommate and I trekked all the way down to the Tenderloin since we were both craving Indian food, however we weren't super blown away by our average dining experience.

We ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala, Vegetable Samosas, Naan (plain & garlic), Mango Lassis, Basmati rice, and Aloo Gobhi (cauliflower & potato). So, figuring that there was a long wait for the ppl behind us, we were thinking... this place must be THAT good. However, everything was satisfying, but unfortunately wasn't mind blowingly good. Everything seemed to have sauces with more of a sweet base, even their Basmati rice which had cinnamon sprinkled on it. A bit odd when you're looking for something w/ lots of spice. Their Mango Lassis though were just to my liking. Not loaded w/ sugar, it made a perfect addition to the meal. I even bypassed the opportunity to pop open a few bottles of wine just to enjoy the Mango Lassi that much more!

Despite the so-so food, our server was pretty entertaining. When my friend asked if the mango drinks were freshly made, he lowered his eyes, stared right at her and gave her "The look". Like: "Are you kidding me?? Of course." Both him and the owner seem like genuinely nice guys that are passionate & proud about their food.

If I'm in the area I'll give it another shot (i didn't get to try their specialty, Tandoori Fish!), but I won't be going out of my way.

excerpts: My buddy had the Basmati rice (we were told by the busser that the rice was organic, kudos...) and Aloo Ghobi (extremely delicious, perfectly prepared)
The Chai was nothing special, but the busser, owner, price point, and food all get 5 stars from this chef....
basmati rice.author: Samuel J.
basmati rice.review: Unbelievably great !   I knew about Lahore, which is in my neighborhood, but i had never eaten there, due to having so many good options in the TL for food. After reading the reviews for this place on Yelp, i decided to check it out and man, what a smart decision that was.. The Naan was out of this world. I also had the Butter Chicken which was so flavorful and had a nice portion of protein in it. My buddy had the Basmati rice (we were told by the busser that the rice was organic, kudos...) and Aloo Ghobi (extremely delicious, perfectly prepared) The Chai was nothing special, but the busser, owner, price point, and food all get 5 stars from this chef....

excerpts: We ordered about 6 different items (chicken tikka masala,tandoori chicken,  saag paneer, naan, cauliflower and potato, basmati rice, etc) so we could try different things and make a good assessment of the place, but that STILL didn't get us very far.
I would def.
pick Shalimar a million times over this place.
And to my friends who recommended this...I'd have to say,
"Really???
Thanks Alot!!
P"
basmati rice.author: danae k.
basmati rice.review: Several of my friends said this was THE best Pakistani food in the city. I tried it and all I have to say is, "Meh". We got there and were seated at a dirty table (I realize we didn't go to this place for the ambiance, but come on) and it took us FOREVER to be served. I think there was only one server, but still, it was frustrating because we were hungry. We finally ordered and received our mediocre food. It was ok, seriously, just OK. And the server had the worst BO ever...sorry, I just had to throw that in there because it really added to my dislike for this place. We ordered about 6 different items (chicken tikka masala,tandoori chicken,  saag paneer, naan, cauliflower and potato, basmati rice, etc) so we could try different things and make a good assessment of the place, but that STILL didn't get us very far. I would def. pick Shalimar a million times over this place. And to my friends who recommended this...I'd have to say, "Really??? Thanks Alot!! =P"

excerpts: We left - sadly - no fish eaten and headed to Pakwan which saved the night with their achar ghost, biryani and beer permissive attitude.
achar.author: Abhi S.
achar.review:
My folks are in town from the old country.  I raved to them about the Tandoori Fish at Lahore Karahi.  It's Amritsari style!  Somehow, the fact that they live in the same state as the actual source of this amazing fish style didn't deter them from buying into my suggestion.  And yes, the wanted to try it in San Francisco.  

 We were beaten to the entrance by four women who then tragically took the one empty table while we waited. I walked to the nearest liquor store to pick up some beer and upon returning we opened one of the Pilsner's.  

Quickly, there were gasps. The waiter pointed and said "Nooooo" as if  I had just stolen his first born child.  I walked over the counter to talk to Gudoo.  I told him I had brought beer from the nearby liquor store several times before and had then drunk it in open view at his fine establishment. I also mentioned how I had specially bought the folks from the old country to try his special fish.  I was confused when he, at first, insisted that I could never have possibly done so but then said he hadn't allowed BYOB for the last three months.  I tried to reason that I didn't know things had changed but he would not let us drink the beer.  We left - sadly - no fish eaten and headed to Pakwan which saved the night with their achar ghost, biryani and beer permissive attitude.   

I still love the fish Gudoo but without a nice beer to wash it down, I must take away a star.  Hope you get that license soon!

excerpts: Thank you!!), fresh homemade achar (pickled veggies), and mango chutney.
achar.author: Preet K.
achar.review:
This place is great, no doubt. If you want a super down-home Indian/Pakistani eating experience though, I would hit up Kabana on University in Berkeley; light green walls, dim fluorescent lights, menz cookin in the kitchen, bollywood bonanza jumpin off on THREE different screens, bathroom that would induce immediate cardiac arrest in one martha stewart and food that will blow your damn mind. Anyways, onto the review at hand:

The Good - Chicken Korma, Chicken Tikka Masala (a lil sweet, but not too much), Garlic Nan, Saag Paneer, Raita (they whipped it up fresh, DAMN! Thank you!!), fresh homemade achar (pickled veggies), and mango chutney.

The Aight - Tandoori Fish; too fishy, not that fresh tasting, but based on all the other rave reviews, maybe just an off night? Mango Lassi; tasted a lot artificial. 

The personal growth/"have a heart you bougi twit!!!" moment - My friends and I were gonna roll out without our leftovers b/c we had flights to catch and the waiter brought us take-out containers anyways and told us to pack it up and give it to someone who needed it - "it's not right to throw this food away in here when someone is hungry out there." word!!

Service was fast on a Sunday night and we were seated immediately.

excerpts: I tried lamb vindaloo, chicken achar and samosa.
you can get better samosa at  restaurant near 3rd and folsom.
I would say lamb vindaloo and chicken achar are just ok, nothing special about them.
achar.author: Abhishek G.
achar.review:
Being an INDIAN, I know for real how the real taste of indian/pakistani food should be, and I have had better pakistani food in SF.

I tried lamb vindaloo, chicken achar and samosa. you can get better samosa at  restaurant near 3rd and folsom. I would say lamb vindaloo and chicken achar are just ok, nothing special about them.

excerpts: their achar is  killer; my wife and I have to get our own portions to avoid snarling like dogs over it.
achar.author: digiTED ..
achar.review:
Guddhu (johnny carson) and Malik (ed mcmahon) keep it very real.

The best curry in San Francisco. Period. In the heart of the TandooriLoin, no less. Guddhu makes everything to order, and is it ever worth the wait in this 70's BollyWood flickering O'Farrell Street haven for lovers of 1000 spice meals.

Their biryanis are a mountain of flavor, and the Bengan Bharta (creamy eggplant+carmelized onion) is simply the tastiest curry I've ever had. It rivals what I've had traveling around the Arabian Gulf. Oh yeah: their achar is  killer; my wife and I have to get our own portions to avoid snarling like dogs over it.

Malik brings everything to the table with swift efficiency and if you're lucky, you'll get a culinary history lesson on what you've ordered.

If you have any room left, there will be no disappointment in their rice pudding (an ode to cinnamon and pistachio) or their ice cream (a saffron+cardamum dream).

I love it and am compelled to evangelize, though I've only been there about 40 times over the last couple of years...

excerpts: The pista kulfi and mango ice cream were ok.
Our bill came out to be around $48 was average given what we ordered.
kulfi.author: robert s.
kulfi.review: Good quality South Asian place.  A bit hole in wall.  The chicken tandoori was excellent. The saag paneer was good.  The garlic bread was good too.  The pista kulfi and mango ice cream were ok.  Our bill came out to be around $48 was average given what we ordered.

excerpts: I had sampled their desserts of Kheer (rice pudding) and Kulfi (frozen spiced reduced milk) and they were on the spot !!!
kulfi.author: Umesh T.
kulfi.review:
Lahore Kadahi is a little different from the other Indian restaurants that I have frequented so far. Not different as in the selection of food but in the flavors. 

I particularly remember the "Daal Makhani" which was very authentic in it's flavor but could use a little more softening of the lentils/grams/sprouts (Daal encompasses lentils , sprouts , and chickpeas that it's hard for me to say which is which). If it was a little more "mushy" (for lack of a better word, and I agree it does not sound very enticing either --- ok, let's go with "creamy") I would surely rate it as the best in the area. 

The other dish they execute way better than *ANY* other Indian restaurant (save Viks in Berkeley) is the Alu Paratha, or the potato stuffed Indian bread. It's still not quite a paratha but more naan/tandoori-roti, yet they executed it really well that I had no cause for complaints. I'd highly recommend it. 

I made the mistake of ordering the kebab platter (I think it had beef, chicken, and possibly, lamb kebabs) and realised it was way too much meat for one person. It is best shared by three people. 

The other dishes were standard fare and pretty good but did not jump forth like the aforementioned so I don't remember. 

Just be forewarned: your clothes will smell like dinner once you're done due the combination of ventilation that could do better, and the nature of spicy steaming-hot food from the subcontinent. 

I had sampled their desserts of Kheer (rice pudding) and Kulfi (frozen spiced reduced milk) and they were on the spot !!!

I'd recommend it.

excerpts: My parents grew up eating kulfi, malai, and all that  cardiac health goodness and often crave those sweets.
They roll the kulfi right in front of you.
In fact, they make everything in front of you since the kitchen is out in the open.
My parents enjoyed the kulfi and malai a lot, but I didn't eat it
so I can't say much about it.
kulfi.author: Colleen W.
kulfi.review:
When it comes down to Indian, I can get really picky. Maybe it's just because my dad cooked curry for us almost every DAMN DAY of my childhood. I learned to grow accustomed to all the spices of the middle east and south asia. Curry, masala, cumin, saffron, cardamom, you name it. My parents grew up eating kulfi, malai, and all that  cardiac health goodness and often crave those sweets.  I've never been a fan of those milky desserts, but I comply.

We were actually aiming to dine at the Sultan down the street, but we found out that they still hadn't opened. I wonder if they're even going to reopen... ever. Anyways, a quick search on Yelp led us down to Lahore Karahi. Off we went.

Our waiter was very nice. He treated everybody with respect and went out of his way many times just to answer my talkative dad's many questions.

We ordered a garlic naan, two regular naans, tandoori fish, chicken biriyani, and a mixed grill platter. We all absolutely LOVED everything. The biriyani was amazing. The rice was perfectly cooked, not too soft, not too hard. The fresh aroma of the cilantro blended nicely with the turmeric and other spices. The food definitely wasn't overspiced the way most "Indian" restaurants do it. Everything was light with the right amounth of flavor. The garlic naan was delicious as well. The tandoori fish was very tender and fragrant, but it was a bit too sour for my liking. I think I tasted a bit of tamarind as well. It would've been nice in a salad. The lamb and chicken on the mixed grill platter were very tender and juicy. Oh, don't forget to eat the vegetables that accompany the meat! The onions and lettuce that came along with the meat tasted soooo sweet and  good. Mmmm....

They roll the kulfi right in front of you. In fact, they make everything in front of you since the kitchen is out in the open. My parents enjoyed the kulfi and malai a lot, but I didn't eat it so I can't say much about it. They said it was heavenly.

We are definitely coming back. This is definitely one of the better Indian places in the city. 

Good stuff!

excerpts: Got back to the hotel and found we'd been given veg samosa instead of veg pakora, and kulfi instead of gulab jamun.
But the kulfi was melted by the time we figured out it wasn't gulab jamun (it was heavily wrapped in tin foil) and it was just ok.
Decent food, careless service.
kulfi.author: Susanna W.
kulfi.review: Pretty good food, but we ordered takeout, and they got half our order wrong. Unfortunately I didn't check too closely when we picked it up, just peeked in the bag and checked their receipt to make sure it was mine. Got back to the hotel and found we'd been given veg samosa instead of veg pakora, and kulfi instead of gulab jamun. Luckily the samosas were pretty good, as was the aloo saag, and the chicken tikka was great. But the kulfi was melted by the time we figured out it wasn't gulab jamun (it was heavily wrapped in tin foil) and it was just ok. Decent food, careless service.

excerpts: The Kulfi (mango) is so good.
You are required to save room for it.
The Saag Paneer isn't he best, but the Palak Methi Aloo is to die for.
kulfi.author: Jennifer P.
kulfi.review:
Absolutely Fabulous. Darling.

The Tandoori Fish is so mouth watering just thinking about it now makes me want to go there! The Kulfi (mango) is so good. You are required to save room for it. The Saag Paneer isn't he best, but the Palak Methi Aloo is to die for. My roommate loves the Butter Chicken. I love everything.

menu: http://www.lahorekarahisf.com/pakistani-menu.htm

excerpts: You MUST get the palak paneer & garlic naan, and the mango kulfi if you want dessert.
The place is a hole in the wall in an unspectacular neighborhood of San Francisco, but is full of well to-do professionals.
By hole in the wall
I mean I didn't drink out of the water glass.
I think it's only the chef & one waiter, so service can be kind of slow but they are very kind.
- Garlic Naan
: Lahore puts garlic and a spice rub on their garlic naan, and it's amazing.
I saw the cook pat out the dough & stick it into the tandoor fresh to order, so the bread came out super soft and warm.
- Mango Kulfi:
Wow.
They make their own homemade, which is amazing on it's own, and it turns out really really good.
The flavors of mango, cream, saffron, pistachio, and a little cardamom come together beautifully.
Chai Tea:
How nice that it's complimentary.
It was a nice end to our meal, and way better than Starbucks.
kulfi.author: Jasmine A.
kulfi.review:
Lahore Karahi serves some amazing Indian food with great value. By choosing your dishes carefully you can have a five star meal here. You MUST get the palak paneer & garlic naan, and the mango kulfi if you want dessert. The place is a hole in the wall in an unspectacular neighborhood of San Francisco, but is full of well to-do professionals. By hole in the wall I mean I didn't drink out of the water glass. I think it's only the chef & one waiter, so service can be kind of slow but they are very kind. We had: 

- Palak Paneer: Probably the best palak paneer I've ever had, my mom has ever had, and my dad has ever had (and between the three of us, that is a lot of palak paneer). This stuff is so fresh! The flavor is amazing, the texture is perfect, and it's a must (order two). 
- Lahore Channa: Their channa masala was ok. It's not the best I've ever had, but rounded out our meal nicely. It's a bit more sweet than most, darker in color, and more 'soft' (the garbanzo beans are more mushed up). Also I thought it tasted a little peanut buttery, which is not a flavor commonly found in channas. 
- Aloo Gobhi: This is a dish I would recommend avoiding. It's really oily & doesn't have very good flavor. 
- Garlic Naan: Lahore puts garlic and a spice rub on their garlic naan, and it's amazing. I saw the cook pat out the dough & stick it into the tandoor fresh to order, so the bread came out super soft and warm. 
- Mango Kulfi: Wow. They make their own homemade, which is amazing on it's own, and it turns out really really good. The flavors of mango, cream, saffron, pistachio, and a little cardamom come together beautifully. 
- Chai Tea: How nice that it's complimentary. It was a nice end to our meal, and way better than Starbucks.

excerpts:
Desserts like the kheer and kulfi are tasty.

Only downsides are the wait (my friends and I have taken to calling in about 30 minutes before we arrive and we still wait 20  minutes for our entrees when we get there) and fact that the excellent and complimentary masala tea thermos is usually empty...

I wish i could come here more - but my friends all prefer shalimar - amateurs!

Thanks to yelp for helping me discover this place by the way. 
I never would have ventured off Jones street without you all...
kulfi.author: D S.
kulfi.review:
My absolute favorite indian/pakistani restaurant in the city.  If they had south indian food (and mexican pizzas) i would probably move in.  The tandoori fish is wonderful and the lamb korma is probably my favorite indian dish anywhere (and i'm indian).

Desserts like the kheer and kulfi are tasty.

Only downsides are the wait (my friends and I have taken to calling in about 30 minutes before we arrive and we still wait 20  minutes for our entrees when we get there) and fact that the excellent and complimentary masala tea thermos is usually empty...

I wish i could come here more - but my friends all prefer shalimar - amateurs!

Thanks to yelp for helping me discover this place by the way. I never would have ventured off Jones street without you all...

excerpts: The food remains amazing, I like the garlic naan and kulfi.
The owner Guddu has a huge smile that brings me joy.
Sometimes my friends and I wave to him as we're walking by just to see his grin.
kulfi.author: Meghan F.
kulfi.review:
I'm really sad that the waiter with terrible service (who was totally amusing as a result) is no longer here. The food remains amazing, I like the garlic naan and kulfi. The owner Guddu has a huge smile that brings me joy. Sometimes my friends and I wave to him as we're walking by just to see his grin. Yes, we're weird.

Best recent experience here: sitting at a table next to the window, a man on the street peered in, stared, smiled and waved at my friend & I for like five minutes. I love the TL its delightful character.

excerpts: I could seriously go on about the Kulfi, or how good the free Chai is, but i think you all get the point.
You probably don't need to check this place out - after all one cook, smaller place, you don't feel like waiting for food.
lol
kulfi.author: Mike C.
kulfi.review:
"I care about every order - thats the difference". Ya know what - that is the difference. Guddu truly seems to care about all the dishes he serves up. Definitely the best Northern Indian/Punjab food I've had in the city and as good as most I've had in India proper.

The best Aloo Paratha I've ever eaten and their Naan is pretty much perfect. Hard to find Matar Paneer in the city to begin with, but it's really good here - uniquely sweeter. Chicken Vandaloo was like Holi taking place in my mouth - colors and spice jumping all around. Like others have pointed out - the fact that his cooking doesn't have a layer of oil floating at the top (standard most places) makes it even better and the flavor doesn't suffer at all.

I could seriously go on about the Kulfi, or how good the free Chai is, but i think you all get the point. You probably don't need to check this place out - after all one cook, smaller place, you don't feel like waiting for food. lol

excerpts: He even served our table with complimentary kulfi for dessert!!
kulfi.author: Amy B.
kulfi.review:
This place is probably one of THE best Indian places I've been to in this city. The neighborhood totally sucks beyond belief, but every mouthful is worth the smelly people you have to walk over and through to get here! 

I had the lamb biryani, which, suprisingly, did not come with raita but was still really good. I also ate some my friend's bengan bhartha, which was sooooo good I took her leftovers! The naan, in addition to everything else, is made fresh in front of you and is super delish. Next time I really want to try the Afghani Naan (w/ raisins, nuts, cheese & cherries). The owner says this is more of a dessert naan.

Speaking of the owner, he was as friendly and helpful with suggestions as he could be! We had constant refills on our drinks, even with a little bit of a lunch rush. He even served our table with complimentary kulfi for dessert!! That was also really yummy.

Despite the location, it's close enough to work that I will most definitely be going back as often as possible!

excerpts: They once let us try their kulfi (ice-cream), and now, we always go there for dessert every time after we have dinner in the area
...  chai with kheer and kulfi...  mmmmmm....
kulfi.author: Haywood H.
kulfi.review:
My favourite, favourite, repeat FAVOURITE Pakistani/Indian food joint in the city.

Specialties include their tandoori, and seafood (though I wasn't personally too impressed with it - I guess it's hard to impress a Cantonese food connoisseur with seafood dishes from other cuisines), their impressive selection of curries (vegetarian or lamb, avoid the chicken).

The ingredients are fresh, every dish is served piping hot (spicy, too!) and cooked personally by the chef - you can tell he puts his real heart into his cooking.  We get on great with Guddu and Abdul too - guess we kinda stick out because I've never seen any other East Asians eat in their restaurant....

They once let us try their kulfi (ice-cream), and now, we always go there for dessert every time after we have dinner in the area...  chai with kheer and kulfi...  mmmmmm....

excerpts: He offered us some homemade kulfi, but we could not eat anymore, and so told him we would gladly take some home.
Later on that night we delved into the kulfi which was creamy and superb.
And yesterday we broke out the leftovers and bread pudding.
kulfi.author: Brian J.
kulfi.review:
The place was 80% full at around 8:30pm when we showed up. The chef-owner greeted us warmly and pointed us at an open table.

We ordered Lamb Vinadloo, Bengan Bhartha, Tandoori Fish, 1 naan, and 1 onion kulcha. When asked if we want spicy, we said yes, please make it as spicy as you like it.

It took a while for us to get our food, but having read reports we were prepared for this. Thankfully we weren't starving so we didn't mind waiting. I picked up some beer from a nearby market and we drank and waited patiently.

The lamb arrived and was unlike any vindaloo we had ever had before. It was shreddy and succulent, immersed in a complex and delicious sauce. It was definitely spicy, but was also excellently spiced bursting with a plethora of flavors.

The bengan bhartha was extremely spicy. Easily the spiciest dish of the night. We were both happy and impressed with the level of spicyness. It's nice to find a place that's not afraid to bring the real heat. The dish was also quite tender and tastey.

The naan was great. Hot out of the tandoor in all its crispy-chewy glory. The onion kulcha tasted good, too, but I thought it could have used a bit more onion.

Lastly, the tandoori fish arrived sizzling on a cast iron hot plate. Flakey and tender chunks of sea bass with nicely charred edges, on a bed of lightly fried onions and lettuce. One bite and I knew it was the best Pakistani-Indian flavored fish dish I had ever laid my mouth upon. "Wow", was all I could muster up. The fish was fully flavored with lots of cilantro, coriander seeds, and fresh chilies.

Totally sated I walked up to the front and thanked the chef for all the glorious and amazing food. I asked him what kind of fish was in the tandoori dish and he told me it was seabass. He mentioned that other chefs use salmon or catfish, but that he finds sea bass to be superior in taste. As I'm not a fan of cooked salmon, I totally agreed.

He offered us some homemade kulfi, but we could not eat anymore, and so told him we would gladly take some home. We wrapped up our leftovers and after paying, the chef gave us an additional complimentary dessert of bread pudding.

Later on that night we delved into the kulfi which was creamy and superb. And yesterday we broke out the leftovers and bread pudding. The leftovers were just as good the next day, and the bread pudding was another winner.

It's really amazing how much good cheap food there is to be found in the Tenderloin. If anyone has any other dish recommendations for Lahore, I'd be glad to hear them.

excerpts: kulfi cubes?
kulfi.author: Tara A.
kulfi.review:
best. funking. indian. food.... ever!!!!

i always always always get something with spinach, and i'm not even really into cooked spinach!
the garlic naan is delicious! 
kulfi cubes? yes please!
special non-menu dishes, funk yeah!

don't expect a quick meal though, when there's only one chef [the owner] things take a little longer, but it's so worth it! 

eat here. and often!

excerpts: Try his mango kulfi - its mind blowing.
His tea though his very milky but very tasty and flavorful.
Malik the only server though slow due to health
reasons-
Guddu has taken kind interest in helping Malik to good health.
I am impressed by his good character and his kindness to help a person from his country- Pakistan.
Lot said-
the ambience is ok but its definitely much cleaner than Shalimar and Pakwaan.
If you seen the rest room of Shalimar and Pakwaan you will simply faint.
LK's rest room is much cleaner.
kulfi.author: Ashish M.
kulfi.review:
Lahore Karahi simply rocks. Guddu bhai is simply great in dishing out tasty Indian fares. I would highly recommend Tandoori Fish and Chicken Koorma for spice fans. Try asking Guddu for the specials- he is a genius and he tries making new items not found in his regular menu.
The service is slow but its worth the wait because he cooks everyhting fresh and is not stale stuff that likes of Shalimar, Pakwaan, Nan and Curry and chutney dish out. Guddu is generous with his proportions too.  To top it all he is the freindliest guy and I have been to his place more than 50 times and I have never seen him anything but jolly.  He always has customer satisfaction as his motto and I have seen him bend his back even if it means customers eats on house. He has always been generous with the free delicious treats at end. Try his mango kulfi - its mind blowing. His tea though his very milky but very tasty and flavorful.
Malik the only server though slow due to health reasons- Guddu has taken kind interest in helping Malik to good health. I am impressed by his good character and his kindness to help a person from his country- Pakistan. Lot said- the ambience is ok but its definitely much cleaner than Shalimar and Pakwaan. If you seen the rest room of Shalimar and Pakwaan you will simply faint. LK's rest room is much cleaner.

excerpts: that free kulfi he gave us at the end was magnificient, my cholay rich and filling, the best green sauce i have ever tasted.
He topped it off with free kulfi and bannana pudding, homeade.
my friend uttered: "this man is the god of the moment.
Doesn't everybody want to be, just once?
this guys hits that every couple of minutes.
Are you still eating at shalimar?
kulfi.author: Christopher J.
kulfi.review:
yes, yes. this place dominates the quadrant. that free kulfi he gave us at the end was magnificient, my cholay rich and filling, the best green sauce i have ever tasted. my friend said that the lamb saag ascended above, all these marvelous things. dont pass this one up, give naan and curry, shalimar, chutney and pakwan a rest for five minutes ( listen, i know, its hard. they are go to places that have all the accolades and what have you. just do it, once.)
DUDE, UPDATE: 3/22/06 OH MY GOODNESS! Gudoo really went overboard tonight. I brought in three friends, and both chef and patron went to town. Starting with samosas, we went traveled a saag ghost, dal makhani (extra spicy, no cream. MAMA SEITA), dal masala, beingan bhartha, 4 garlic naan, an order of rice, a salad and my friends shared the patented fish tandoori, which they said reached emperor status. He topped it off with free kulfi and bannana pudding, homeade. my friend uttered: "this man is the god of the moment." Doesn't everybody want to be, just once? this guys hits that every couple of minutes. Are you still eating at shalimar?

excerpts: o-u-s!  and top it of, the mango lassi and mango kulfi excellent.
this was all in a lunch w/ 16 people today!
needless to say the productive at work after lunch was non-existent...
kulfi.author: Swarup B.
kulfi.review: quite possibly the 2nd best indian meal i have had in SF.  my co-workers adore this place and know the owner very well and always get the hookup.  so on to the food.  wasn't too big a fan of any of the chicken dishes asides from the chicken saag which was on point.  the tandoori fish has to be one of the best indian dishes i've ever had in the city!  not a big fan of goat so i won't rate that.  the lamb vindaloo was incredible as was the bengan bertha was so d-e-l-i-c-i-o-u-s!  and top it of, the mango lassi and mango kulfi excellent.  this was all in a lunch w/ 16 people today!  needless to say the productive at work after lunch was non-existent...

excerpts: I ate the chicken saag and enjoyed it very much.
chicken saag.author: Abbas B.
chicken saag.review: Great food and nice place to hang out.  We were a group of 4 people.  We all loved our food.  I ate the chicken saag and enjoyed it very much.
