excerpts: Got takeout from this place the other day, ordered the butter chicken and plain naan.
There was nothing objectionable about the food but, and maybe this is because I was just in India, it was nothing to write home about.
The naan was denser than I would have expected/liked, and the butter chicken was more or less indistinguishable from a tikka masala.
butter chicken.author: Max A.
butter chicken.review:
Got takeout from this place the other day, ordered the butter chicken and plain naan. There was nothing objectionable about the food but, and maybe this is because I was just in India, it was nothing to write home about. The naan was denser than I would have expected/liked, and the butter chicken was more or less indistinguishable from a tikka masala. The sauce could also have done with being thicker.

Perfectly reasonable for the price, but if this is the best Punjabi food in SF then that's pretty disappointing.

excerpts: We ordered fish tikki masala, beef shesh kebap, butter chicken, saag paneer and an eggplant dish (+naan, rice and raita)
I was thoroughly disppointed by the butter chicken.
This dish used to be one of my favorites and unfortunately the taste has totally changed.
The chicken is nowhere as succulent as before and the sauce was very average.
butter chicken.author: Nhan N.
butter chicken.review:
Went there last night for the first time after the ownership change.  While the food was still tasty, it wasn't as exceptional as before.  I think the prices went up too.  

We ordered fish tikki masala, beef shesh kebap, butter chicken, saag paneer and an eggplant dish (+naan, rice and raita)

The fish tikki masala was pretty tasty.  The saag paneer was pretty standard.  The eggplant dish was good but I remember it being more flavorful before.  

I was thoroughly disppointed by the butter chicken.  This dish used to be one of my favorites and unfortunately the taste has totally changed.  The chicken is nowhere as succulent as before and the sauce was very average.  Boo!

The shesh kepab has also lost some of its tastiness from before and in addition to that was on the dry side. 

I will probably come back at some point but definitely not as often as before.

excerpts: they have awesome butter chicken and tandoori chicken.
butter chicken.author: Sarah S.
butter chicken.review: I can't believe I haven't written a review for Lahore! This place is my bf's FAVORITE restaurant. He is a super picky eater but when we started dating I wanted to take him to one of my favorite cuisines as he had never had Indian before. I had been here once before and thought it was pretty good so brought him and the best friend here. HE FELL IN LOVE and we come here at least once a month every month. Now he has his coworker and his gf hooked and we just love it. The people here know us now obviously and are always very friendly. Its BYOB and they have awesome butter chicken and tandoori chicken. Oh and garlic naan! There's more but just GO! Its great and super reasonable! You won't be disappointed!

excerpts: Crusty rice from the bottom of the pot, watery butter chicken, and the world's saltiest tandoori fish left a bad taste in my mouth.
To their credit, the naan was quite good and the butter chicken was spiced nicely, but overall I'd say there are many better options in the city.
butter chicken.author: L D.
butter chicken.review:
Crusty rice from the bottom of the pot, watery butter chicken, and the world's saltiest tandoori fish left a bad taste in my mouth.

Even the mint chutney was extraordinarily salty; I'm not sure how you can get that wrong. I'm talking an order of magnitude here in terms of the salt level -- I made the mistake of putting the chutney on the fish and it literally tasted like I was eating a spoonful of salt. The saag aloo, surprisingly, was bland with no salt at all. Either that or our taste buds were fried from the fish and chutney salt bomb.

To their credit, the naan was quite good and the butter chicken was spiced nicely, but overall I'd say there are many better options in the city.

excerpts: The butter chicken is so crisp on the outside and so most and tender on the inside.

Same ratings
for the tandoori chicken.
Same ratings for the  Afghani Nan, Chicken Boti .I am not a chi tea drinker, but theirs was made from scratch
and I had 4 glasses of it.
Despite the health warnings, I found the restrooms xclean.
Ice water was ice cold.
Despite the negatives I will come back here again and again,
butter chicken.author: Peter F.
butter chicken.review:
First off: The food is so darn good. Any place that has indians double parked 4 deep waiting for take out ( they are so smart, more on that later) all night long is a clue that the food must be good. Walked in and sat down and someone brought over menus... 10/12 minutes I am trying to get his attention to order and he is at the counter not paying any attention to the dining room. I call out to him that I want to order and he points up to the ceiling to sign ( because of the lighting no one in our group of 4 could read) that says to order at the counter. We ordered at 8pm and got our food at 9pm!!!!! NO SERVICE OF ANY KIND. You get your own silvereware, beverage, napkins, etc. But the food: OUTSTANDING!!!! It has to be the best Indian food in SF. The Garlic nann is outstanding. The butter chicken is so crisp on the outside and so most and tender on the inside. Same ratings
for the tandoori chicken. Same ratings for the  Afghani Nan, Chicken Boti .I am not a chi tea drinker, but theirs was made from scratch and I had 4 glasses of it. Despite the health warnings, I found the restrooms xclean. Ice water was ice cold.  Despite the negatives I will come back here again and again,

excerpts: My roommate loves the Butter Chicken.
butter chicken.author: Jennifer P.
butter chicken.review:
Absolutely Fabulous. Darling.

The Tandoori Fish is so mouth watering just thinking about it now makes me want to go there! The Kulfi (mango) is so good. You are required to save room for it. The Saag Paneer isn't he best, but the Palak Methi Aloo is to die for. My roommate loves the Butter Chicken. I love everything.

menu: http://www.lahorekarahisf.com/pakistani-menu.htm

excerpts: Get the lamb vindaloo, garlic naan, and butter chicken!
I like that they spent 20+ minutes to make my food - signs of quality and freshness!
butter chicken.author: Gina H.
butter chicken.review: The best Indian restaurant in SF so far. Get the lamb vindaloo, garlic naan, and butter chicken! I like that they spent 20+ minutes to make my food - signs of quality and freshness!

excerpts: Anyway, I had ordered the Afghani naan, rice, butter chicken and a mango lassi.
I was quite disappointed by everything that I had ordered.
The Afghani naan was definitely not what I expected.
It tasted like a Christmas fruit cake packed inside a different tasting kind of naan.
The butter chicken was different.
butter chicken.author: Nicole B.
butter chicken.review:
I really wanted to like this place. I was in San Fran for the weekend & was on the hunt for some great food. I saw Lahore Karahi, and thought wow this place has great reviews we should give it a try. I met up with my best friend during the labor day weekend. It took us awhile to get to this place. I really wanted to impress her, and show her some great eats in San Fran. We got there pretty late, so there wasn't a line. We were seated promptly. It was pretty packed in there. I am pretty sure I only saw 2-3 people that worked in there. 

Anyway, I had ordered the Afghani naan, rice, butter chicken and a mango lassi. I was quite disappointed by everything that I had ordered.
The Afghani naan was definitely not what I expected. It tasted like a Christmas fruit cake packed inside a different tasting kind of naan. The butter chicken was different. Creamy but in a different way, as in not a good way. 

Our meat dishes appeared and we had to wait at least 5 minutes for the rice and the naan. My friend had ordered the tandoori fish, and it was pretty spicy despite asking for it mild. 

To top it off there was a cockroach on the wall. Maybe it was the day.
Restaurants have off days right? Anyway, not sure if I'd go back. I honestly though Naan 'n Curry was 10 times better. Maybe it's what I ordered.

excerpts: The butter chicken was in a sauce that looked radio-active and was watery.
butter chicken.author: Lishdish R.
butter chicken.review:
Lahore Karahi has fallen off the tallest pedestal.  I have fought the urge to go back to LK since Guddu sold the restaurant some time ago.  Tonight I gave in and really wish I hadn't.  Aside from ordering for delivery using delivery.com and then getting a call that they didnt have  anyone working that could deliver (umm, I literally live across the street) I found the food no short of disgusting.  No joke.  How can food be bland and spicy at the same time?  Well, it can be.  The butter chicken was in a sauce that looked radio-active and was watery.  The roti was the consistency of naan, the rice was plain white rice with a few slivers of carrot and minimal spice, and the Aloo ghobi had no sauce whatsoever.  And there was no one in the restaurant at 7:30 pm.  There ya go.  What a huge (yet predictable) disappointment.  

The major silver lining to this dark cloud is that thanks to yelp reviewers I now see that Guddu is back in SF and has a new restaurant!  While it's apparently in the middle of nowhere (outer sunset) I will be able to enjoy Guddu's artistry again very soon.  I can almost smell the love of his cooking already!

Steer clear of LK.

excerpts:
We had ordered 
Chicken tikka - very dry and no flavor, breast pieces used
Butter chicken - tasted like it was missing something, very bland, breast pieces used
Chicken biryani - good and flavorful, breast pieces used
Reg. 
naan - it was reg naan
All of my dishes were made with chicken breast.....was not mentioned on the menu!
I asked for it to be spicy...
it was not!
We were really hoping for good paki food 
but instead we got crappy food. 
Service was ok. 
It was my first and last time going there. 
I wish I had read some of recent reviews before going there....
butter chicken.author: Monty D.
butter chicken.review:
I went with my family last night and we were very much disappointed. 
We had ordered 
Chicken tikka - very dry and no flavor, breast pieces used
Butter chicken - tasted like it was missing something, very bland, breast pieces used
Chicken biryani - good and flavorful, breast pieces used
Reg. naan - it was reg naan
All of my dishes were made with chicken breast.....was not mentioned on the menu!
I asked for it to be spicy...it was not!
We were really hoping for good paki food but instead we got crappy food. 
Service was ok. 
It was my first and last time going there. 
I wish I had read some of recent reviews before going there....

excerpts: I've enjoyed all of the curries I've tried here, from the aloo gobhi to the chicken tikka masala (my personal favorite from here) and the butter chicken curry.
The naan is also top notch -- soft, fluffy and crispy all at the same time -- very delicious and addicting, you'd better make sure you get at least two orders.
The uber popular tandoori fish is pretty tasty as well.
butter chicken.author: Erich D.
butter chicken.review:
In an area of San Francisco chock-full of Indian and Pakistani restaurants, this one stands out as my favorite thus far.

I've enjoyed all of the curries I've tried here, from the aloo gobhi to the chicken tikka masala (my personal favorite from here) and the butter chicken curry.  The naan is also top notch -- soft, fluffy and crispy all at the same time -- very delicious and addicting, you'd better make sure you get at least two orders.  The uber popular tandoori fish is pretty tasty as well.

excerpts: I ordered the Tandoori Fish and the Butter Chicken.
Both were insanely delicious.
The tandoori fish was a little too spicy for me, but I will have you know that I am the biggest wuss in the world when it comes to spice.
It was so freakin good
I kept eating it though.
Maybe next time I will ask if they can make it
non spicy.
I wanted to swim in the butter chicken sauce.
It was that good.
Of course, we ordered naan.
Mmm, dip your naan in the sauce.
butter chicken.author: Liz M.
butter chicken.review:
Have you ever eaten so much you find it hard to breathe? Okay, maybe you aren't an over eating ogre like me, but yeah, I occasionally do that. Lahore Karahi made me do that. I seriously COULDN'T stop eating. It was sooooo good. After checking out suggestions for good Indian food on Yelp, Lahore seemed like a highly rated place. I made a date with a friend and walked over here with a 6 pack of Stella. Lahore is not in pretty neighborhood but don't let that deter you.

Everything we ate was amazing. I chose two of the items I ordered because there were so many rave reviews on them. I ordered the Tandoori Fish and the Butter Chicken. Both were insanely delicious. The tandoori fish was a little too spicy for me, but I will have you know that I am the biggest wuss in the world when it comes to spice. It was so freakin good I kept eating it though. Maybe next time I will ask if they can make it non spicy. I wanted to swim in the butter chicken sauce. It was that good. Of course, we ordered naan. Mmm, dip your naan in the sauce. Ignore anyone who glares at you for eating with your hands. 

The waiter recommended the saag paneer, which is spinach and cheese. It was off the hook. Seriously. Dip your naan in that too. Oh man, that's what made it hard for me to breathe. I couldn't stop dipping my naan in it. We also got a side of rice. Yeah, that sounds like a lot of food for two girls, but whatever. Lane Bryant here I come.

So, the food is 5 stars fer sher. And at SUCH a great price too!!!! AND you can bring your own beer, wine, etc. Now, I know most everyone else who reviewed this placed warned of a wait for a seat and a wait for your food. It was a Thursday night at about 7:30 and the place was pretty crowded. Honestly, maybe I got really lucky, but I didn't wait at all for a seat and I felt that our food came out at an appropriate pace.  And the waiter was very nice. So 5 stars from me.

excerpts: Lamb vindaloo, butter chicken, veggie biryani, 2 orders of naan, 2 orders of mango lassi, free chai tea and water...all of this for three people for $30!
It would have been more
had they not forgotten the fish tandoori -- we were disappointed in that since it's their specialty and neither of us had tried it before.
Oh well...
butter chicken.author: Elaine W.
butter chicken.review:
Spicy flavor-packed deliciousness! Lamb vindaloo, butter chicken, veggie biryani, 2 orders of naan, 2 orders of mango lassi, free chai tea and water...all of this for three people for $30! It would have been more had they not forgotten the fish tandoori -- we were disappointed in that since it's their specialty and neither of us had tried it before. Oh well...we'll save it for the next visit! 

We experienced all the negatives that previous reviewers had mentioned from the long wait(s), slow service, and being dive bombed by roaches - literally...apart from the ones crawling on the walls, one dropped down on my arm from above. The food truly trumps every fault you can find with this place. It's so good. And the long wait/slow service can be forgiven considering that the owner is the sole cook, and he was only being helped by one waiter. The two of them were simultaneously taking orders (both dining in and take out), and prepping stuff in the kitchen. Amazing, really.

Bring the people here whose company you most enjoy cause you'll have plenty of talk time!

excerpts: You can't go wrong with the curries such as the Chicken Tiki Masala or Butter Chicken.
butter chicken.author: Suzi K.
butter chicken.review:
This place is the definition of a hole in the wall which is my fav type of restaurant.  Screw foo-foo, forget about chains, it's all about these under the radar joints.

Lahore Karahi is in the TL so a few things that probably suck is finding parking on the street, walking passed a dirty ass hooker, crackheads talking to themselves, and the hustlers at the corner of the block.  All good though.  You mind your own business, they do the same.  It's all about respect in this neighborhood.

The restaurant has changed in that they don't have a waiter taking your order.  You get to be host/waiter/waitress by writing down your order and finding the next available table.  Oh yeah, it's BYOB so don't forget to bring your favorite drink.  They have pitchers of water for those that need it.

I gotta give it up to the owner/chef.  He's a one man cooking machine!  Homeboy is the only one cooking food so you can't be mad if you're waiting a while for the food.  The other two assistants are there to cook anything in the tandoori oven and serve up the customers.

I have never been disappointed with the food here.  Everything is awesome and each dish has a unique taste with different levels of flavor which stimulate all the taste buds in your mouth.  The prawn vindaloo is delicious.  Prawns are juicy, the sauce is a bit sour and has some aromatics in there that just makes it the perfect combination of flavors.  You can't go wrong with the curries such as the Chicken Tiki Masala or Butter Chicken.  All of them are a bit thick, slightly sweet and the curry is perfect for dipping the Garlic Naans.

I'll stop yapping now.  You get the point.  This place is good...

excerpts: I have no clue why we order chicken tikka and butter chicken when they're both the same thing.
He warned us but we went for it anyways.
Oh wells.
The chicken tikka masal had pistachios on top!
First time seeing it served like that
but it went well with the dish.
Tasted delish.
Both the chicken tikka masala and buttered chicken tasted the same
but we still enjoyed it.
I like how it's not like Naan and Curry's sauce.
Naan and Curry seem to have more heavy cream in their recipe and this one is more Authentic like.
butter chicken.author: Juliane N.
butter chicken.review:
A new place to grab some great Indian food! My brother wanted to try this place out so him, my sis and I came here for lunch today before I had to go work. The place was really empty and the gate was still half closed so we thought it was not open. But then the owner came out and it was open. He apparently was the only person working so the food took a little longer then expected.

Free Chai! YAY! Love it. So we ordered our usual food. 
Vegetable Pakora : Mixed vegetable fritters
Chicken tikka masala : Chicken in mild & creamy tomato curry sauce
Buttered chicken : Chicken cooked in creamy tomato sauce
chicken biryani : Saffron basmatic rice w/ chicken & nuts
Plain nann, garlic nann, potato nann

Wayy too much food for 3. I have no clue why we order chicken tikka and butter chicken when they're both the same thing. He warned us but we went for it anyways. Oh wells. The chicken tikka masal had pistachios on top! First time seeing it served like that but it went well with the dish. Tasted delish. Both the chicken tikka masala and buttered chicken tasted the same but we still enjoyed it. I like how it's not like Naan and Curry's sauce. Naan and Curry seem to have more heavy cream in their recipe and this one is more Authentic like. The vegetable pakora was good too but wayy oily... It is fried so yea. Chicken biryani? Good but spicy. I'm becoming so slow with food terms, I didn't even know med is spicier then mild. How lame. So I had to drink tons of water after each bite of food!

The owner/chef was super nice and made sure everything was good and that we enjoyed it. He even offered dessert but I was too full to actually except it..

Cheap good authenic Indian food is the best!!! Oh, and I didn't smell like spices coming out of the restaurant!

excerpts: Butter Chicken - Tandoori chicken pieces cooked in a creamy/buttery sauce was just perfect to scoop up with the garlic naan.
butter chicken.author: Casey L.
butter chicken.review:
BYOB and write up your own order! My friend decided on Lahore and Karahi and opted to even bring the wine and beer. Grabbing a free table, hellos were exchanged and foolishly we didn't realize we had to write out own menu, good thing we caught it early on and the person with the most legible handwriting wrote up the menu. 

Wait time for our food was longer than expected, but we did read how there is one chef making everyone's order so good conversation mixed with alcohol helped pass the time.

Samosas were a good bite but wasn't as crispy as I wanted them to be.

Garlic naan took awhile to get to our table, and luckily we got them in two separate intervals so the second batch was fresh and warm...yumm...

Butter Chicken - Tandoori chicken pieces cooked in a creamy/buttery sauce was just perfect to scoop up with the garlic naan. 

Lamb looked and smelled amazing, but I couldn't have any at the time, but the general comment was it had a nice strong spicy kick to it. 

Eggplant was a nice change of pace to our palates, by means of nonmeat, but it was good and spicy as well, so I found myself sucking down on water by the end of the night. 

Parking can be atrocious in the Tenderloin if you opt to find a free meter after hours. Décor was nothing special, and felt cramp most times, but for the food we received and the experience we got, I'll gladly suffer anytime. Food overall had a nice spicy taste so be warned for those who don't like spicy food, but the flavor hits the mark and that's all I could ever hope for. Make sure to grab a free table or prepare to wait, write your own menu, and grab a bottle to help lighten the mood. Yes, prepare to wait if you don't see a free table, and the food will come out relatively slow if there is a packed house.

excerpts:
butter chicken - rich, nutty, creamy
Lahore rice - nice blend of flavored rice cooked on karahi
Tandoori roti - simple all purpose traditional unleavened bread 
garlic naan - crispy, smokey and garlicky simplicity
butter chicken.author: Daidan J.
butter chicken.review:
Truly one of the best Lahori cuisine in Sf!  Coming from San Jose This has been our 4th times eating here. And in every visit, we always come to appreciate this place as having the authenticity of Pakistani cuisine.

Seekh kebab - succulent and complex mixed of spices 
fish tandoori - chef's specialty - spicy, flavorful, and scrumptious (quite rare in pakistani cuisine)
lamb biryani - complex, nutty, tangy, smokey 
butter chicken - rich, nutty, creamy
Lahore rice - nice blend of flavored rice cooked on karahi
Tandoori roti - simple all purpose traditional unleavened bread 
garlic naan - crispy, smokey and garlicky simplicity 

This place is a treasure!

excerpts: We ended up getting a couple of the spicy lamb plates with an amazing butter chicken.
butter chicken.author: M C.
butter chicken.review:
Felt kind of stupid when my friends and I came here. We ordered a few plates and only a couple naan thinking that our plates included rice. We later had to just add more and more stuff as we ate. 

We didn't order that Tandori fish as everyone said we should. We ended up getting a couple of the spicy lamb plates with an amazing butter chicken. The foods are real authentic and prices are not bad, no wonder there are lines on Fridays and Saturdays.

For those who bought the Restaurant.com coupon, don't. They don't accept them. Waste of your time and your money.

excerpts: I usually order the butter chicken EXTRA spicy--it's absolutely amazing.
You can see the whole kernels of spices wading in the thick, rich curry sauce and the chicken is always plump, juicy, and abundant.
Pair that with the pillowy, naan that's usually basted with oil and can you say SENSORY overload?
lol.
butter chicken.author: Katie O.
butter chicken.review:
I would give this place more stars if I could---it's THAT good.

Everything I have ever ordered here has been solid, and more. And when i mean more, I mean the dishes are aggressive with spice. Definitely not for those with zero tolerance for heat, and definitely for those who want a little challenge with their tastebuds. 

I usually order the butter chicken EXTRA spicy--it's absolutely amazing. You can see the whole kernels of spices wading in the thick, rich curry sauce and the chicken is always plump, juicy, and abundant. Pair that with the pillowy, naan that's usually basted with oil and can you say SENSORY overload? lol. No, really, another religious experience is had to be found here. 

Other no-nonsense delicious picks: tandoori lamb chops, saag paneer, tikka masala, matter paneer....but I'm sure everything will be a hit. I heard through the grapevine that the fish tandoori is to die for.

And I love the food so much that even gripes in servicing cant lower my rating. Check this: I made the trip over to Lahore last night at about 9:30. Apparently the usual server (who is a spritely and awesome young man, i might add) couldn't make it and they had a server/busser working on the fly. it took about 45 minutes to get my order in and another 30 to get my food. I might have calculated the whole ordeal to be a 2 hour meal, but I definitely utilized the BYOB rule and enjoyed the waiting game nonetheless.

GO HERE NOW!

excerpts: I love the chicken tikka masala, butter chicken, karahi chicken, and I'm trying to branch out through the rest of the menu.
I try to go every week.
butter chicken.author: David M.
butter chicken.review:
Lahore Karahi is so delicious that I can't stop going back. I guess only the owner ever cooks, it's always the same guy, and he must be some kind of genius. I love the chicken tikka masala, butter chicken, karahi chicken, and I'm trying to branch out through the rest of the menu. I try to go every week. It's the best Indian food I've ever had, and it seems to somehow be cheaper than the other Indian restaurants in this neighborhood (there are at least 4 more around here).

This is a very casual environment, partially self-service. You read the menu at the counter and write your order on one of the pads yourself, then get water and seat yourself. You do not help yourself to beer etc. from the fridge; order that from the waiter, who will eventually stop by your table. When you are done eating your incredibly delicious food, you pay at the counter on the way out. Often it's crowded. It may take a while to get your food if it's busy, and you'll likely have to wait a bit at the counter to pay after eating, but it's well worth it.

excerpts:
* Butter Chicken
* Palak Paneer
* Dal Makhani
Butter chicken is really what CTM aspires to be.
The latter being merely its pale, poultry shadow.
LK's version was a little heavy on the fenugreek and onion for my tastes and lacked a hint of sweetness, but was decent.
butter chicken.author: Tak N.
butter chicken.review:
TL;DR: For now, as long as Zulfiqar is manning the stove, my go to place for solid Punjabi food in the Bay Area. 


It might seem that I have universal contempt for veg fare, though that's not really true. The fact of the matter is that, more often than not, veg dishes at many Punjabi joints here well... suck. That the non-veg dishes never quite measure up to my expectations either--well I figure, better to just cut my losses. 

What's missing exactly? Some kind of weltanschauung--a totality of experience--encompassing the things we love and the art to express it? 

Difficult to imagine in a status obsessed, foodie-ville like SF, but opulence and cost have nothing to do with it. Some of my most memorable meals in the subcontinent were for less than a dollar... 

For example, in Old Delhi, Ustad Moinuddin's seekh kababs, made at a tiny street-side charcoal brazier on a congested side lane down from the old haveli of the great Urdu poet Ghalib, are probably the best I've ever had (or will have). While President Clinton can shell out 25 USD for a plate at Bukhara, I'm happy to know that a cycle-rickshaw-wallah can get equal (or better) ones at 4 Rs (10 cents) a pop (this was after a 1 Rs price hike a few years ago). Ustad Moinuddin-ji could easily charge double or triple, but I think that it's not just about money, but about art, along with an obstinate refusal to compromise. 

***



THE REVIEW:

For now Lahore Karahi will be my go to place for Punjabi khanna. This is the first place I've been to in the Bay Area where both the non-veg and veg items were done equally well. The food is honest, straightforward--reflecting something of the cook's dedication and skill. Definitely not trying to ingratiate itself to local tastes. While inexpensive, (like nita m. said below) if you choose well, you can get some amazing food.

The dishes:

* Butter Chicken
* Palak Paneer
* Dal Makhani
* Aloo Paratha
* Garlic Naan
* Tandoori Roti
* Raita

My measure of a good Punjabi restaurant is how well they make their dal and tandoori rotis. While a North Indian staple, for most restaurants here they are an afterthought. What's more telling about a place is not the specials, but their approach to the basics. To me a flavorless dal, or mediocre tandoori roti reflects a basic lack of skill or respect for the food.  And a shame really, because a good plate of dal accompanied by chawal (rice) or a simple tandoori roti, is to me, basic comfort food.

Zulfiqar, the chef and owner in the kitchen, has a touch. The food actually has personality. The tandoori roti was decent, not some kind of dry cracker, and the dal? Flavorful.

Butter chicken is really what CTM aspires to be. The latter being merely its pale, poultry shadow. LK's version was a little heavy on the fenugreek and onion for my tastes and lacked a hint of sweetness, but was decent. But what really stood out was the palak paneer. 

Compared to other places the flavors were distinct and had depth. The paneer was fried to a golden color with brown edges, giving it a nice firm texture. 

As far as the bread goes, it's okay. The aloo paratha was decent, better than the one that I had at Kabana. The sprinkle of sesame seeds on the garlic naan is a nice touch. Though personally, I prefer my naan to be a little thicker, more pillowy (can't say I've found good naan outside of Old Delhi, honestly). And the fact that they can make tandoori roti already speaks volumes. 

The only thing that kind of sucked was the raita. While they may make their own yogurt at the restaurant--which is great--the raita was way too tart, with a bit of a 'carbonated' taste from being overly fermented.

Sans hipsters, all-in-all, LK could be a neighborhood joint in Delhi or Lahore. Like some other reviewers said, if you're missing real Punjabi food, I recommend this place.


Service was friendly, prompt and good. 

Cleanliness-wise: during our wait for a table, a roach did double duty as a greeter on a stack of Urdu newspapers by the entrance. Though I'm not really all that squeamish and don't care that much, it does detract from the overall experience.

excerpts:
+ butter chicken
+ chicken tikka masala
+ chicken vandaloo
+ lamb biryani
+ aloo bengan
+ saag paneer
+ naan

+ onion kulcha
+
butter chicken.author: Jenny L.
butter chicken.review:
Definite benefits in having a big group come to Lahore.  That way, you get to try everything, and you're not the only one walking down the street smelling like Indian food.

+ byob.  $10 for a 6-pack at the corner liquor store.  makes all the difference.
+ butter chicken
+ chicken tikka masala
+ chicken vandaloo
+ lamb biryani
+ aloo bengan
+ saag paneer
+ naan
+ onion kulcha
+ garlic naan

Maybe I'm not too good at distinguishing all the different flavors of the dishes, but after 10 minutes, everything started to taste the same to me.

At least I walked out full and happy.

excerpts: ..... finally my butter chicken arrived with side of rice.
No plates for nearly 5 minutes.
Then another 3 or 4 minutes for the naan to arrive.
Meanwhile, there were only 4 bite-sized pieces of chicken in my dish of butter chicken.
butter chicken.author: Katie A.
butter chicken.review:
What a difference! I'd been waiting to get back to San Francisco for a Lahore fix for months. Finally got there last night. Slow..... finally my butter chicken arrived with side of rice. No plates for nearly 5 minutes. Then another 3 or 4 minutes for the naan to arrive. Meanwhile, there were only 4 bite-sized pieces of chicken in my dish of butter chicken. And how did they manage to make basmati rice sticky?
Guddu, please open another place anywhere. I'll come find you!
Yelp, can you re-start Lahore Karahi's reviews to coincide with the change in ownership? It's too deceiving to people when they think they're getting the same old Lahore.

excerpts: so I thought just as long as I had butter chicken or chicken tikka masala, I'd be good.
The butter chicken was easily the favorite dish amongst our table.
butter chicken.author: Jane N.
butter chicken.review:
I had been craving Indian food so I thought just as long as I had butter chicken or chicken tikka masala, I'd be good.  Sadly I left this place feeling unsatisfied and a bit annoyed.

It's a small place and always crowded, so be prepared to wait.  You're not going to just be waiting for a seat, but you're going to be waiting for your food also.  My friends and I came super hungry and it took an hour to get our food.  Not sure if it's because they didn't put in our order, but the fact that they only have one cook (and one guy making the naan) probably didn't help matters.  They also got our order wrong but since we were so hungry, we didn't care and just took whatever dish they made us.

The butter chicken was easily the favorite dish amongst our table.  Garlic Naan was pretty tasty.  I think the other two dishes we got were vegetarian, the Galoo Gobhi (cauliflower and potato) and Aloo Bengan (eggplant and potato).  They were both bleh to me.  Might be because I'm a carnivore and I'm not happy unless there's meat.  Everything was spicy too.  Two of my friends were dying.

In the end, I wasn't very impressed.  There's better Indian food around where you don't have to wait around forever for everything.

excerpts: Seekh Kabob, Butter Chicken, Saag Paneer, Lahore Rice, and Naan.
The portions are hefty compared to other places like Naan and Curry and the amount of actual meat you get is worth what you're paying for.
butter chicken.author: Char C. B.
butter chicken.review:
This is my go-to spot to eat dinner prior to grabbing drinks at B&B.  I know, I know...where's the relation?  The only relation I have to tell you is purely how close they are to each other and how great the food is at Lahore.

The staple dishes I like to order are:  Seekh Kabob, Butter Chicken, Saag Paneer, Lahore Rice, and Naan.  The portions are hefty compared to other places like Naan and Curry and the amount of actual meat you get is worth what you're paying for.  There's normally only one server, so you can't really complain about service being slow unless if you want another $ dollar added to the menu prices.  

During my last visit, I saw the owner being visited by a mother and her 2 year old son dropping off a X-mas present to Zulfiqar.  It was really nice to see how the restaurant is supported by its neighbors and the interaction of the chef to his patrons.  Go here if you want well made Pakistani/Indian food and decent prices to follow on your bill.  If I'm on a tight budget, you'll find me here!

excerpts: I ordered the butter chicken while my friend ordered the chicken tikka masala.
She warned me about the spice levels being higher than the usual.
So I opted to get mine in a medium instead of hot like she did.
My medium butter chicken was SOOO spicy.
It was delicious
but I must admit
, I think I would've enjoyed my meal better with less heat.
I was literally sweating I had to take my sweater off.
One of the waiters saw & gave us complimentary yogurt to help soften the dish.
It really did help!
The same waiter also brought us complimentary dessert because he felt bad that I couldn't fully eat my chicken.
butter chicken.author: Kris B.
butter chicken.review:
By far one of THE BEST customer service I have ever had. Not to mention the food quality was equally amazing. Lahore Karahi is one of the smallest restaurants I've ever been in. It fits about 5 or 6 tables that fit 2-4 people each. But it didn't feel cramped. There was complimentary tea by the utensils. It made it homey & I felt welcomed.

I ordered the butter chicken while my friend ordered the chicken tikka masala. She warned me about the spice levels being higher than the usual. So I opted to get mine in a medium instead of hot like she did. My medium butter chicken was SOOO spicy. It was delicious but I must admit, I think I would've enjoyed my meal better with less heat. I was literally sweating I had to take my sweater off. One of the waiters saw & gave us complimentary yogurt to help soften the dish. It really did help! The same waiter also brought us complimentary dessert because he felt bad that I couldn't fully eat my chicken. He really didn't have to because I more than enjoyed my meal!

With the service being more than helpful, the dishes extremely flavorful, the complimentary treats tasty & delightful, I can honestly say that Lahore Karahi is one of my favorite restaurants!

excerpts: The only thing I did not like was their butter chicken.
butter chicken.author: Mrinalini K.
butter chicken.review:
This is my favorite Indian restaurant!
Their tandoori fish, ghosht curry, chicken tikka masala, karahi chicken, veg biriyani and karahi paneer is awesome! Customer service is fabulous too! The only thing I did not like was their butter chicken.

excerpts: We started the meal with some poppers and then shared the butter chicken and saag paneer with garlic and regular naan.
I really liked the saag paneer -- the cheese was tofu-like and remarkably light, nothing gooey about it.
The butter chicken was a tad spicy, but with some water, a non-spice eater, such as myself, was able to down it.
butter chicken.author: Jun H.
butter chicken.review:
I came here following the recommendation of a friend, and after I read about all the food-poisoning incidents at Chutney (I really didn't want to risk it while I was on vacation).  The restaurant is in the "'loin" so careful!  We had to park on the street and walk for a few blocks -- a little pre-dinner exercise.

We started the meal with some poppers and then shared the butter chicken and saag paneer with garlic and regular naan.   I really liked the saag paneer -- the cheese was tofu-like and remarkably light, nothing gooey about it.  The butter chicken was a tad spicy, but with some water, a non-spice eater, such as myself, was able to down it.  

This restaurant could have easily gotten 5 stars from me but the sluggish service holds me back.  And it wasn't only the food that was slow to arrive, the check required two reminders and eventually, we went up to pay.

excerpts: I ordered the butter chicken but shared a whole host of other dishes with a group of people including a few varieties of naan and tandoori chicken.
butter chicken.author: Jasmine S.
butter chicken.review:
Um. The food was OK. I ordered the butter chicken but shared a whole host of other dishes with a group of people including a few varieties of naan and tandoori chicken. The problem I had with this place was the wait time.

This place is tiny but I think what makes it worse is that there are only two guys working the place, at least there were when I ate there for lunch on a weekday. My party ended up waiting 45 minutes for a table and then about 20 more for our dishes. One of us didn't get his tandoori until we had finished all of the other dishes. 

I'm not familiar with Indian food, having only eaten it a handful of times in my life, but it was actually OK, especially the curries. But the tandoori chicken was only OK, probably because it was rushed (I think the super-busy cook forgot until the last minute). 

And yes, the bathroom is scary. Didn't see any roaches but was freaked by the dirty broom stowed away alongside the toilet and the lack of proper toilet paper (they only had a large roll of crisp, paper towels). 

If it weren't for the fact that someone else paid for my meal, I wouldn't have gone here. And what's more, I went here as part of a 'welcome' meal-- couldn't have been less welcoming but I knew it wasn't the fault or the intention of the people who took me out. I wanted Indian food but wasn't familiar with the restaurants in the area so I left it up to someone else to pick (and yes, I realize Pakistani food is different but I specifically said I wanted to eat Indian and this is where I was brought-- I'm not implying that Pakistani and Indian are "all the same"). Throughout the wait and after the meal (wait time+actual eating=2 and a half hours!), a few people in my group asked me if I had chosen the place. I only realized later that they must have been like 'Who was the nut who chose this place???'  If I had to pay, I would not go back here.

excerpts: Also there butter chicken is creamy thick and delicious !
They have good portion and the price is pretty affordable !
Although they do get busy ALOt of the times but if you comd in at 5 it's actully a good time !!
OVERALL
I think this place is good for family && they also give FREE CHAI(tea) & you can bring your OWN Alcohol bottle !
SO IF YOUR IN THE TENDERLOIN AND STARVING THIS IS THE PLACE TO GO !!!
butter chicken.author: Mahnoor S.
butter chicken.review: For me they have the best naan in the city (: && the new owners are super nice and friendly the women who cooks is super friendly & hardworking ! Plus they have remodeled the place it looks better now than it did before well my favorite dish they Serve is Fish Biriyani it really tasty and this biriyani has the most flavor in it !! Also there butter chicken is creamy thick and delicious ! They have good portion and the price is pretty affordable ! Although they do get busy ALOt of the times but if you comd in at 5 it's actully a good time !! OVERALL I think this place is good for family && they also give FREE CHAI(tea) & you can bring your OWN Alcohol bottle ! SO IF YOUR IN THE TENDERLOIN AND STARVING THIS IS THE PLACE TO GO !!!

excerpts: The garlic naan, tandoori fish and butter chicken were standouts.
At the time, the restaurant was BYOB
(I'm not sure if it still is) and that was/is an awesome perk!
The new owners were very kind and accommodating!
The new LK is a great idea for groups or even a party of 1.
The bill for our group was very reasonable and the food was outright delicious!
Thank-you, Mr. & Mrs. Sheikh!
Also, don't miss the rice pudding; amazing!
butter chicken.author: Baroness M.
butter chicken.review: I had the pleasure of eating here with a group of co-workers and friends. Our entire group loved all the dishes we ordered. The garlic naan, tandoori fish and butter chicken were standouts. At the time, the restaurant was BYOB (I'm not sure if it still is) and that was/is an awesome perk! The new owners were very kind and accommodating! The new LK is a great idea for groups or even a party of 1. The bill for our group was very reasonable and the food was outright delicious! Thank-you, Mr. & Mrs. Sheikh! Also, don't miss the rice pudding; amazing!

excerpts: We inhaled the veggie samosas, daal makhani, butter chicken, and garlic/regular naan.
Also, on the way, our cabbie asked us where exactly we were going,
once we told him, he started raving about the place and said he'd just found it the night before...

He also ran inside with us, placed his order, and said see us in a bit when he comes back to pick it up :)
Summing it up, this place teeters on my list of possibly the best Indian/Pakistani food I've ever eaten.
I would say 'locals only' but then it would make the tourists flock here.
My boyfriend says I'm not allowed to tell the tourists that they'll be mugged if they go here.
butter chicken.author: Paula S.
butter chicken.review:
Heads up; you cannot be shy here, you grab a table/seat where ever you can find for your party, then grab a menu from the counter and fill out your own order slip and hand it over to whomever will grab it.
Next, get your plates/cutlery/napkins.
Finally, wait. It's worth it.
We walked by this place years ago and the smell was freaking amazing. We didn't go in because we were there to take a friend to a certain restaurant (#fail), we finally made it back and will continue to frequent. 
Nomnoms:
We inhaled the veggie samosas, daal makhani, butter chicken, and garlic/regular naan.
Also, on the way, our cabbie asked us where exactly we were going, once we told him, he started raving about the place and said he'd just found it the night before... He also ran inside with us, placed his order, and said see us in a bit when he comes back to pick it up :)
Summing it up, this place teeters on my list of possibly the best Indian/Pakistani food I've ever eaten. I would say 'locals only' but then it would make the tourists flock here. My boyfriend says I'm not allowed to tell the tourists that they'll be mugged if they go here.

excerpts: We had butter chicken (fyi, when you order it hot, it will be HOT!) and chicken saag with naan and pappadam.
Everything was delicious, and the place is casual and homey.
butter chicken.author: Elli F.
butter chicken.review:
I can't believe I lived across the street from this place for a year and then in the area for another year and a half and just tried it out now.  Seriously!  The food was really good.  We had butter chicken (fyi, when you order it hot, it will be HOT!) and chicken saag with naan and pappadam.  Everything was delicious, and the place is casual and homey.  I will certainly be coming back.

If you are looking to use your airline miles through restaurant.com (which is how I ended up trying Lahore Karahi out, they do accept the certificates!

excerpts: but I don't recommend the butter chicken there.
butter chicken.author: Christian P.
butter chicken.review:
I got the Butter Chickenw ith rice and a naan. It was just alright. Good portion tho for a little over $10.
The tandoori meats looked really good tho. Maybe I'll give the place another try for its tandoori but I don't recommend the butter chicken there.

excerpts:
My companions had:
- saag gosht - fair
- chicken saag - barely touched
- butter chicken - adequate
- chicken biryani - barely touched

Breads:
- Onion kulcha was soggy and needed salt
- Naan was OK but buried under the kulcha in layers, became soggy.
butter chicken.author: Martha M.
butter chicken.review:
I don't understand the hype about this place.  I was excited to try it after reading all the good Yelp reviews, and was sadly disappointed.

First off, we tried to order some appetizers for a table of 5.  Vegetable samosas?  "Sorry, we are out."   Aloo Tikki?  "Sorry".  OK, then just some vegetable Pakoras, and some Aloo Paratha.  Papadams?  "No need to order, they are on the house".

- There were no discernible vegetables in the pakoras. They were heavy and  without good flavor. The "chutneys" accompanying them were watered down sauces with flat flavors.
- The papadams never arrived; we had to ask twice and they finally showed up with the entrees
- The paratha never showed up
- "Out" of samosas, probably the most popular Indian appetizer, early on a Saturday evening?  What, they ran out of flour and potatoes?

Main courses:  

- having read so many raves about the tandoori fish, I had to try it.  The flavor, spice and burn were all good, but something must have been unbalanced since I found myself burping tandoori for the next 6 hours.

My companions had:
- saag gosht - fair
- chicken saag - barely touched
- butter chicken - adequate
- chicken biryani - barely touched

Breads:
- Onion kulcha was soggy and needed salt
- Naan was OK but buried under the kulcha in layers, became soggy.

Summary:
Service: slow, missed items
Atmosphere: dank
Food: sub-par

excerpts: I ordered butter chicken, but whatever-- I really didn't want to wait another hour for that to come around.
butter chicken.author: Tianyi S.
butter chicken.review:
Lahore Karahi is as delicious as ever! And, as it seems to be with every delicious downtown eatery, less accessible than ever! Hungry diners, be warned. If you plan on popping in during SF-dinner-rush-hour, (6-8pm) hoping to order-and-eat in a span of two, even three hours... well... lol. Just, lol. 

The problem, my group realized, during our two-plus-hour dining experience, is that there is only one, max two chefs, cooking each order, lovingly, one at a time, be it rush hour or not. So the creamy, stewy daal makhany you ordered? Yeah, it's going to take at least 20 minutes on top of the time it takes Chef Guddu to make everything else. 

Not realizing this, my group of four crowded in at 7:30, wrote down our order via the new-fangled self-service process, watched the tab slip into Guddu's pocket, and sat down to wait. And wait. And wait. And then wait some more. When, 45 minutes later, the single waiter hurried out with an urn of hot chai, everyone made a mad beeline for it, hoping to refuel their starved bodies with the sticky, hot concoction of caffeine, milk and sugar. It was gone within 10 minutes, and would not be replenished.

An hour and 15 minutes later, we went to check on our meal ticket, which was still lying, crinkled and forgotten, in Guddu's pocket. Realizing this, he pulled it out, chuckling apologetically, and placed it in front of all the other meal tickets, which were being arbitrarily assembled and sent out. 30 minutes after that, we flagged down the harried waiter, who asked if we wanted some naan in the meanwhile. We did, and it came out buttery and hot, within five minutes. Having made this awesome discovery (that naan is the only thing that will come out in under five minutes) we called for more, and when we were finally satiated with the puffy rounds of bread, the dishes started coming out, (at this point, past the two hour mark) staggered, one by one. 

The food wafted up to our noses in fragrant curls of steam, and every bite of my chicken tikka masala was tender, silken and spicy. I enjoyed it greatly, despite the fact that I didn't order chicken tikka masala-- I ordered butter chicken, but whatever-- I really didn't want to wait another hour for that to come around. The kabobs were deliciously smoky, and the aloo paratha yielded comforting, giant mouthfuls of spiced potato and fresh cilantro. 

At 9pm, the atmosphere crackled with the polar swing of ravenous irritation and silent content. Merry beer drinkers gave way into irascible finger-tappers. A displeased Indian family dissolved into smiles when their tandoori fish finally made it to their corner table. 

All said, it would probably be easier to know a Pakistani mama who can make similarly delicious food for you, but if that isn't obtainable... Come full so that you can digest your food during the two-hour wait and then be hungry enough to eat again, or just come really late. 9:45pm should do the trick. You'd have to be a real trooper to eat here regularly.

Happy eating!

Bottom Line: Epitome of the ridiculous foodie experience.

excerpts: I love the butter chicken here and my boyfriend loves the lamb korma!!
butter chicken.author: Cnn F.
butter chicken.review:
We have been here twice. The food has been amazing both times. I think the price is great. For the quality of food that you get, the price is very outstanding. Both times we came, the waiter messed up our order. The second time there, we brought our two friends and unfortunately we had to witness a cockroach crawling on the wall. 

2 STARS for the restaurant itself - it is small, old, and smokey because the kitchen is pretty much part of the dining area

41/2 STARS for the food 

I love the butter chicken here and my boyfriend loves the lamb korma!!

excerpts: There were 6 of us, including a 4 year old who thought everything was too spicy except for the Naan... the rest of us enjoyed everything from the Butter Chicken (the best I've ever had...just the right blend of spices and texture-
butter chicken.author: Kit S.
butter chicken.review:
We love good Indian/Pakistani food...there are far too many eateries out there with substandard dishes (especially the cheap buffets!!!)  We don't like to waste our time, so we rely on reading reviews here to help us when eating out of town.  We liked the reviews we read and decided to take a chance at Lahore Karahi.

We were not disappointed!!!  There were 6 of us, including a 4 year old who thought everything was too spicy except for the Naan... the rest of us enjoyed everything from the Butter Chicken (the best I've ever had...just the right blend of spices and texture-I ordered mild but the 4 year old still thought it was too spicy,  to the grilled plates, tandoori fish, kabobs and saag paneer for our vegetarian daughter).

My husband liked the kabob a lot!!!  He is very picky about his Kabobs since he is from Iran and eating good Kabobs is very important to him. 

I must say, the highlight of the evening was eating the tasty fresh out of the the tanoor, Naans.  We ordered all kinds... even ones not on the menu (Keema Naan).  Everything was reasonably priced except for the soda cans!!!  (If you can avoid ordering the overpriced drinks... then you won't be angry about having to pay $3 for a can of Sprite/Pepsi when a fresh homemade Naan straight from the oven is only $1.  (But I could be wrong about the price of the drinks since I didn't actually look at the bill personally and just going by what one member of our party was saying... which is why I didn't take a star away from my ratings.)  

Anyway, our server, a young boy (probably owner's son) was very polite and pleasant, but distracted probably because many people do go through.  We were lucky to be there when it wasn't quite so busy just yet.

I highly recommend this place... especially for those tired of the same menu and blah taste of the usual Paskistani/Indian food.  This place is small.. a bit of a hole int he wall.. but worth venturing to!  You won't regret it!

excerpts: butter chicken be made mild, and that was the perfect amount of heat for me--in no way could it be considered "mild," at least insofar as this whiter-than-white girl is concerned, but it was spicy enough to make me feel warm and fuzzy.
butter chicken.author: Jennie K.
butter chicken.review:
A crackhead tugs on my sleeve.  "Come here, sweetie," he says, and holds on as I try to continue walking.  He was the crackhead of my dreams, I assure you, and if I hadn't had dinner plans, I totally would have run away with him, but...  "Uh, no," I say, jerk my arm away, and hurry on up Leavenworth to Lahore.

Mmm!  Local flavor!

Sketchy neighborhood aside, this may very well be my new favorite restaurant.  We went on a Sunday night--there was plenty of business, but we didn't have to wait for a table.  It's not a fancy restaurant (although it looked pretty clean and spiffy to me), but the smell of the food knocks you flat and proceeds to permeate your entire being, until you smell like curry and MAGIC.

(I had a date that night after dinner, and made my friends smell me afterwards to see if I smelled more like hugs (another story entirely) or indian food.  Verdict: hugs.)

I requested that my (delicious! and $6.50!) butter chicken be made mild, and that was the perfect amount of heat for me--in no way could it be considered "mild," at least insofar as this whiter-than-white girl is concerned, but it was spicy enough to make me feel warm and fuzzy.  Naan and rice are a must, of course.

Best part: it is incredibly cheap.  With tax and tip, the five of us paid $11 each.  This is after 3 orders of both naan and rice, plus five entrees.  Normally I don't put a price on personal safety, but I think a delicious $11 dinner is a fair trade.  I'll walk though the crackhead microcosm for this!

NOTE: their BYOB policy is no longer in effect, and they took our beers from us.

excerpts: We ordered butter chicken which was bland.
Also we ordered baingan bharta which was so definitely NOT baingan bharta!
It was a creamy gravy instead of a dark roasted eggplant in a thick tomato base!
And let me not even start about the naan - it was ridiculous.
Bottom line - awful place, do not go there!
butter chicken.author: Shruti S.
butter chicken.review: Extremely disappointed. The place came highly recommended and I had high expectations. We ordered butter chicken which was bland. Also we ordered baingan bharta which was so definitely NOT baingan bharta! It was a creamy gravy instead of a dark roasted eggplant in a thick tomato base! And let me not even start about the naan - it was ridiculous. Bottom line - awful place, do not go there!

excerpts: I've had the well loved fish curry, and really liked it, the the potato/cauliflower aloo gobhi (extra interesting here and absolutely delicious with what can be relatively bland ingredients) and the butter chicken.
butter chicken.author: Mike F.
butter chicken.review:
I've been here twice now, and if I was just rating the food, I would give it 5 stars, particularly for value for the money but we went last night and the service was just dreadful. We ended up missing the movie we were supposed to go to because the service was so slow.

Let's start with the food. All of the dishes I've had are richly spiced and really nicely put together, especially for $7 or $8. Even old standbys are extra tasty here, and they aren't greasy which can be the downfall of some cheap South Asian restaurants.

I've had the well loved fish curry, and really liked it, the the potato/cauliflower aloo gobhi (extra interesting here and absolutely delicious with what can be relatively bland ingredients) and the butter chicken. All were delicious.

The first visit I made a month or so ago (7/09) the service was quick and efficient. It's a small room and one person should be able to cover it even when busy.

Last night, 9/12/09,  was just dreadful. The one waiter was scattered and couldn't seem to figure out that bringing more than one dish from the kitchen at a time would be more efficient and less annoying to the patrons. He would go to the kitchen, get one thing, and then go back and get another and take it to the same table. Crazy. 

It took 30 minutes for our food to come which seems very long in a restaurant of this sort. People who sat down after us got their food before us, which is always irritating, moreso when you're trying to go to a movie up the street. The waiter was also packaging to go orders, so it's not entirely his fault, but he clearly had no idea what he was doing. 

When the first dish finally came, we reminded him to bring us the bread, rice and mixed pickle we ordered, which he brought ON THREE SEPARATE TRIPS from the kitchen, even though it's either pre-made (pickle) or sitting there waiting to be dished up (bread and rice).

Just crazy. it would make me hesitate to go back, particularly if I was in a hurry, like last night. I'd also say that for a little more money, travelling up the street to Sultan (behind the Hilton on O'Farrell) will get you as good a food and FAR better service.

excerpts: My girl friend gets the butter chicken.
butter chicken.author: Peter G.
butter chicken.review:
This might just be my favorite restaurant in San Francisco! 

Lahore is nestled in a very a safe/ un-sketch block in the tandor-loin.  Parking is always easy, prices are right, service is great, and the food is heavenly..

I've tried several Pakistani/Indian places, and this by far exceeds any competition.  Lahore is seriously in a league of its own!  

I typically order the chicken tikka marsala, mango lassi, garlic naan and a few samosos.  My girl friend gets the butter chicken. 

Trust me you can't go wrong!

excerpts:
Not everything is a winner, but these are 5-star-worthy:

* butter chicken--this one is different than the one at Amber, which is more tomatoey; it's creamy and has a combination of spices I can't ID.
butter chicken.author: Mehul P.
butter chicken.review:
Not everything is a winner, but these are 5-star-worthy:

* butter chicken--this one is different than the one at Amber, which is more tomatoey; it's creamy and has a combination of spices I can't ID.
* kheer--mushy like it's supposed to be, not milky which seems to be the norm.
* biryani--better than (Mission) Pakwan. Pakwan biryani is rustic, and here it's tender, spicy, and refined.

Looking back at my list, it looks like an unadventurous order of a Indo/Paki dilettante. All that's missing is the garlic naan, which I also order. But whatev.

excerpts: Jerry, Omar and I feasted on Chicken Vindaloo, Butter Chicken, some other chicken fantastakabobbie thing, garlic naan and mango laasi's.
The butter chicken was indescribable.
It seemed to be a combination of a light curry, a smattering of sweetness (cinnamon, I assume) with a tub and a half of butter thrown in for good measure.
I wanted to doggy paddle in the freakin' sauce...
it was that good.
butter chicken.author: Mc Matty b.
butter chicken.review:
I've been wanting to get my 'curry on' over here for years, because it's just a few doors down from the loved ones house. The place is usually packed to the gills, but since I no longer have the temperament to dodge the occasional stray bullet and/ or hooker, we'd always end up elsewhere. And then came the rain...washing all the hoodlums away, and the customers apparently. Lahore Karahi was empty! Jerry, Omar and I feasted on Chicken Vindaloo, Butter Chicken, some other chicken fantastakabobbie thing, garlic naan and mango laasi's. 

The chicken vindaloo was perfectly spiced, although if I had it my way - I would have made it bloodcurdling hot. My fellow diners have weaker constitutions.  The naan was thinner than what I am usually accustomed to...less dense, with a light crisp to it.  More importantly: the garlic was fully-cooked, not thrown on at the end, rendering it too pungent.  The butter chicken was indescribable.  It seemed to be a combination of a light curry, a smattering of sweetness (cinnamon, I assume) with a tub and a half of butter thrown in for good measure.  I wanted to doggy paddle in the freakin' sauce...it was that good.  The mango laasi's were perfectly paired for the dishes as well...not too thick, and not too sweet like some other places I've been to.

And now the pet peeves:  The Bollywood film playing on the television was simply terrible...and yet I could not peel my eyes away from it.  The food was brought out awkwardly...one dish at a time, then the naan.  By the time the raita came - there was nothing left on the table to dip (other than my spoon, and so I ate it like soup).  Also they did not give us enough rice for three people.  Lastly, Jerry bit down on a 

R
O
C
K

(okay, it was a pebble)  But still - WTF.  He sank it in his water glass, cleaned it off and passed it around the table.  Sure enough - it was a rock.  We banged it against the table...scratched the table with it in fact.   And then we scratched our heads.  Maybe it was a spicy rock? A spice rock?  A cinna-pebble? We debated how such a pebble could get into the vindaloo, and then debated some more whether to tell the chef-owner when paying.  Jerry decided he should.  The owner just kinda looked at it for a bit.  Then he picked it up and rolled it between his fingers.  The smile never left his face.  I felt awkward.  US/ Pakistani relations are slightly strained right now, and I thought this might add to the tension, so I went out for a smoke...

Moral of story:  Enjoy the food...order extra rice and avoid rocks and uncomfortable situations.

excerpts:
Sesame Naan
Seekn Kabab
Butter Chicken
Lahore Karahi Rice

Everything we order was good.
butter chicken.author: Emily W.
butter chicken.review:
My friend brought me here for dinner one night and I have to say it  was so good! I was not sure what to think since it is not in the nicest part of town and it was a hole in the wall place.

We went to dinner on a Friday night and it was very crowded - we had to wait a little bit for a table.

We got:
Garlic Naan
Sesame Naan
Seekn Kabab
Butter Chicken
Lahore Karahi Rice

Everything we order was good. It did take a bit to get the food since there is only one person who works the front of the restaurant but it was well worth the wait. 

When I went it was BYOB - but from what I have heard that has not changed (too bad too).

The dinner is also very inexpensive....

excerpts: Butter chicken ($6.50)
The chicken in the butter chicken was awesome- definitely marinated in something yummy!
Lahore Karahi is small, cheap, and yummy- infinitely better than Naan n' Curry buffet at 2am that I didn't go to (okay I did, but I regret it!).
I only subtracted a star because the portions were pretty tiny.
My boyfriend and I split the two dishes and two naans and my half was just barely enough food for me.
When we got home, he started eating again.
butter chicken.author: Cersei T.
butter chicken.review:
Highlights:
Garlic naan ($2.50)
Butter chicken ($6.50)

The prices were fair, just like the weather.  We also had mill juli sabzi ($5.50) and regular naan ($1).  The dishes were all really good- not too oily.  The chicken in the butter chicken was awesome- definitely marinated in something yummy!  Lahore Karahi is small, cheap, and yummy- infinitely better than Naan n' Curry buffet at 2am that I didn't go to (okay I did, but I regret it!).  I only subtracted a star because the portions were pretty tiny.  My boyfriend and I split the two dishes and two naans and my half was just barely enough food for me.  When we got home, he started eating again.

excerpts: Saag Paneer, Butter Chicken, Freshly made Naan and all Halal.
butter chicken.author: J A.
butter chicken.review:
What did you do with my adopted Indian mom, Elizabeth?

 Did you kidnap her and have her make your samosas for you? Where is she hiding???? 


Where did you put my maataa? 


After all the times she recommended Shaadi.Com, told me I can marry anybody I want, told me "you're so pretty, you'd make good babies!",chased Akshay Kumar (the wrong Akshay http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akshay_Kumar) thinking it was the right Akshay who I have a crush on in Bollywood films, all through the entire Singapore Aiport just to get an autograph? One day she had to move and I have not had a good samosa since that day. :( We keep telling each other we will find time and she'd hunt down Akshay for me and feed me more samosas, but alas, that day in Goa, stuffing my face with her samosas is but a dream.

But wait,  after not seeing her for awhile, I think she is here....hiding somewhere in the kitchen of this hole in the wall restaurant with authentic yummy food and Old  1960's Bollywood flicks of Sholay and Khabi Khabi!  After all the stories of her in Bombay making food, and her colorful stories of travel, Lahore Karahi has captured my mum Elizabeth. Good business move. 

The food tastes like my adopted mum's, so don't expect to leave in a hurry. Good food takes time. When it's from scratch, you can consider it homemade. 
So Lahore Karahi is far better, so it can't even be compared to Shalimar. Shalimar becomes Delhi Belly and Lahore Karahi is like being in Elizabeth's Kitchen, while she tells me stories and tells me repeatedly, "You're sooo pretty, you can get any husband you want, You'd make good babies!"
 Doesn't get better than that. Saag Paneer, Butter Chicken, Freshly made Naan and all Halal. OH BOY! 

Hey Aunty Elizabeth,Where's Akshay Khanna (the right Akshay http://8c.img.v4.skyrock.com/8cb/fleurdeglace01/pics/89131440_small.jpg)? I think you need to go to Goa next time to find him for me. He surfs like me! :) Of course, if Lahore Karahi can spare you for a week. I'm sure they could let you go for awhile. But I'm sure they were doing just as well before, but I'm convinced, they have you, Aunty. Return the Samosas to me. ALL OF THEM. :D

excerpts: My friends and I had the Butter Chicken, Lamb Korma, Aloo Gobhi (cauliflower and potato), and side orders of Lahore Karahi Rice and naan.
Although I'm not a big fan of Indian food, the chicken seriously made me reconsider this--I loved the flavor of the creamy sauce and butter.
Butter definitely makes everything better.
The lamb was extremely tender and the curry, well-spiced.
It's always interesting to see cinnamon sticks used outside of desserts.
I found the cauliflower and potato to be mediocre, but my friends really enjoyed this dish.
Anyway, I'm actually looking forward to trying more Indian food--or just to get more of that butter chicken.
This is definitely one of the better Indian restaurants I've been to in my life.
butter chicken.author: Liz T.
butter chicken.review:
Four stars for the food alone, but I had to take one off because 1) we found a strand of hair in our food and 2) the waiter asked us to leave right after we paid the bill because a party was waiting. Not cool on both counts.

My friends and I had the Butter Chicken, Lamb Korma, Aloo Gobhi (cauliflower and potato), and side orders of Lahore Karahi Rice and naan. Although I'm not a big fan of Indian food, the chicken seriously made me reconsider this--I loved the flavor of the creamy sauce and butter. Butter definitely makes everything better. The lamb was extremely tender and the curry, well-spiced. It's always interesting to see cinnamon sticks used outside of desserts. I found the cauliflower and potato to be mediocre, but my friends really enjoyed this dish. The rice was incredibly fragrant and the naan, hot and doughy--I'm just in love with everything doughy.

The waiters will serve you water but you have to self-serve Chai tea. I don't understand the logic in this at all. Anyway, I'm actually looking forward to trying more Indian food--or just to get more of that butter chicken. This is definitely one of the better Indian restaurants I've been to in my life.

excerpts: butter chicken....
on point....
its sweet with some nuts.
great texture super yummy.
lamb biyrani
.... the rice is soo good!
i would just get this alone next time.
rice...it was okay but
butter chicken.author: Ashley H.
butter chicken.review:
i have been here three times but this is the first time i wanted to write a review. the first time i wasnt really impressed with the food. the naan is doughy and burnt....dont know how that happens...but it just wasnt that appealing. the first time i had the chicken tikka masala. again...not too happy with the quality. last night i got the following

garlic naan...ehh....no thanks
fish tandori...bomb!!! but hella spicey.
butter chicken....on point.... its sweet with some nuts. great texture super yummy.
lamb biyrani.... the rice is soo good! i would just get this alone next time.
rice...it was okay but not the best i have had.

its ok. it reminds me of naan and curry which i am not a super fan of either. i think some people might like it but im sure that if i dont mind walking one more block i can just go to chutney.

excerpts: Tikka masala, vindaloo, keema and butter chicken are all fine choices...but I recently discovered the nihari (not on the menu) which is my new favorite.
Nihari is a traditional Pakistani dish that's apparently served commonly for breakfast.
I don't have prior nihari dishes to compare it to, but I thought it was damn good.
It's a darker curry, a lot oilier, served with beef, (reminds you of Japanese curry) and packs a lot more punch with the spices.
If you try to get similar dishes - say CTM & Butter Chicken - he'll give you grief for getting the same thing and try to cajole you into ordering different tastes.
butter chicken.author: Tsubasa O.
butter chicken.review:
Gotta love the curries here. Tikka masala, vindaloo, keema and butter chicken are all fine choices...but I recently discovered the nihari (not on the menu) which is my new favorite. Nihari is a traditional Pakistani dish that's apparently served commonly for breakfast. I don't have prior nihari dishes to compare it to, but I thought it was damn good. It's a darker curry, a lot oilier, served with beef, (reminds you of Japanese curry) and packs a lot more punch with the spices. Ask your server if they've still got any nihari in the back because it ain't always gonna be around.

I'm not a huge fan of the tandoori fish (as I'm not a huge fan of tandoori to begin with), but it's still good. Naan's are solid here too, get them over the rice. 

I don't know where the old guy went (haven't seen him around the past couple times) but that guy's a character. If you try to get similar dishes - say CTM & Butter Chicken - he'll give you grief for getting the same thing and try to cajole you into ordering different tastes. Same thing with the naan - don't try to sneak in an order of two plain naan's or he'll get on your ass. 

When it's time to get the curry fix on in San Francisco, there's only one option - Lahore Karahi.

excerpts: Now on to the curry, the butter chicken and sagg paneer (or sagg ghost) are necessary as is the garlic nann.
All are melt in your mouth, artery clogging heaven.
I have never cared so little about my waistline as I have here.
Three dishes and three nanns between two people?
It was good, but hello butter chicken!
You're good enough to butter me up plump and get me walking bare foot with babies hanging off my shoulder.
If I end up dying and I have one last meal, you better be it babe.
butter chicken.author: Alexandra M.
butter chicken.review:
Hello my holy grail of curry fat, and spicy fare. Where the hell have you been all my life? Ah that's right you've been a damn good secret, and I hope you stay that way forever....not enough to close you down that is, but that doesn't seem to be a problem. 

There are so many great things about you, but here's one. You are open from 11am to 11pm everyday. Now for those who complain about waits, pish posh. I don't see a wait at 3pm ladies and gentleman. All I see is the smiling face of the owner as he prepares food for my friend and I, the only diners in the restaurant who funny enough are sipping on cold beer bought from the corner store (Bring Your Own Bottle makes a come baccccck!). Want some sparkling rose with your curry? Yes please.

Now on to the curry, the butter chicken and sagg paneer (or sagg ghost) are necessary as is the garlic nann. All are melt in your mouth, artery clogging heaven. I have never cared so little about my waistline as I have here. Three dishes and three nanns between two people? Usually a family could eat that, but two women who love Lahore Karahi can also do the job.

And then there's the tandoori fish. They won an award for this, but it was not my favorite. No not at all. It was good, but hello butter chicken! You're good enough to butter me up plump and get me walking bare foot with babies hanging off my shoulder. If I end up dying and I have one last meal, you better be it babe.

excerpts: We also had the butter chicken and lamb korma - each was made fresh (you can see the kitchen from the dining area) and filled with delicious spices.
The naan was crisp on the outside and soft on the inside - some of the tastiest naan I have ever had.
Prices were more than reasonable which allows you to order a bit more than you normally would.
Owner was there and was extremely friendly.
butter chicken.author: Dana H.
butter chicken.review:
Wonderfully prepared Indian food with Tenderloin prices - doesn't get much better than this.  The menu has all of the Indian staples you would expect, but also includes several seafood preparations (including a fish dish that gets great reviews).  

My dining partner and I stuck to the basics and ordered pakora to start off our meal.  The individual pakora were slightly larger than I was used to, but they were way more flavorful than the average preparation.  Sooo tasty with the mint sauce on the table.  We also had the butter chicken and lamb korma - each was made fresh (you can see the kitchen from the dining area) and filled with delicious spices.  The naan was crisp on the outside and soft on the inside - some of the tastiest naan I have ever had.  Prices were more than reasonable which allows you to order a bit more than you normally would.  Owner was there and was extremely friendly.

excerpts: Masala/ Butter Chicken right.
I am saying this because perhaps they have those recipes down
and I did not taste those dishes.
I don't think I will go back.
butter chicken.author: Roshan T.
butter chicken.review:
I would like to inform that I know a thing or two about Indian/Pakistani food since I come from that part of the world. 

I went with some high hopes after reading Yelp reviews. I had looked at the pictures of the restaurant  on Yelp so did not have high hopes on the ambience. I ordered take out for Chicken Tandoori and Lamb Vindaloo. After eating it I have to say that any novice by just reading recipes from the internet could have done a better job. Indian/Pakistani food is not about getting Chicken Tikka Masala/ Butter Chicken right. I am saying this because perhaps they have those recipes down and I did not taste those dishes. I don't think I will go back.

excerpts: Don't miss the butter chicken.
butter chicken.author: Ben A.
butter chicken.review:
Lahore.  Yes, I know Lahore is the name of a city, but it's still an epically unfortunate name for a tenderloin establishment.  But the food is amazing, the spice just right, and the price cannot be beat.  It's BYOB, and the staff is very welcoming, so you can really linger and have a great meal -- which is great as long as you're not the one waiting on one of the five tables.

The waiter once recommended the tandoori lamb chops as one of their best dishes.  It's very good, but the tandoori fish is my favorite dish, followed closely by the saag.  Unlike most indian restaurants I've been to, Lahore uses some sort of greens for the saag, rather than spinach.  Friends tell me that saag in India is made with a cousin to colllards or mustard greens, and the Lahore version is the most authentic they've had in this country.  I don't know about all that, but I can tell you that the saag is outstanding, as is anything eggplant.  Don't miss the butter chicken.

excerpts:
We ordered the deep fried potatoes and peppers, butter chicken, lamb roti, garlic naan and regular naan.  

Even though the garlic naan was good, I still think Shalimar's garlic naan tops Lahore.
butter chicken.author: Jon T.
butter chicken.review:
Actual rating: 4.5

I used to be fearful of Indian food, but recently had a change of heart.  The food here was absolutely amazing!  We ordered the deep fried potatoes and peppers, butter chicken, lamb roti, garlic naan and regular naan.  

Even though the garlic naan was good, I still think Shalimar's garlic naan tops Lahore.

I would take .5 stars off because the flatware was a little dirty and the staff was a little slow.

excerpts: The butter chicken had a weird consistency and tasted nothing like any butter chicken I've ever had.
butter chicken.author: Benjina D.
butter chicken.review:
Really, people? What's the big deal about this place? We went in for an early dinner on Sunday evening. The place was pretty empty and we were seated on the big table in the middle, even though there were only two of us. Next to a us was a little table in the corner full of dirty dishes. I looked around to see four tables that still had dirty dishes...all this was a huge turn-off, but we decided to stay anyway since the reviews were so good. The place is small, and only a few tables were taken, so why the waiter/buss boy was so damn slow in doing his work was beyond me. 

It was irritating to see him walk around, answering his phone every few minutes while doing everything in slow-mo.
